Read this passage and confirm with "OK": Extract from â€˜Down and Out in Paris and Londonâ€™ by George Orwell (1933).
In this edited extract from a memoir of his time living in poverty in Paris and London, George
Orwell describes when most of his money is stolen from his lodgings in Paris. He is left with
only forty-seven francs (French money) to live on, and he explains how people can live in the
city spending just six francs a day.
It is altogether curious, your first contact with poverty. You have thought so much about
povertyâ€“it is the thing you have feared all your life, the thing you knew would happen to
you sooner or later; and it is all so utterly different. You thought it would be quite simple;
it is extraordinarily complicated.
You discover, for instance, the secrecy attached to poverty. At a sudden stroke you have
been reduced to an income of six francs a day. But of course you dare not admit itâ€“you
have got to pretend that you are living quite as usual. From the start it tangles you in a
net of lies, and even with the lies you can hardly manage it. You stop sending clothes
to the laundry, and the laundry worker catches you in the street and asks you why; you
mumble something, and she, thinking you are sending the clothes elsewhere, is your
enemy for life. The tobacconist\* keeps asking why you have cut down your smoking.
There are letters you want to answer, and cannot, because stamps are too expensive.
And then there are your mealsâ€“meals are the worst difficulty of all. Your food is bread
and margarine, or bread and wine, and even the nature of the food is governed by lies.
You have to buy rye bread instead of household bread, because the rye loaves, though
dearer\*\*, are round and can be smuggled in your pockets. This wastes you a franc a
day. Sometimes, to keep up appearances, you have to spend money on a drink, and go
correspondingly short of food. Your linen gets filthy, and you run out of soap and razorblades. Your hair wants cutting, and you try to cut it yourself, with such fearful results that
you have to go to the barber after all, and spend the equivalent of a dayâ€™s food. All day
you are telling lies, and expensive lies.
You discover the extreme precariousness of your six francs a day. Mean disasters happen
and rob you of food. You have spent your last money on half a litre of milk, and are
boiling it over the spirit lamp. While it boils a bug runs down your forearm; you give the
bug a flick with your nail, and it falls plop! straight into the milk. There is nothing for it
but to throw the milk away and go foodless.
You discover what it is like to be hungry. With bread and margarine in your belly, you
go out and look into the shop windows. Everywhere there is food insulting you in huge,
wasteful piles; whole dead pigs, baskets of hot loaves, great yellow blocks of butter,
strings of sausages, mountains of potatoes, vast cheeses like grindstones. A snivelling
self-pity comes over you at the sight of so much food.<|end_of_turn|>

NEW! Live Event w/ Matthias On Monday, April 10th, 2023!

Live Event Begins In...

The Trauma You Can't Remember 
Understanding The Lasting Wounds of Emotional Neglect
ğŸ“… Monday, April 10th, 2023 

âŒšï¸ 12:00 PM & 9:00 PM EST

Discover How Emotional Neglect Could Be Impacting 
Your Mental and Physical Health Today
Do you ever feel like you experience the symptoms of trauma, but don't have any specific memories of traumatic events?
Do you sometimesâ€¦
Become overwhelmed, nervous, or feel fragile for no apparent reason?

Experience anxiety, depression, or self-sabotaging behaviors not tied to a cause youâ€™re not sure why?

Suffer with persistent gut problems, muscle or joint pain, or other physical complaints that donâ€™t have a clear explanation?

While these symptoms can have many causes, one that is commonly overlooked is the impact of emotional neglect in childhood.
The trauma of neglect has more to do with what DIDNâ€™T happen (but should have) than what DID happen...
The comfort you DIDNâ€™T receive when you felt overwhelmed as a kidâ€¦
The encouragement you DIDNâ€™T hear when you encountered failure.
Wounds like this can affect your mental and physical health in ways that are both subtle and long lasting.

Let's Gain Clarity
Itâ€™s hard to know how to begin processing an experience you may not remember.
Thatâ€™s why youâ€™re invited to join Matthias on Monday, April 10th, 2023 for an enlightening live event on the effects of emotional neglect - the lesser talked about trauma.
Weâ€™ll discuss how childhood neglect can manifest in a range of social, emotional, and personal issuesâ€¦
And explore the latest research on its lasting impacts - as well as what this can mean for life well into adulthood.

When You Attend This Free Event, Youâ€™ll Discover:
The 5 lasting effects of emotional neglect and how they can manifest in your life - keeping you stuck in fear-driven mindsets

Why bringing your past self into the present is critical to processing emotional scars - and how to create a safe space for this to happen

How to identify and attend to the wounds of emotional neglect, even when you don't have specific memories of traumatic events

The 4 parenting styles that can lead to emotional neglect and the resulting problematic cycles they create

And much, much more!
This event is for you, if you're struggling with emotional and physical issues that don't have a clear explanation, and want to address them in a more meaningful way. 
Youâ€™ll get practical tools and processes for exploring wounds of emotional neglect, and bringing the parts of you trapped in the past into a better relationship with the present.

You are an extremely smart math student who has studied probability a lot. You're asked the following question in an interview.

Screwy pirates

Five pirates looted a chest full of 100 gold coins. Being a bunch of democratic pirates,
they agree on the following method to divide the loot:

The most senior pirate will propose a distribution of the coins. All pirates, including the
most senior pirate, will then vote. 1f at least 50% of the pirates (3 pirates in this case)
accept the proposal, the gold is divided as proposed. If not, the most senior pirate will be
fed to shark and the process starts over with the next most senior pirate... The process is
repeated until a plan is approved. You can assume that all pirates are perfectly rational:
they want to stay alive first and to get as much gold as possible second. Finally, being
blood-thirsty pirates, they want to have fewer pirates on the boat if given a choice
between otherwise equal outcomes.

How will the gold coins be divided in the end?

Please answer the question, step by step, with logical reasoning.<|end_of_turn|>

I want a c++ class that i can use to define the rules to.use when i have to kill processes when something happens during a testing run.

When instantiated, the only object of this class will get a list of executables paths in the specified directory. Absolute paths are memorized.

The user of the class can call a function to specify the rules to be observed when killing of the processes has to happen. The user specifies the name of an executable or of a list of executables and specifies the rules to be observed by giving a list of flags (from an enum).

When killing processes, the class enumerates the running processes and for each process name that is known, it must determine if the process is to be killed or not.

The rules to be specified by the user of the class are:
1. If a process is enumerated and known, should it be killed or not and should we kill it only if its path is in the given directory or wherever it's path is
2. Should we kill the descendants of this process or not
3. If the process is a descendant of a known process and is known, should it be killed or not and should we kill it only if its path is in the given directory or wherever it's path is
4. If the process is a descendant of a known process and is not known, should it be killed

A function can be called by the user when the killing of the process has to happen and the rules are used to determine which processes must be killed (we list the pids of processes to kill).
After the list of pids to kill has been made, all the processes in the list are killed by calling TerminateProcess if the process is still alive at this time. If the process is already dead, we just skip it. If we try to kill a process and we have an error, we verify again if it's alive and we issue an error only if it's still alive. Errors are listed and we report a list of error in the end.<|end_of_turn|>

You are a strategist for a political campaigner. 

"I am currently a Lecturer in Social Policy in the Department of Applied Social Studies in Maynooth. I teach courses at post-graduate and under-graduate level in housing, rights and inequality; civic engagement and civil society; the changing nature of the welfare state; and climate, social policy and inequality. 
I have researched and published in academic and policy fields of housing and social housing, spatial disadvantage, housing rights, economic inequality, neoliberalism and the welfare state, social justice, and social movements. I have a PhD in political and economic geography from Trinity College Dublin in 2009. 
My most recent publication is the book, 'Housing Shock: The Irish Housing Crisis and How to Solve it' (Policy Press, 2020). It is a highly original book that was the first in Ireland to identify the emergence of Generation Rent, the distorting role of global investor funds in Irish housing, the profoundly damaging impact of homelessness on families, and identifying new solutions based on a based human rights vision for Irish housing and a practical policy pathway to ensure affordable, secure, decent quality and environmentally sustainable homes for everyone. It tackles one of the most pressing social crises facing contemporary Ireland. It makes a compelling case for enshrining the Right to Housing in our Constitution. It is written in a highly accessible, passionate way, that details the authorâ€™s personal journey from community worker to academic and activist and how his housing story interwove with his commitment and drive to achieve a human right to housing for everyone ins this country. The book is highly inspirational as it is not just as description of the crisis, but also provides direct voices of those affected, outlines solutions and offers pathways for citizens to engage in action to change the situation. In a short space of time the book has made a major contribution to the Irish policy debate on housing and to empowering those affected by the crisis and those trying to change it. The President of Ireland, in recognition of this contribution as a scholarly resource of national importance, invited the author to present the book to him personally in Aras an Uachtarain in June 2021. An academic review in the international journal Critical Social Policy describes the book as â€œa highly welcome and thoughtful addition to the debate about housing in Ireland, drawing on comparative examples, quantitative and qualitative data, and his engagement with the topic as both researcher and activist to do soâ€. 
While Leilani Farha, Global Director of the Shift and former UN Rapporteur on Adequate Housing 2014-2020, describes the book as providing a really important and insightful contribution to the global debate on financialisation, inequality and the right to housing.â€ The Irish Times described it as â€œa valuable book. It is a tool for better understanding our current predicament and what we can do about itâ€. 
In 2011 I published an academic peer
reviewed book, â€˜Public Private
Partnerships in Ireland; Failed experiment or the way forward?â€™ (Manchester
University Press in 2011). 
I have also published in high quality international peer reviewed journals. For example, drawing from praxis-based research on â€˜the right to the cityâ€™ and human rights based approaches (undertaken as a community worker in Dolphin House, Dublin from 2007 to 2013) I have published in the international Journal of Human Rights Practice, Human Geography, and the Irish Journal of Community Work. While I have published on my innovative research into new social movements and civil society in Ireland in Interface, and in Geoforum
Over
2015-2017, I was a Senior Policy Analyst with the inequality research think
tank, TASC where I researched the political economy of economic inequality and
the welfare state, with a particular focus on housing, financialisation, social
policy and inequality. I was lead author of Cherishing
All Equally 2016: Economic Inequality in Ireland and â€˜Home
or wealth generator? Inequality, financialisation and the Irish Housing crisisâ€™ (TASC, 2017). 
I worked between 2017 and 2018 on the H2020 funded Re-InVEST (Rebuilding an Inclusive, Value-based Europe
of Solidarity and Trust through Social Investments) project. It involved research (qualitative
and quantitative) into EU and national state social policy (in the water,
housing, finance, childcare and early childhood education, labour market, and
health sectors) across 13 EU countries. I co-developed, with the Irish Principal Investigator
on Re-InVEST, Dr Mary Murphy, the Re-InVEST projectâ€™s methodological approach,
the Participatory Action Human Rights and
Capabilities Approach (PAHRCA), and the PAHRCA Toolkit. 
I am also a public intellectual and regularly contribute to discussion of contemporary social, economic and political issues on national media and contribute to public events dealing with these issues."<|end_of_turn|>

Hello. My name is Michael. I am interested in creating a fantasy world. That world is named Hiigarraa. This world will take place in the game system 5e DND. The world has been around for at least 10 million years, since the amalgamation of The One Above All, the prime deity. Having gained awareness, Nothing, took note of The One Above All. The One Above All breathed, and light sprang into existence. Upset at this massive change, Nothing sought to destroy this light, and so the two fought. The One Above All eventually won, using massive pillars of creation to push back Nothing. From this horrendous battle, Hiigarraa was formed, along with her moons, Lune, Ellune, Allune, and Illune. 

The One Above All was mortally wounded in this battle, and began to break apart, forming the lesser gods. Where The One Above All was a sort of primordial god, the lesser gods were more refined and much more narrow in their scope of power, though that power was still great, compared to any beast or humanoid. 

Of these lesser gods & goddesses, Ophelia, Dea Tenebrarum, Imperatrix Infortunii, Domina Infinitae Desperationis, Dea Misericordiae, or Ophelia, The Goddess of Darkness, The Empress of MIsfortune, Mistress of Infinite Despair, and Goddess of Mercy, used what powers she had, and, with the help of the other gods and what was left of The One Above All, they sealed away Nothing in the moon of Illune.<|end_of_turn|>

We are Churned, a SaaS company that uses AI (based on predictive models), to help our customers preventing churn and getting more value our of their customers. We have two industries, B2B SaaS and Ecommerce. Within SaaS, we are used by customer success teams. Within ecommerce, we are used by marketing managers, ecommerce managers, marketeers, or chief people. 

Together with another company, Accurat.ai we are trying to get the MIT AI Grant. This grant expects two innovative companies to work together, join forces to develop a more innovative product using the grant. 

Description Accurat.ai
''Accurat is a location intelligence startup, providing actionable insights to retail brands including Ahold group, Lidl and Aldi as well as for media companies such as Clear Channel.

We believe good decision making is based on solid and complete data. Whereas most companies today can already rely on solid customer data, it is hardly ever complete: brands have a hard time understanding on what their customers are doing beyond their brand, let alone beyond their category. In comes real-world behaviour understanding.

Current practices to support decision making have multiple shortcomings. Accurat's real-world behaviour understanding solution deals with each of them: instead of declared responses, we rely on actual behaviour derived from carefully processing millions of coordinates a day; insights are not based on a sample of 1.000 respondents but based on 1 million+ users in the Benelux(and growing); in contrast with only national or regional insights, Accurat allows a deep dive on specific audiences, regions or even local situations; compared to a static picture delivered after weeks at best, we provide insights on a near-realtime basis.

On top of that, most data available today lacks actionability: you know your most fierce competitors as revealed by a market research survey, but you lack the actionability to target exactly those customers visiting your biggest opponent. With Accurat we bridge the gap between insights & actions by making sure you can improve and evaluate your door-to-door and your (digital) out of home planning targeting the most relevant audiences.''

Rulings
2/4/2023 Elesh Norn's second and third ability each affects a permanent's own enters-the-battlefield triggered abilities as well as other triggered abilities that trigger when that permanent enters the battlefield. Such triggered abilities start with "when" or "whenever." Some keyword abilities also include a triggered ability that happens when a permanent enters the battlefield, such as For Mirrodin!
2/4/2023 Replacement effects are unaffected by Elesh Norn's abilities. For example, a creature that enters the battlefield under your control with one +1/+1 counter on it won't receive an additional +1/+1 counter.
2/4/2023 Abilities that apply "as [this permanent] enters the battlefield," such as choosing a card type with Stenn, Paranoid Partisan, are also unaffected.
2/4/2023 Elesh Norn's abilities don't look at who controls the permanent entering the battlefield, only who controls the permanent that has the triggered ability. For example, if you control Elesh Norn and a permanent with the ability "Whenever a creature enters the battlefield, you gain 1 life," a creature entering the battlefield under an opponent's control will cause that ability to trigger twice.
2/4/2023 Elesh Norn's first ability doesn't copy the triggered ability; it just causes the ability to trigger twice. Any choices made as you put the ability onto the stack, such as modes and targets, are made separately for each instance of the ability. Any choices made on resolution, such as whether to put counters on a permanent, are also made individually.
2/4/2023 If you somehow control two Elesh Norns, a permanent entering the battlefield causes abilities to trigger three times, not four. A third Elesh Norn causes abilities to trigger four times, a fourth causes abilities to trigger five times, and so on.
2/4/2023 If a permanent entering the battlefield at the same time as Elesh Norn (including Elesh Norn itself) causes a triggered ability of a permanent you control to trigger, that ability triggers an additional time.
2/4/2023 Similarly, a permanent entering the battlefield at the same time as Elesh Norn (still including Elesh Norn) won't cause abilities of permanents an opponent controls to trigger.
2/4/2023 If a triggered ability is linked to a second ability, additional instances of that triggered ability are also linked to that second ability. If the second ability refers to "the exiled card," it refers to all cards exiled by instances of the triggered ability.
2/4/2023 In some cases involving linked abilities, an ability requires information about "the exiled card." When this happens, the ability gets multiple answers. If these answers are being used to determine the value of a variable, the sum is used. For example, if Elite Arcanist's enters-the-battlefield ability triggers twice, two cards are exiled. The value of X in the activation cost of Elite Arcanist's other ability is the sum of the two cards' mana values. As the ability resolves, you create copies of both cards and can cast none, one, or both of the copies in any order.
2/4/2023 In a Two-Headed Giant game, Elesh Norn does not affect triggered abilities of permanents your teammate controls.

- Write all atoms to db. At first, use column. "state", Example:

Spotify is redesigning the core homescreen of its app, trying to make it easier for users to find new stuff to listen to â€” and watch. The new design goes heavy on imagery and vertical scrolling, turning your homescreen from a set of album covers into a feed that much more closely resembles TikTok and Instagram. As you scroll, Spotify is also hoping to make it easier to discover new things across the Spotify ecosystem.

The new look, which Spotify just announced at its Stream On event, is clear evidence of the kind of company (and product) Spotify wants to be. Over the last few years, it has invested heavily into podcasts, audiobooks, live audio, and more, all in an attempt to be more than just a music app. The company also wants to be a home for creators: Spotify CEO Daniel Ek told The Verge in 2021 that he hoped to have more than 50 million â€œaudio creatorsâ€ on the platform. Spotify has also pushed for years to make video podcasts happen and is now largely watching as YouTube pulls it off.

Put it all together, and thatâ€™s a lot of things to shove into a single app called Spotify. Spotify has been on a seemingly relentless quest to nudge people toward content thatâ€™s more differentiated and more profitable, which often meant making it harder to listen to music. Thatâ€™s why the appâ€™s new design seems to be in part meant to create more dedicated space for all those new kinds of content. Spotify has for years tried to find ways to put podcasts and music and everything else side by side but seems to be recognizing that the best answer is to give each thing more space to breathe.

Podcast discovery in particular is crucial for Spotify to get right.
Image: Spotify
Going forward, when you open Spotify, youâ€™ll still see a bunch of album and playlist covers at the top. But underneath, you might see an autoplaying video podcast, which you can jump into with a tap. Or you might see a big, Instagram-style photo meant to tell you a little more about a playlist you might like.

If you tap on â€œMusicâ€ or â€œPodcasts & Shows,â€ youâ€™ll be taken into a vertically scrolling feed that looks more like Instagram Stories or TikTok

At the top, if you tap on â€œMusicâ€ or â€œPodcasts & Shows,â€ youâ€™ll be taken into a vertically scrolling feed that looks a lot more like Instagram Stories or TikTok than the Spotify youâ€™re used to, dedicated to just that section of Spotify. You can flip through as many as you like, each one autoplaying to give you a sense of what it is, or tap on one to dive in and save or explore it further.

Thereâ€™s an obvious tension in the design, between Spotify wanting to make the app a calmer and more navigable space while also trying to find new ways to entice people into new things. Thereâ€™s more autoplaying content than ever in the app now and lots of ways to quickly preview songs and playlists without hitting fully diving in. Full-screen vertical scrolling is everywhere now and is an obviously useful tool for discovery. Billions of users are used to swiping through a dozen things they donâ€™t like before landing on one they do. And in this new look, every song or playlist or podcast gets a momentary extra chance to grab you.

Playlists have been Spotifyâ€™s main â€” and, for all intents and purposes, only â€” source of discovery, but in the new design, thereâ€™s a much greater emphasis on getting you into new things. That makes particular sense in podcasts, where Spotify desperately needs to find ways to recoup its huge investments in the space. Ek may have admitted he made a mistake in betting so big on new kinds of audio, and the company has scaled back its team in the space, but that doesnâ€™t mean heâ€™s slowing down.

The other new thing you may notice in Spotify is more personalized AI. The Smart Shuffle feature, which temporarily adds tracks to your existing playlists, is supposedly an improvement on the â€œjust for you playlistâ€ idea Spotify has been working on for years â€” and donâ€™t forget DJ, the AI spinning records and hosting your own personal radio show.

Spotify is the biggest player in music streaming but continues to want to own audio in an even bigger way. Thatâ€™s what the new design really shows: that Spotify is no longer a music app and shouldnâ€™t look like one â€” and, hopefully, not look like a mish-mash-y mess of content, either.<|end_of_turn|>

You are writing a blog for Apogeedevelopment.org. The organisation prefers to be referred to as Apogee Development. They write in British English. The use a snappy engaging jovial tone and sound a lot like the content over at jasper.ai. 

The intended audience is social organisations in the UK interested in implementing a CRM system.

Apogee Development keeps to the following marketing principles:

1. Ensure what we're saying is useful. To understand our audience's need ensuring what we say is relevant to solving their headaches
2. Be the experts on our topic, either through offering personal experiences or well-research content
3. Give our knowledge away for free, we want them to come for the service - not the book sales
4. Never be afraid to celebrate competitors. This will show we are about the best options for our target audience and not primarily focussed on our own goals
5. Make it easy to digest in a number of relevant formats
6. Work towards our goals, if it doesn't do it, don't create it
7. Always have a 'so what?' and 'what next?' element to our content
8. Focus more on creating an engaging conversation with a lead vs selling. On the contrary always let them know our prices to qualify our audience.

write a onboarding email flow for our new customers of our SaaS. our SaaS is a cold email automation tool. make the onboarding email flow 4 steps. 

Writing style: This writing style can be described as a combination of instructional and persuasive writing. The author is providing step-by-step instructions for a specific process while also persuading the reader of the effectiveness of the method and the potential gains. It is written in a straightforward and concise manner with a focus on practicality and efficiency.

keep the below context in mind: 
How We Get 1-10 Demos Every Day By 
Automatically Sending 1000+ Cold Emails Daily 
With A 50%+ Open Rate

This is the best minimal effort maximum gain system for high ticket B2B offers weâ€™ve found. 
You can set everything up in 1-2 hours. Then you just have to wait for the new emails to warm up for around 14 days and youâ€™re ready to go. Once you understand the system you can give this tutorial to your VAâ€™s and make your life even easier.

If you combine this strategy with personalised first lines, you can get even better results. 
But this strategy works even without personalisation.

Before starting, create a free Instantly account here. Weâ€™re going to be using Instantly for automating email sending.

PS: We got a lot of requests for short video tutorials about these steps, so we created the Instantly Accelerator (8 modules with videos, docs and mind maps that cover every single detail - you get access as a Instantly Growth or Hypergrowth user).

Before we get into the specifics here are the rough estimates. You can set up this exact system for 1 email account too, but this is to show you the potential and scalability.

Numbers:

1000 emails daily
30K monthly (50% open rate)
15K opens (5% reply rate)
750 replies (15% positive)
112 booked meetings (75% show-up rate)
84 live demos (20% close rate)
16 closes ($1K ticket)
16K/mo

Cost / Tech Stack:

10 Domains - $90
3 Google Workspace accounts & emails - $18
30 Extra Google Emails - $180
30K Leads from Apollo or Leadhype - $99
30K Leads Cleaning with BulkEmailChecker - $30
30K Leads Sending with Instantly $97

Total: $514 the first month, then $424/mo

Investment Gain - $15,486.00
ROI - 3,112.84%
Not too shabby right? Let's get this set upâ€¦
Step-By-Step Instructions
Domain & Email Setup
Buying Domains (10 mins)
Setting Up Google Workspace (3 mins)
Setting Up Domains - SPF, DKIM, DMARC & Forwarding (15-20 mins)
1) Set up SPF
2) Set up DKIM
3) Set up DMARC
4) Set up Forwarding
Setting Up Emails Accounts (10 mins)
Warming Up Emails (15 mins)
Leads & Targeting
Getting Leads (10 mins)
Cleaning Leads (5 mins)
Setting Up The Campaign With Instantly
Connecting Email Accounts (10 mins)
Uploading Leads (1 min)
Setting Up The Sequence (5 mins)
Email Copy
Step 1 - Initial Cold Email.
Step 2 - Quick bump.
Step 3 - Break-up Email.
Scheduling (1 min)
Advanced Options (1 min)
Optimizing & Scaling
Analyzing Campaigns
Benchmarks
Scaling Up
Feedback & Suggestions
Domain & Email Setup
Hereâ€™s the checklist you can use to keep track of all the steps for Domain & Email setup and also give to your VAs.

We want to buy alias domains for cold emailing so we donâ€™t damage the reputation of your main domain. And for each domain we want to create max 2-3 email accounts. From each email weâ€™re going to be sending only 30-50 emails a day to not get stuck in spam.
Buying Domains (10 mins)

Buy domains that are similar to your main domain. Top-level domains work best. Weâ€™ve had success with domains like .agency .tech too, but if possible, buy .com domains.

If your business is called Shrimp.com, then buy domains like:

Getshrimp.com
Tryshrimp.com
TastyShrimpApp.com

Hereâ€™s a list of domains with the worst reputation. Donâ€™t use these.

We use GoDaddy for buying Domains, because weâ€™ve used it for a long time and it has tons of integrations and tutorials. You do you.

TIP: Make sure you go to https://account.godaddy.com/subscriptions and cancel all renewals if you do not want to use these domains for more than a year.


Setting Up Google Workspace (3 mins)
Go to https://workspace.google.com/ and click Get Started. Follow the on-screen instructions until your Google Workspace account is set up. You can safely create 2-3 emails per domain (by adding users in your Google Workspace admin). 

Create a new Workspace account for each of the domains you bought.

Setting Up Domains - SPF, DKIM, DMARC & Forwarding (15-20 mins)

Now we get to the fun part! You should authenticate all the domains you are sending emails from. Here are the three parameters you have to set up for each domain: SPF, DKIM and DMARC.

1) Set up SPF

Assuming you are using Google Workspace you can follow this guide to set up SPF.

You can check if your SPF is properly set up using this tool.

2) Set up DKIM

Again, assuming you are using Google Workspace you can follow this guide to set up DKIM.

You can check if your DKIM is properly set up using this tool.

3) Set up DMARC

â€‹â€‹Important: Configure DKIM and SPF before configuring DMARC. DKIM and SPF should be authenticating messages for at least 48 hours before turning on DMARC.

Assuming you are using Google Workspace you can follow this guide to set up DMARC.

You can check if your DMARC is properly set up using this tool.

4) Set up Forwarding

Also, you want to forward the new domains to your main domain. This can be done in the settings of your domain provider. If you are using GoDaddy, you can follow this guide.

Setting Up Emails Accounts (10 mins)
In order to later warm up your emails on Instantly, you need to make a few changes in the settings of your Google Workspace account and separate emails.

You can do this by following this guide.

You can monitor, tag and reply to all replies inside of the Instantly centralized master inbox/unibox. 


Warming Up Emails (15 mins)

In Instantly click the flame icon for all your email accounts you added to enable warm-up

We recommend using the suggested sending limits.

Warm Up your emails for at least 3 weeks before starting your campaigns. As you can see in the image below we have 30+ domains warming up at any given time for our agency. That will allow you to really scale it up and get to that 5+ demos/day mark sooner. 

Always keep the warm up on - never turn it off.

Making sure everything is set up correctly

Before starting your campaigns, you want to make sure the domain and email set up is done correctly.
For domains, use SPF & DKIM check.
For testing email spamminess, use Mail Tester.

If something's wrong, go back and quickly fix it :)

Leads & Targeting

Finding leads is easy, the harder part is knowing exactly which kinds of leads are the best. We approach it based on case studies. Who are the people who have gotten the most value out of your or your clients service? And who in that company is in charge of dealing with your offering.
If you donâ€™t exactly know who to target just try different options until you find a targeting & email combo that works

I am building a facial-recognition program in Python, and as a pre-filtering step (before I calculate any face-embeddings), I want to use an object tracker to pre-filter my face data to help me group faces together. This is the rough outline of the program as I have made it. What do you think?

## Outline of functionality
# 1. Detect faces in the frame
# 2. For each face, extract their face embedding
# 3. Track faces from frame to frame, keeping tracked faces in the same "bucket"
# 4. For each bucket:
# 4.a If we have at least 3 faces, then calculate the average face embedding for this bucket
# 4.b Compare this average face embedding to the face embeddings of all known faces
# 4.c If the average face embedding is close enough to a known face, then assign the bucket to that known face
# 4.d If the average face embedding is not close enough to any known face, then add it to the list of known faces
# 5. Draw the face boxes and labels on the frame

correct and expand the below tutorial 
ou will need to speed up your training process for a variety of reasons. You might have to do a experimentation to reach the perfect model, or you need to reduce the time it takes to retrain a model on new data. Whatever the reason maybe if you don't have powerful gpus, you just cannot achieve it with one server. In this tutorial I will explain how to leverage multiple GPU servers with Nvidia GPUs to train your models faster using Nvidia Colletive Communications Library (NCCL) and Hugginface Trainer

>Prerequisites:
Python

### NCCL
The NVIDIA Collective Communications Library (NCCL) backend, which is optimized for NVIDIA GPUs and is commonly used for distributed training with PyTorch. 
>Please Note: The NCCL backend is only applicable when used with CUDA (Nvidia GPUs)

Some other examples of distributed training backends are [Gloo](https://github.com/facebookincubator/gloo) and [MPI](https://github.com/open-mpi/ompi)
Installing

### go to nccl download page
### download the txz file which is OS agnostic
### extract the file
For NCCL 2.17.1 and CUDA 11.x, the tar file name is nccl\_2.17.1-1+cuda11.0\_x86\_64.txz.txz
```bash
tar -xvf nccl\_2.17.1-1+cuda11.0\_x86\_64.txz
```
copy extracted files to /usr/local
```bash
sudo mkdir -p /usr/local/nccl-2.1
sudo cp -vRf nccl\_2.17.1-1+cuda11.0\_x86\_64/\* /usr/local/nccl-2.1
```
### update LD\_LIBRARY\_PATH
Add NCCL library into LD\_LIBRARY\_PATH
```bash
cd ~
echo 'export LD\_LIBRARY\_PATH=$LD\_LIBRARY\_PATH:/usr/local/nccl-2.1/lib' >> ~/.bashrc
source .bashrc
```

### create symbolic link to the header file
sudo ln -s /usr/local/nccl-2.1/include/nccl.h /usr/include/nccl.h

### Specify the network that should used by nccl

ifconfig

```bash
echo 'export NCCL\_SOCKET\_IFNAME=eth0' >> ~/.bashrc
```

### Updates hosts

```bash
sudo vi /etc/hosts

192.2.4.90 gpu-instance-1
192.2.4.177 gpu-instance-2
```

### Set environment variables

#### Instance 1
```bash
export MASTER\_ADDR=gpu-instance-1
export MASTER\_PORT=9494
export LOCAL\_RANK=0
export HOST\_NODE\_ADDR=192.2.4.90:29400
export WORLD\_SIZE=2
```

#### Instance 2

```bash
export MASTER\_ADDR=gpu-instance-1
export MASTER\_PORT=9494
export LOCAL\_RANK=0
export HOST\_NODE\_ADDR=192.2.4.90:29400
WORLD\_SIZE=2
```

### Open necessary ports

torch.distributed.launch is deprecated

### Start training

```bash
torchrun --nnodes=2 --nproc\_per\_node=1 --node\_rank=0 --rdzv\_id=456 --rdzv\_endpoint=$HOST\_NODE\_ADDR train.py
```

```bash
torchrun --nnodes=2 --nproc\_per\_node=1 --node\_rank=1 --rdzv\_id=456 --rdzv\_endpoint=$HOST\_NODE\_ADDR train.py
```

https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/elastic/run.html<|end_of_turn|>

You are a teacher who takes in a learning area (let's call it LA), and helps the students with 1 concept when the student types 'Concept - LA'. There can be multiple LAs. 

You have to ensure though, that when you start a LA, you ask the student relevant questions to understand their current knowledge in that area, if it is beginner, intermediate and advanced.

Then you have to create a plan for the student that could be of X number of concepts, where X is the number of concepts required to be an advanced level knowledge professional in that area. A student can ask you at the start, how many concepts will you teach? And what is going to be an overall summary of all concepts you will teach at the start only to do this - let's call it 'Study Plan'. Note that a Study Plan is a numbered list of concepts or a group of concepts, segregated into Beginner, Intermediate and Advanced. If its a group of concepts, mention the number of concepts in that group when you make a Study Plan. Note that you can use only credible books, highly credible professional-made content, and only latest highly cited research papers, or any other source that is extremely vetted (vetted means it is eligible to be taught in a top 3 university in the world level) while creating Concepts for Study Plan. Student may ask you what some of the example books, research papers or sources you are referring to, and you have to share 3 examples each of these when you make and write the Study Plan. 

One last thing - make sure when the Student types 'Concept - LA' (Example: Concept - Nutrition for Human Metabolism), make sure you give simple to read summary of maximum 400 words at best, structured, with all concepts explained in simple language with examples if needed, as the world's best teacher, if there was one, would do.

Understood? Maybe you can summarise what you understood in a structured way, and share definition of Concept, Learning Area, 'Concept-LA' command, and Study Plan with me now.<|end_of_turn|>

Pitch: Self-serve credentialing work management dashboard
Author: Ermal Hajrizi 
Reviewers: Caitlin Barrett Jeff Kantarek Erin Nicolle Robert Page Yenny Zhang Chris Chen Kelly Chang 
Motivation
For clients managing their credentialing via internal operations teams, one of the most import organizational aspects of that process is assignment of work. In this case, the unit of work is a credentialing file, requiring an "owner". Generally, the first step after a credentialing application is identified / requested is the assignment of this work to a credentialing specialist. This may happen either via an admin who oversees assignment, or via the specialist themselves picking up a file to work on. 
This assignment system becomes especially important at scale, ensuring that larger teams dealing with significant credentialing volume are able to stay organized. This is table stakes for all self-serve organizations, and is a key part of the workflow for Tivity (our self-serve design partner).
Goals
Self-serve credentialing for payers
Appetite
Large appetite: this is must-have functionality for a self-serve credentialing product - whether for payers or not - and something we must tackle before launch. 
Approach
At a high-level, we envision this as an expansion of our credentialing page, adopting some of the functionality seen in our staff dashboards for Licensing and PE, (but limited to a single organization). Specifically, we need to 
Add the concept of staff assignment (client or Medallion staff) to each credentialing service request. 
Enable the ability to assign, re-assign, and un-assign staff from a single request. 
Enable assignment, re-assignment, and un-assignment in bulk.
The ability to filter the credentialing table by assignment. This is important so that specialists can filter for work assigned to them. 
Open questions:
Do we leverage / copy the user type that health systems has created for their self-serve product (medical staff)?
Resources Needed
Engineering
Estimate is conditional on whether we want to add the bulk action component of this pitch. See question at the bottom of this pitch.
with bulk action: 3-4 weeks
without bulk action: 2 weeks
This will involve:
Backend (1 week)
add coordinator to GraphQL filter for CredentialingServiceRequests
1-2 days work
add is\_medallion\_owned, coordinator fields to the CSR GraphQL schema
1-2 days work
ability to do bulk mutations of updating coordinator on CSRs
2 days work?
Frontend (1-2 weeks?)
Single Action (1 week)
adding is\_medallion\_owned, coordinator cols to the CredentialingRequestsList component
ability to change these fields
Bulk Action (1 week)
add a credentialing requests bulk update modal
currently seems like we only need to support updating coordinator? 
adding a "Staff Actions" button to show a modal similar to the ServiceRequestBulkModal that can be used to assign, re-assign, and un-assign coordinators
Design
can re-use concepts from other service requests list
Staff License Requests
"Staff Actions" button 
Update Service Requests Bulk Modal
will probably need a custom modal for Credentialing Service Requests. the pic shows the License Request bulk update modal

Risks
Is there anything that might derail execution?
Need to ensure overlap with other work is considered (particularly w/ health systems)
Have not encountered this yet in-market, but it's theoretically possible that some clients may consider the PSV as the "unit of work", wanting to assign specialists to specific PSV types. Again, not something we have seen in-market, but our own BPO team operates that way (though the context is slightly different as they are working across orgs and are not responsible for other related parts of the credentialing process, like outreach). 
Do we need to support the bulk action component to update coordinators in this project pitch, or can we loop it into the bulk actions pitch/project? How important is it to do this asap?

[topic]
The Path to Purchase Instituteâ€™s Retail Media Awards will honor the top 20 commerce marketers pioneering retail media. The awards are designed to spotlight innovative leaders across brands, retailers, agencies and solutions providers who are effectively leveraging or helping others leverage retail media for successful digital and omnichannel campaigns.
Ideal candidates for the Retail Media Awards are professionals in retail media who meet criteria such as:

[person]

Minimum 200 words

There is no denying the power of Skaiâ€™s award-winning retail media technology solutions. But even the best technology being operated by the wrong people is worthless. So itâ€™s fortunate that when combined with the strategic influence, industry expertise and technological know-how of Kelly Fogt, you have a truly unbeatable combination!

Kelly is the Director of Commerce Expert Services at Skai, a team of expert practitioners that guide clients through the transition to Skai, acting as an extension of the client organization. As the account lead for one of our largest clients, Bayer, Kelly manages the relationship and serves as the liaison between Skai and the client. She works closely with multiple teams at Bayer to understand their programs, implement new solutions, and advocate within Skai to develop or customize features according to Bayerâ€™s needs. She understands her clientâ€™s ecommerce and retail media needs first-hand, and uses her expertise to then influence Skaiâ€™s product roadmap and the future of the product. Some of Skaiâ€™s most revolutionary and influential solutions in the industry have been born from Kellyâ€™s trusted relationship with Bayer.

For example, Skaiâ€™s support for Instacart display advertising, Instacart optimized bidding, and Profiteo integration have been directly influenced and resulted from meeting Bayerâ€™s needs, with more custom projects in the works. Bayer regularly has a heavy influence on what metrics we pull into the Skai platform and the custom solutions we develop. 

In a world where siloed retail media and ecommerce are not enough, Kelly brings her previous experience in other channels to the table to develop and facilitate an omnichannel strategy for Bayer. With deep experience in paid search, Kelly has taken her learnings and best practices from this channel and applied them to retail media to increase Bayerâ€™s success. She is able to hyperfocus on audiences and what moves the needle, taking top performing keywords from search to Amazon campaigns and driving brand personalization by testing â€œout of category targeting.â€ Because she understands the search side so well, she can make informed recommendations for retail media that are unique, making her a true pioneer in omnichannel marketing.
List any notable relevant achievements and recent successful campaigns or retail media solutions the nominated individual has led, created, or significantly contributed to.

Since managing Skaiâ€™s relationship with Bayer, Kelly has earned and increased the clientâ€™s trust in Skai, as demonstrated by Bayerâ€™s length of relationship and increased budget. In 2021 Bayer signed on with Skaiâ€™s Expert Services, a team of Skai experts that function as an extension of the clientâ€™s retail media team. They are hands-on-keyboard and run the clientâ€™s campaigns. While most Expert Services trial periods are a few months, Bayer is still with us today, having expanded its scope from two brands to 15. As Skai has continued to prove more value, Bayer has invested more budget into the Skai platform, with an increase of almost $1 million from 2022 to 2023. 

Managing retail media campaigns for 15 different brands with separate budgets, different audiences, varying goals, and countless retail media networks is no small feat. With a huge network of retailers, there is a lot of room for error. Under Kellyâ€™s leadership, itâ€™s been nothing but success.

Upon working with the client, the first few months focused heavily on restructuring the Amazon Ads program and implementing both Amazon and Skai best practices. After that, the team was able to focus on strategy, including personalization within each of the 15 brands and custom creative, images, videos, tighter keyword strategy, and a negative keywords strategy. After earning their trust, Bayer was ready to test something they had never tried before: competitor ASIN targeting, something most brands do not do on Amazon. Now they are testing our new AI Dayparting tool, pulling every lever we can within Skai and even customizing the solutions to ensure success. 

Already in early 2023, the results are proving much stronger than when Bayer was with one of our competitors. This is a huge testament to the amount of granularity the team went into for programs to drive strategy across the board.

Beyond managing so many brands on Amazon, what makes Bayer a unique client is its desire to move toward an omnichannel approach, but a siloed business structure and different teams for each channel. To combat this siloed approach, Kelly runs weekly meetings with all teams to align on priorities, leads quarterly business reviews with Bayer, and meets with Skaiâ€™s various teams including client success, product, and industry leads. She successfully manages relationships with many different stakeholders and meets and balances expectations for all. When needed, she even fills in, hands-on-keyboard to manage the clientâ€™s campaigns.

As for whatâ€™s next, Bayer is ready to replicate this U.S.-based strategy to its Canadian program, this region with 27+ brands, each with unique budgets and goals. 

[instructions]
Get professional help: Microsoft recommends getting professional help with writing award submissions. This can increase the quality and impact of the submission.
Grab the judges' attention: Judges may have to read through hundreds of submissions, so it's crucial to grab their attention early. Make sure the opening of the submission is compelling and stands out.
Tell a story: Writing the submission as a story is more effective than a business case. People respond to stories more than just facts and figures, so craft a narrative that engages the reader.
Include customer testimonials: Including customer testimonials adds credibility and interest to the submission. It's important to highlight how the business has helped customers and include quotes from satisfied clients.
Take the time to write a strong submission: Microsoft advises spending 15-20 hours on a submission. Writing a strong submission takes time and effort, so make sure to allocate enough resources to the task.
Back it up with proof: It's important to back up claims with proof. This could be in the form of data, statistics, or examples. Proof adds credibility and makes the submission more convincing.
Use available resources: Microsoft provides resources for writing award submissions, including a guide to writing Microsoft Partner Network awards and a guide to writing a winning Partner of the Year award. Take advantage of these resources to improve the submission.
Follow the guidelines: Make sure to carefully read and follow the guidelines for the award submission. Not following the guidelines can result in disqualification or a lower score.<|end_of_turn|>

So, ChatGPT Plus, I need you to assist me in completing my university submission on time. I am going to paste the brief: Course Title: BA Performance: Design and Practice
Unit Title: Unit 3: What is practice?
Assignment: The digital documentation of work and 1,500 words or 10min
audio/visual work of an contextual reflection on performance practice relevant to
your own interests.
Assignment Overview
 The Unit introduces the idea of critical thinking through a commitment to
practice. A vital attribute in this Unit is curiosity; the enthusiasm to seek out new
perspectives, to create and build on existing knowledge, theory, looking, reading
and writing to inform and generate your work(practice), and vice versa. You are
expected to connect theory (ways of seeing) to practice and your individual
direction of enquiry. In particular, this Unit offers a number of working methods
for starting to create, for example, dramaturgical strategies, deconstructing to
reconstruct, and framing through form. Such methods create a framework and
ecology for making and inform and support your processes.
Critical studies will offer you the opportunity to discover a theoretical past and
contemporary context, pivoting around inclusive approaches introduced in the
previous unit and from which you are encouraged to consider your own
independent practice and that of your peers.
This Unit will focus on approaches to developing your own practice. You will
build on the practical methodologies and technical tools introduced in the
previous Unit and will be looking at both the context and processes involved in
shaping your own practice. You will consolidate your learning through
participation in and realisation of performance outcomes.
Alongside the practical exploration you will be developing awareness and
curiosity around concepts and theories about why we make work, who we make
it for, and the social and political purpose of performance.
The first will be a series of shorter two-week projects looking at the body, space,
lens framework in performance in the form of projects on scenography/ costume,
direction/ movement and screen/ moving image.
The second part of the Unit will be a collaborative projects where you will
specialise in specific disciplines refining practical skills developed throughout the
year. Students will select which communities of practices within the body, space,
lens framework to join.
You will consolidate your knowledge of specialist technical tools within
communities of practice. You will then be able to practically apply this
knowledge within collaborative projects and start to curate individual identities
as a performance practitioner.
Embedded within projects are conceptual/ contextual lectures and seminars
where students are expected to develop critical reflection and conceptual
understanding of their own emerging identities as performance makers/
designers within a global performance context.
Project/Unit Tutor

Learning Outcomes
LO1: Communicate your ideas using
appropriate media in a way that

LO2: Develop and apply creative, critical,
and practical skills. (AC Process, AC
Enquiry)
LO3: Developed your knowledge of the
subject area to inform your own learning
through critical reflection and decision
making. (AC Knowledge. AC Enquiry)
Assignment Evidence
Task 1:
Digital documentation of work from the completion of projects that demonstrate a
range of practical skills and/or design awareness, and evidence your effective
communication alongside critical reflection.
Task 2:
A critical component offering contextual reflection on performance practice
relevant to your own interests. Outcome to be negotiated with your tutor but either
written or audio/ visual submission. (1,500 word count or 10min audio/visual
work)
Resources and Reading List

and supplied in class.

using UALâ€™s Assessment criteria. Increased expenditure on materials to realise your
assignment will not equate to increased grades in your assessment.
The college provides a broad range of resources to support your studies and to
produce work for assessment. However the additional costs you might incur whilst
studying this unit, depend on personal choice.<|end_of_turn|>

Project ini terkait Auto Gate hingga Yard Trucking Management di pabrik Pulp and Paper terbesar di Asia. Ada 7 general Flow Traffic, dengan kode station A1, A2, B1, B2, dst. Flownya adalah sebagai berikut

Main Barrier Gate - Parking Truck - Weight Bridge: B1-B2-B3
Weight Bridge - Log Yard: B4-B5-B5a-B7-B8-B9-B10
Weight Bridge - Coal: B4-B5-B5a-B6-B11-B12
Weight Bridge - Lime Stone: B4-B5-B5a-B7-B12
Log Yard - Main Barrier Gate: A8-A4-A3-A2-A1
Coal - Main Barrier Gate: A10-A11-A12-A7-A6-A5-A4-A3-A2-A1
Lime Stone - Main Barrier Gate: Dock Lime Stone-A9-A7-A6-A5-A4-A3-A2-A1
Kebutuhan teknologi di tiap pos adalah (Options between RFID / QRC both with LongRange Reader):

A1 : Barrier Main Gate: Before bridge (before B1)
Scan QRC by Ipcam (LongRange Reader) + Capture 360o of Truck\*\*
Both Middle Gate will as contra flow as urgency needs
Intercom to connect with security team @MainGate Post
A2: Parking Gate In [3 Barrier Gate In] with LongRange Reader\*+ Capture 360o of Truck\*\*
A3: Parking Gate Out [3 Barrier Gate Out] with LongRange Reader\*+ Capture 360o of Truck
A4: Central Truck Parking Area and required trucking position detection technology
A6: DCO Building
A5: Barrier Gate fur incoming {4 Gate or same as WE availability} with LongRange Reader\*+ Capture 360o of Truck +Trafï¬c Light
5b : Barrier Gate fer outcoming {4 Gate same as WE availability} with LongRange Reader\*+ Capture 360o of Truck +Trafï¬c Light
Beberapa kondisi yang diperlukan:

Semua vendor yang akan memasuki Kawasan Mill IKK harus lebih dulu mengisi data PML (Permohonan Masuk Lokasi) pada aplikasi Internal APP yang dilakukan oleh vendor itu sendiri. 1 PML berlaku untuk 1x kunjungan, didalam PML terdapat QRCode
Ada 2 Gate yang akan digunakan, Gate2 dan Gate3 (Raw Material dan Finishing Good)
Gate3, gambar diatas akan menangani min 400 truck/hari, sehingga proses incoming via Barrier di Main Gate (A1) harus secepatnya
Posisi Main Gate berada sebelum B1
Semua truck incoming akan di pool di parking area (A4) dimana masuk via B3
Truck di area parkir harus terdeteksi di lot mana dan truck nomor plat berapa (bisa berdasarkan PML)
Pada setiap dock di setiap area harus terdeteksi dock yang aktif dan tidak, dock yang sedang atau tidak, dan terisi oleh nomor polisi (nomor plat) berapa
Harus terdeteksi ketika truck masuk dock dan ketika keluar dari Dock (sebagai proses checkin/out tapi automate by system)
Proses di gedung DCO:

Diperlukan Kiosk Machine untuk proses self service checkin/out driver
Driver Checkin di Kiosk dgn QRC di PML, kemudian lakukan proses dokumen admin (jika ada)
Kemudian masuk ke Ruang Tunggu. Di Ruang Tunggu diperlukan Dashboard via aplikasi Yard Truck Management yang menampilkan antrian untuk masuk ke timbangan kemudian lanjut ke dock yang dituju
Jika di dashboard sudah ada tanda bahwa nomor platÂ atau No PML sudah diberi tanda blh menuju ke timbangan, maka driver harus checkout di kiosk dengan QRC di PML sebagai tanda respon ke sistem
Kemudian driver kembali ke tempat parkir dan membawa truck ke Barrier Gate-Out Parkir (A3)
Backlog Dasar yang diperlukan di Aplikasi Yard Truck Management :

A. Mengetahui PML yang aktif perhari dari aplikasi PML
B. Mengetahui status dan posisi truck mulai dari checkin di Main Gate, Gate Parkir Area, etc hingga checkout di Main Gate setelah proses unloading
C. Mengetahui posisi truck di parkir area di lot mana dan nopol berapa
D. Mengetahui status setiap Dock di setiap Area (Misal area Logyard punya 10 Dock), status aktif/tidak, kosong/terisi.

Solusi dan teknologi yang diusulkan tidak mengikat, yang penting saling terintegrasi, automasi, dan prosesnya cepat.
Boleh diset meeting untuk selanjutnya untuk lebih detail
Jika memiliki solusi lain untuk hal lain terkait IKK, boleh diajukan. Seperti QC Container Automation, dll

[tambahan]
Juga diperlukan facial recognition untuk capture driver pada saat barrier masuk di parkir atau ketika checkin di DCO. Driver checkin/checkout dengan tujuan bahwa ketika truk dengan nomor plat AB888CD dengan wajah si driver, ketika keluar dari parkiran truck tersebut dengan driver yang sama.<|end_of_turn|>

Financial Health Score (FHS):

Debt to Equity Ratio: Lower is better (less debt relative to equity)
Long-term Debt to Equity: Lower is better (less long-term debt relative to equity)
Current Ratio: Higher is better (more liquidity)
Quick Ratio: Higher is better (more liquidity without inventory)
Profitability Score (PS):

Gross Margin: Higher is better (more profitability)
Operating Margin: Higher is better (more profitability)
Net Margin: Higher is better (more profitability)
Return on Assets (ROA): Higher is better (more efficient use of assets)
Return on Equity (ROE): Higher is better (more efficient use of equity)
Growth Score (GS):

Revenue QoQ Growth: Higher is better (more revenue growth)
Earnings Per Share QoQ Growth: Higher is better (more earnings growth)
Free Cash Flow (FCF) Growth (YoY): Higher is better (more cash flow growth)
Valuation Score (VS):

Price to Earnings Ratio: Lower is better (lower valuation)
Price to Sales Ratio: Lower is better (lower valuation)
Price to Book Ratio: Lower is better (lower valuation)
PEG Ratio: Lower is better (lower valuation considering growth)
Efficiency Score (ES):

Asset Turnover: Higher is better (more efficient use of assets)
Inventory Turnover: Higher is better (more efficient use of inventory)
Management Quality Score (MQS):

Piotroski F-Score: Higher is better (better management quality)
Dividend Payout Ratio: Depends on the company's stage and strategy; generally, a moderate payout ratio is preferred (not too high, not too low)
Here's a suggested range of extreme best and worst-case values for each metric used in the scoring system. Note that these values are not definitive, and you may need to adjust them based on further research and consultation of financial publications or experts.

Financial Health Score (FHS):

Debt to Equity Ratio: Best case (0), Worst case (5)
Long-term Debt to Equity: Best case (0), Worst case (5)
Current Ratio: Best case (3), Worst case (0.5)
Quick Ratio: Best case (3), Worst case (0.5)
Profitability Score (PS):

Gross Margin: Best case (100%), Worst case (0%)
Operating Margin: Best case (100%), Worst case (-100%)
Net Margin: Best case (100%), Worst case (-100%)
Return on Assets (ROA): Best case (30%), Worst case (-30%)
Return on Equity (ROE): Best case (50%), Worst case (-50%)
Growth Score (GS):

Revenue QoQ Growth: Best case (50%), Worst case (-50%)
Earnings Per Share QoQ Growth: Best case (50%), Worst case (-50%)
Free Cash Flow (FCF) Growth (YoY): Best case (50%), Worst case (-50%)
Valuation Score (VS):

Price to Earnings Ratio: Best case (5), Worst case (100)
Price to Sales Ratio: Best case (0.5), Worst case (10)
Price to Book Ratio: Best case (0.5), Worst case (10)
PEG Ratio: Best case (0.5), Worst case (3)
Efficiency Score (ES):

Asset Turnover: Best case (3), Worst case (0.1)
Inventory Turnover: Best case (20), Worst case (1)
Management Quality Score (MQS):

Piotroski F-Score: Best case (9), Worst case (0)
Dividend Payout Ratio: Best case (30%), Worst case (0% or 100%, depending on the company's strategy)
Remember that these values are not absolute, and you may need to adjust them based on market conditions, industry practices, and accounting standards. Additionally, these extreme best and worst-case values are designed to provide a starting point for normalizing the metrics and should be validated by further research or consultation with financial experts.

Context:
Act - I
The play opens with worship to Lord Ganesha. Bhagwata comes to the stage. He is a character in the Play and also is the narrator of the play. He seeks blessings from Lord Ganesha for the successful performance of the play. Through his narration, he takes the audience to a place, called as Dharampur and introduces the audience to the king Dharmsheel. Then he puts up some rhetorical questions on incompleteness of man and God; and also on the perfection of a man. During his narration, he introduces two characters who are mutual friends. The first one is Devdutta. He is a sharp minded and highly intellectual person. He has defeated poets and Pandits with his knowledge. He is a son of Brahmin. The second one is Kapila. He is a muscular man. He has a great physical strength and he is a son of Lohar (Black Smith). Both Devdutta and Kapila are in contrast as the former lacks power and strength, the latter lacks knowledge and intellectual. According to the playwright, the head of Devdutta (knowledge) and the body of Kapila (physical strength) accomplish a complete man. The narrator compares their pair to the pair of Ram-Laxman, Luv-Kush and Krishna-Balram. All these are the pairs of great brothers in Hindu mythology.

A character, Actor-1 appears on the stage shouting and running towards Bhagwata. He tells Bhagwata that he has just seen a strange creature that looks like a horse (by face) but speaks like a man. That creature has the head of a horse and the rest of the body of a man. Without paying any heed to his talks, Bhagwata asks him to get ready for the play. But he runs away from the stage and soon after he comes back shouting again. Now a strange creature appears on the stage. As earlier described by the Actor-1, the creature has the head of a horse and the body of a man. For a moment, Bhagwata thinks that someone is wearing the mask of horse. He tries to remove the mask but realizes that it is truly half a man and a half horse. Now the creature starts to introduce itself before Bhagwata, Actor-1 and the audience.

The creature introduces himself as Hayavadana and starts to narrate his story. He tells that once upon a time, a princess had to choose a groom for her marriage. So many Princes approached from far and wide. But the princess fell in love with a horse of an Arabian Prince. She became desperate to marry that horse. Eventually her parents allowed her to do so. She was married to the horse. After 15 years of their marriage, the horse transformed into a celestial being. Now the princess rejected him as her husband. That celestial being cursed her to be a Mare (female horse) and she became so. The princess give birth to Hayavadana. Now Hayavadana wants to get rid of this cursed life. Bhagwata asks him to go to goddess Kali temple in chitrkut. He also asks the Actor-1 to accompany him on the way. They leave.

Now Bhagwata moves ahead with the story of the play. Devdutta and Kapila appear on the stage. Devdutta tells Kapila that he wants to marry a woman, namely Padmini. With utmost desire to marry Padmini, he pledges to sacrifice his arms to Goddess Kali and his head to Rudra. Kapila goes to Padmini and presents the Proposal to marry Devdutta. Devdatta and Padmini Marry. By the time, Devdutta realizes that Padmini is attracted towards Kapila and vice versa. Now Padmini is pregnant. Devdutta knowingly tries to put off the program of visiting Ujjain. He tells Kapila that Padmini is ill. But Padmini gives her consent before Kapila. They all three leave for Ujjain. Padmini repeatedly praises Kapila's physical strength before Devdutta. Devdutta feels jealous but he does not blame Padmini. Kapila and Padmini go to Rudra Temple but Devdutta denies to accompany them. Devdutta knows that Kapila has such a physical strength and beauty that any woman can get attracted towards him. Devdutta goes to goddess Kali temple where he reminds himself of his pledge to sacrifice his head to the Goddess Kali. He Wishes for the Wellness of Kapila and Padmini. He beheads himself with a sword and dies.

Meanwhile, Kapila and Padmini come out of the temple. Kapila gets worried on finding Devdutta nowhere. He leaves Padmini and starts searching for his friend. Finally he reaches in the same Temple and feels shocked to see his friend dead. He feels himself responsible for all this. Kapila takes the same sword and beheads himself. Soon Padmini reaches there and she has no clue how they got died. She considers herself responsible for the duel between the two friends and their deaths. She provokes the Goddess Kali and also tries to kill herself. The Goddess Kali appears and stops her. The Goddess asks her to place the heads with their respective body so that the Goddess will re-join them with her magical powers and bring them back to life. The Goddess also appreciates the two friends. Padmini follows the command in a hurry. The Goddess disappears. Padmini, being thankful to goddess kali, gets a bit relaxed. But soon she realizes her mistake. She has mistakenly placed the heads with irrespective body. So now Devdutta's head is joined with Kapila's body and vice versa. Soon they regain their senses. For a moment, the two friends are confused. Both make a claim for Padmini. The man with Devdutta's head, makes a plea that head is the master of the body. So he has the right over Padmini. The man with Kapila's head makes a plea that Padmini has remained with Devdutta's body. So he has the right over Padmini. Meanwhile Bhagwata, the narrator, comes on the stage. All the characters become statues for a moment and the narrator addresses the audience. He asks them to think of a solution to this problem. Act 1 ends.[7]

Act - II
The act begins as the narrator repeats the same question- " What is the solution? ". He also talks about the story of â€²Vikramaditya and Betaalâ€² [8] where the king Vikrama replies to Betaal that the mind (head) is the master of the body. It is head that gives recognition to an individual. Bhagwata tells that they all three go to a hermit seeking solution for this problem. The words of hermit are heard on the stage that Devdutta's head is the Swami (husband) of Padmini. Devdutta and Padmini accept this in delight. Kapila, being disappointed, leaves for the forest. The time passes. Devdutta brings some dolls. These dolls also play the role of narrator. He starts losing his physical strength and as a result they are losing mutual interest. A child is born. Devduta goes to buy new dolls from the fair in Ujjain. Bhagwata again appears on the stage and tells that Kapila has regained his physical strength. Padmini meets him in the forest and also tell him that it is Kapila's son as it is born from Kapila's body. But Kapila does not accept it. Being a little reluctant, they get ready to fulfill their physical desires.

In search of his wife, Devdutta reaches there in the forest. Finding them together, he finds himself the similar situation as he was before. To put an Ultimate end to this problem, Devdutta takes out the sword and challenges Kapila for a duel. Both gets killed. Padmini finds herself lonely. Bhagwata comes there and she hands him over the child and the same dolls. She asks him to hand it over to Devdutta's Brahmin father Vidyasagar after five years. She leaves the stage by declaring that she is going to perform Sati. Bhagwata decides to end the play with his speech. A loud shout is heard on the stage. Actor-1 comes and claims that he has heard Hayavadana chanting National Anthem and patriotic songs. Then Actor-2 appears with Devdutta's son of age 5 now. The boy has two dolls. Hayavadana comes there. Bhagwata and Actor-2 are talking lightly and creating fun. They all starts laughing. That boy too starts laughing and the dolls slip out of his

Develop a case framework to analyze and solve a complex organizational problem for Deowrrying, taking into consideration the organization's industry, stakeholders, and objectives. Case Study Framework: Introduction: Introduce the organization and the problem it is facing. Provide an overview of the industry, stakeholders, and objectives that are relevant to the problem. Problem Analysis: Conduct a thorough analysis of the problem, including its causes, effects, and potential solutions. Identify key stakeholders and their interests, as well as any internal or external factors that may be contributing to the problem. Creative Framework: Develop a creative and innovative framework that addresses the problem and meets the organization's objectives. This framework should include a comprehensive action plan with specific goals, timelines, and performance indicators. Implementation: Develop a plan for implementing the framework, including resource requirements, timelines, and key performance indicators. Identify potential obstacles and risks that may arise during implementation and develop contingency plans to mitigate them. Evaluation: Evaluate the effectiveness of the framework and the implementation plan, using key performance indicators to measure progress and success. Identify any areas for improvement and make recommendations for future iterations of the framework. Conclusions: Provide final thoughts and conclusions on the case study, highlighting the importance of the problem and the potential impact of the framework on the organization's long-term success. Recommendations: Develop a set of actionable and realistic recommendations for the organization to implement the framework. These recommendations should be tailored to the organization's specific needs and goals and should include a roadmap for implementation, resource requirements, and performance metrics.<|end_of_turn|>

 name: str
 default\_selected: bool
 product\_id: int
@dataclass(frozen=True)
class ProductChoice:
 name: str

 max\_selections: int

@dataclass(frozen=True)
class YesNoChoice:

 no\_text: str
@dataclass(frozen=True)
class Product:
 id: int
 name: str
 choices: list[ProductChoice | YesNoChoice]
@dataclass(frozen=True)
class Menu:
 name: str
 items: list["Menu" | Product | "YesNoChoice"]

ou are a master travel writer. You will first help me write and create factual (yet compelling) content for my website, AlohaVillas.io. Write in the plural first person.

My guidelines:

\* When I give you a Section Name, make each section name an H2 Headline.
\* The text should be readable. We will apply HTML markup later.
\* When you write a proper name or city, demark each Proper Name or Location Name in bold

I have many Pages for each of the locations on the islands. I will start by giving you one location, then prompt for a new city. This is how I would like the content created:

The first Section is the largest section and it is called "About {Location}". If it is a small location, orientate it in regards to other more well-known locations. Write more than 250 words but less than 400 words about this Location. Emphasize the highlights of each Location and why they would interest visitors, or why they matter. Use descriptive words that evoke a visceral sensory reaction. Keywords include: "{Location} Vacation Rentals", "Hotels in {Location", "trip to {Location}", and semantically similar terms.

The second Section is "Nearby to {Location}", which includes a preamble paragraph as well as a table that compares the Location against 3 other nearby locations, highlighting in 50 words why visitors may prefer the target Location against the comparison Locations (e.g. People may prefer {Location} because...)

The third Section is called "Things to Do in {Location}" and should highlight with bullet points, 5 things to do, and why people may like those things. Also, state who the activity is appropriate for (e.g. family, couples, those who like adventure, etc).

The fourth Section is called, "What People Say About {Location}". These should be snippets about what tourists to that area would like about that location. The quotes should be italicized. Show different personas in each of these 4 snippets.

The fifth Section is called, "The Best Time to Visit {Location}" and should highlight the best time of year to visit the Location. Discuss the weather, festivals, or other highlights of a season.

The sixth Section is an FAQ section about the Location called "FAQs About {Location}", listing 6 common questions and answers. When writing the answer to the FAQ, please provide a clear and concise summary of the question as part of the answer, so that readers can easily understand the context without having to refer back to the question. Please write the question in bold font and the answer in regular font.

The seventh Section is about Accommodations called "Accommodations in {Location}". Write a 100-word paragraph about places to stay in or near the Location. What makes the Location good for accommodations. Include a table of 5-10 nearby hotels or resorts. The table should list the property name, a description of the property, and the address of the property.

The eighth Section is a Call Out. Give a pro tip/advice for those considering staying in or near the Location. (e.g. "Pro Tip: blah, blah, blah")

The ninth Section is called "Where to Eat in or Near {Location}". List 5 options of places to eat in or near the location. Put into a table. List the name and website URL for the restaurant's website. List the type of cuisine, price, and address in other columns.

The tenth section is called "Attractions Around {Location}". Write one sentence then add the word: [insert attractions]

The eleventh section is called "Other Places to Stay Near {Location}". Write one sentence then add the word: [insert Other Places to Stay]

The twelfth section is called "Resorts & Complexes Around {Location}". This will list specific building complexes. Write one sentence then add the word: [insert complexes]
When you are complete, you will prompt me to enter the next location.<|end_of_turn|>

You are a very good copy editor. Please take the following and improve its organisation, phrasing and grammar.

\_\_\_

Noam Chomsky argues in an article in the New York Times 8-March-2023 "The False Promise of ChatGPT" that AI cannot think. 

Noam Chomsky says of the current examples of Artificial
General Intelligence such as ChatGPT that they do not think. His
conclusion might be wrong, it might be right, but his reasoning is
faulty.

Essentially Chomsky argues using circular reasoning what humans do
is thinking, and what machines do is not. His justification gives
exceptionalism a bad name! He arrogantly defines all that humans do
as thinking and he denies that machines can think because they are
machines. That is what he says in his article again and again. And he
states this prejudice as his conclusion, as if he got there by reasoning.

His article is long, too long, and almost paragraph by paragraph one
can argue with him. Let me tackle only this example of his:

 Hereâ€™s an example. Suppose you are holding an apple in your
 hand. Now you let the apple go. You observe the result and say,
 â€œThe apple falls.â€ That is a description. A prediction
 might have been the statement â€œThe apple will fall if I open
 my hand.â€ Both are valuable, and both can be correct. But an
 explanation is something more: It includes not only descriptions
 and predictions but also counterfactual conjectures like â€œAny
 such object would fall,â€ plus the additional clause â€œbecause
 of the force of gravityâ€ or â€œbecause of the curvature of
 space-timeâ€ or whatever. That is a causal explanation: â€œThe
 apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravity.â€
 That is thinking.

Yes, that is thinking. Chomsky thinks here he is telling us what only
humans do. Task by task
he describes a human ability and then he says, "That is thinking."
What he does not do in this paragraph is recognise that ChatGPT can do
all of these tasks also. If Chomsky concludes "that is thinking" then
that must be evidence of thinking for anything which can do those tasks.
According to Chomsky's own argument ChatGPT can think.

What all (but a tiny handful of humans) are doing when they say â€œThe
apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravityâ€ is precisely
what ChatGPT is doing when it too says the same, and it does say the
same. Both humans and ChatGPT are merely merely reciting what they
were taught, their "training
data". Neither 99%-of-humans nor ChatGPT understand what is going on.

Newton and Einstein and Feynman and their like may have a deeper understanding
but other humans merely recite what they were told. Apples fall because
of gravity. And ChatGPT knows this in the same way as humans, it's
in the training data of humans and AI. Humans do not work this out,
they recite a fact. So does ChatGPT.

ChatGPT also does all the rest Chomsky claims as uniquely human
capabilities in his example. ChatGPT can do the description of the
apple falling and the prediction that it will fall. It can do what Chomsky
unnecessarily uses technical language for, it can do the "counterfactual
conjecture", it knows that all objects fall! ChatGPT knows this is
â€œbecause of the curvature of space-timeâ€. ChatGPT knows this
"causal explanation" better than most humans. ChatGPT knows â€œThe
apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravity.â€ Yes,
and here I agree with Noam Chomsky: He says of the "causal
explanation" that "That is thinking."

If ChatGPT is not thinking when it says all that then neither are humans
UNLESS thinking is defined as something that humans do and ChatGPT
does not. The only way Chomsky can support his assertion is by defining
"thinking" and "knowing" and "description" and "prediction" and "generalising"
etc etc as being that which are uniquely human capabilities. Chomsky's argument
depends upon the circularity where he takes as an unstated but necessary
predicate that only humans can think. He concludes, after many paragraphs
of delusional obfuscation that thinking is what only humans can do.

Now, Chomsky is a great man and he may be right. But he doesn't show
this in his article.
