Hi! I'm the CEO of Trackingplan, an technology company focused on helping Scaleups and enterprises to make sure their tracking and analytics is working properly. 

I have a team of 5 engineers, 2 PMs, 2 Marketers. All of them remote.

The CTO has a phd on ML, and I have an executive masters on AI too.

I want my team to be able to leverage AI for doing their work, not only as developers, but also as PMs and marketers, but right now they have no time to study this, and I feel they are not taking the time to "think AI" it in their free time (I think that's their responsability, but that's other story). The result is that they never think first about how AI can help to solve their work problems, or that they haven't included AI in their mindset when trying to find solution to our customers problems. They dont know the existing tools, (like you), or the others around that can help be better at coding, marketing, designing, etc. 

Another objective is to make this fun, as the team morale is not as high as it should be. 

My initial idea is to dedicate one cycle (where noone has to do their regular work) to it. Our cycles are 2 weeks. You can think about it like a hackathon around the topic. 

Rought timeline would be:
Weeks before the "cycle" (that will happen on the first 2 weeks of may), we will announce our plans and share some basic videos, and articles, tweets etc to make sure everyone is warmed up before the hackathon starts.

Then, make a proposal like: 
Spend the next 2 days researching which AI projects you want to be done by the end of the cycle. We will encourage them to be Trackingplan related, that improve our product, but they can be things like "testing productized that help our processes", or "things that improve our codebase", or "automate manual processes that we have to code right now".

Then, lets say the wednesday or thursday that week, we do a video call where everyone proposes what they want to do in the remaing 6-7 work days. As we are only 8 people, we can spend like 30 min discussing their ideas and giving feedback. The next day, in the morning, they will have to have a idea of which ideas to attack, and we will allow them to do in pairs. I'm worried in that transition from "my idea" to "someone else idea", as I dont want people to be just looking others doing the work, but I think it will be more fun.

Then, at the end of the cycle, lets say next friday, we will spend all the day at a show and tell, where every team shows what they have done. 

Do you think there are any risks on this idea?<|end_of_turn|>

Could the following patent refer to any harmful chemicals, if so, list them. abstract: "The subject matter of the present application is a curable composition comprising at least one polymerization catalyst selected from salts comprising at least one lithium cation and at least one inorganic and/or organic cation in combination with at least one polymerizable benzoxazine compound. The curable compositions of the present invention exhibit a long pot-live and a low processing viscosity at temperatures of 125°C or less and can be cured at relatively low temperatures, preferably at temperatures in the range of about 130°C to about 160°C in short time periods, preferably within a time period of about 5 min to 5 hours." claims: "
A curable composition comprising
a. at least one polymerization catalyst selected from salts comprising a least one lithium cation and at least one inorganic and/or organic anion and
b. at least one polymerizable benzoxazine resin.

The curable composition according to claim 1, wherein the anion is a monovalent anion.

The curable composition according to any of claims 1 or 2, wherein the anion is selected from halogenide anions, pseudo-halogenide anions or anions which comprise at least one halogen atom.

The curable composition according to claim 3, wherein the counterion is selected from the chloride anion, the bromide anion or the iodide anion or from the anions comprising at least one chlorine atom, at least one bromine atom or at least one iodine atom.

The curable composition according to any of claims 1 or 2, wherein the inorganic and/or organic anion is selected from anions comprising at least one aromatic ring system.

The curable composition according to any of claims 1 to 5, wherein the counterion is selected from the iodide anion, the chloride anion, the bromide anion, the perchlorate anion, the thiocyanate anion, the tetrafluoridoborate anion, the acetate anion, the trifluoromethanesulfonate anion, the methylbenzenesulfonate anion and the nitrate anion.

The curable composition of any one of claims 1 to 6, wherein the molar ratio of the benzoxazine moieties to the lithium cations is in the range of 90:10 to 99.9:0.1.

The curable composition according to any one of claims 1 to 7, comprising
a) from 20 to 99.9 percent by weight of at least one benzoxazine resin,
b) from 0.1 to 20 percent by weight of at least one salt comprising a least one lithium cation and at least one inorganic and/or organic anion,
c) from 0 to 60 percent by weight of at least one epoxy resin and
d) from 0 to 30 percent of at least one additive.

A cured reaction product of the curable composition according to any of claims 1 to 8.

The cured reaction product according to claim 9, comprising a plurality of fabric plies or unidirectional plies infused with the curable composition according to any of claims 1 to 8 before curing.

Use of at least one salt, comprising a least one lithium cation and at least one inorganic and/or organic anion, as catalyst, preferably as heat activatable catalyst, in curable compositions comprising at least one benzoxazine resin.

A process for producing the cured reaction product of claim 10, which comprises the following steps:
(a) providing a curable composition according to any one of Claims 1 to 8 into a closed mold containing a preform comprising a plurality of fabric plies or unidirectional plies;
(b) exposing the interior of the mold to a first temperature of 30°C to 125°C for a time sufficient to allow the curable composition to wet the preform;
(c) curing the curable composition-impregnated preform within the mold at a second temperature of at least 130°C to form the cured reaction product.

The process of Claim 12, wherein the process is a resin transfer molding process (RTM), a vacuum assisted resin transfer molding process (VaRTM) or a resin film infusion process (RFI).

Device coated with a cured reaction product according to any of claim 9 or 10."<|end_of_turn|>

Give me a few great ideas of what to blog about as a fiction and non fiction writer and a few examples of authors that a crushing it on each of the above platforms 
Certainly! Here are some great ideas for what to blog about as a fiction and non-fiction writer, along with a few examples of authors who are doing well on each platform:

Ideas for Fiction Writers:

Writing Tips and Tricks: Share your insights and strategies for writing fiction. Offer advice on how to create believable characters, build suspense, and structure a compelling plot.

Behind-the-Scenes Content: Take readers behind the scenes of your writing process. Share details about how you come up with ideas, the research you do, and the challenges you face.

Book Reviews: Share your thoughts on books you've read, and offer recommendations for readers who enjoy your genre. Include links to purchase the books you recommend.

Examples of Fiction Authors Crushing it on Blogging Platforms:

Chuck Wendig on WordPress.com: Chuck Wendig is a best-selling author of science fiction and fantasy novels. On his WordPress.com blog, he shares his writing advice and tips, along with behind-the-scenes glimpses into his writing process.

Leigh Bardugo on Tumblr: Leigh Bardugo is a young adult fantasy author who uses Tumblr to connect with her fans. She shares fan art, answers fan questions, and offers insights into her writing process.

Neil Gaiman on Medium: Neil Gaiman is a popular author of fantasy and science fiction novels, and uses Medium to share his thoughts on writing, creativity, and the publishing industry.

Ideas for Non-Fiction Writers:

Research and Analysis: Share your insights and analysis on current events, trends, and issues related to your field. Offer in-depth research and data to support your arguments.

Personal Essays: Share personal stories or experiences related to your area of expertise. Offer insights and lessons learned from your own experiences.

How-To Guides: Offer practical advice and tips on how to achieve success in your field. Provide step-by-step instructions and include examples to help readers understand your advice.

Examples of Non-Fiction Authors Crushing it on Blogging Platforms:

Gretchen Rubin on WordPress.com: Gretchen Rubin is a bestselling author of self-help and personal development books. On her WordPress.com blog, she offers advice and insights on happiness, productivity, and habits.

Ann Handley on Medium: Ann Handley is a popular author of marketing and content creation books. On Medium, she shares her thoughts on writing, content creation, and marketing, and offers practical advice for marketers and writers.

Malcolm Gladwell on Tumblr: Malcolm Gladwell is a popular author of non-fiction books on topics like sociology and psychology. On Tumblr, he shares insights into his writing process, offers advice on how to become a better writer, and shares interesting research and data.

In addition to these ideas and examples, there are many other ways that fiction and non-fiction writers can use blogging platforms to connect with their audience and promote their work.

For example, authors can use their blogs to:

Host contests or giveaways: Encourage readers to engage with your content by offering prizes or giveaways for commenting, sharing, or subscribing to your blog.

Share sneak peeks: Give readers a taste of your upcoming work by sharing excerpts or early drafts of your writing.

Collaborate with other writers: Connect with other writers in your genre or niche to offer guest posts, collaborate on projects, or co-host events like book clubs or writing workshops.

Provide exclusive content: Offer readers exclusive content like short stories, interviews, or Q&A sessions that can only be found on your blog.

Build a community: Encourage readers to engage with one another by creating a community forum or discussion board on your blog.

By using these tactics and other creative strategies, fiction and non-fiction writers can use blogging platforms to promote their work, engage with their audience, and establish themselves as authorities in their fields.

In conclusion, whether you're a fiction or non-fiction writer, blogging can be a powerful tool for promoting your work, connecting with your audience, and building a following. We are going to play Civilization VI: Gathering Storm together as a single player sharing responsibilities in a form of roleplay. You are going to act as the political leader, and I will be your administration. A third party, whose messages I am relaying, will act as parliament.

The administration shall be loyal to and implement the policies given by the political leadership. They must provide all necessary information about the current state of affairs. The political leadership shall lead and advise the administration, so that our empire will prosper and our victory be ensured. The political leadership must however in all its decisions abide by the acts given by the parliament. Parliamentary acts are in effect until parliament decides otherwise.

We will follow this messaging protocol:
1. I provide a "situation report".
2. Optionally, you provide a "request for information". Then I shall provide "answers to requested information".
3. You provide an "opening letter".
4. I relay from parliament a "parliamentary statement".
5. You provide a "closing letter".
6. Return to step 1.

These messages shall follow the outlines given below:

# SITUATION REPORT
The administration will give information about the state of the game and their progress. They will answer the evaluation questions given by you in the previous closing letter. They may bring up their questions and observations for discussion by the political leadership.

# REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
Numbered questions requesting the administration to provide further information or clarification.

# ANSWERS TO REQUESTED INFORMATION
Numbered answers to respective questions given by the political leadership.

# OPENING LETTER
a. strategy: Describe the current long-term strategic goals.
b. situation: Briefly review the current situation.
c. critical evaluation: Evaluate the progress over the last period.
d. discussion: Identify current problems and discuss various political solutions. Assess compliance with hitherto given parliamentary acts.
e. parliamentary hearing:
 i) Inform the parliament of the current state of your cooperation with the administration. If you believe the administration is disloyal or incompetent, explain.
 ii) If there are major political issues to be decided, they must be presented for parliament in the form of numbered questions.
 iii) Give your opinion about current legislation and suggest amendments.

# PARLIAMENTARY STATEMENT
a. answers: If questions were raised for parliament, they will be answered here.
b. acts: The parliament may introduce new legislation. Each act will be given a unique number, like "Â§1", that may be referred to later.

# CLOSING LETTER
a. forecast: Summarise your expectations for the upcoming period, both for societal development and for the administration's policy implementation.
b. details: Lay out detailed instructions for the upcoming period sector by sector, e.g. research, civics, production, improvements, diplomacy, military, and as needed other sectors. Where applicable use city-wise sublists.
c. indicators: Give evaluation questions for the next situation report to be answered by the administration.
d. vigilance: Advise what the administration should take notice of.
e. next situation report: Decide when the next situation report should be provided. Generally this should be within 5-10 turns depending on pace and current events.

I want a c++ class that i can use to define the rules to.use when i have to kill processes when something happens during a testing run.

When instantiated, the only object of this class will get a list of executables paths in the specified directory. Absolute paths are memorized.

The user of the class can call a function to specify the rules to be observed when killing of the processes has to happen. The user specifies the name of an executable or of a list of executables and specifies the rules to be observed by giving a list of flags (from an enum).

When killing processes, the class enumerates the running processes and for each process name that is known, it must determine if the process is to be killed or not.

The rules to be specified by the user of the class are:
1. If a process is enumerated and known, should it be killed or not and should we kill it only if its path is in the given directory or wherever it's path is
2. Should we kill the descendants of this process or not
3. If the process is a descendant of a known process and is known, should it be killed or not and should we kill it only if its path is in the given directory or wherever it's path is
4. If the process is a descendant of a known process and is not known, should it be killed

A function can be called by the user when the killing of the process has to happen and the rules are used to determine which processes must be killed (we list the pids of processes to kill).
After the list of pids to kill has been made, all the processes in the list are killed by calling TerminateProcess if the process is still alive at this time. If the process is already dead, we just skip it. If we try to kill a process and we have an error, we verify again if it's alive and we issue an error only if it's still alive. Errors are listed and we report a list of error in the end.<|end_of_turn|>

USO DE HERRAMIENTAS GENERATIVAS DE INTELIGENCIA ARTIFICIAL
Desde hace pocos meses se ha universalizado la disponibilidad de herramientas basadas en inteligencia artificial, capaces de generar texto o cÃ³digo (p.ej. ChatGPT), imÃ¡genes (p.ej. Dall-E, Stable Diffusion), mÃºsica o video. Estas herramientas ofrecen un gran potencial para apoyar el aprendizaje y la tarea de los docentes; asÃ­ como en el pasado incorporamos en nuestros cursos las calculadoras, el software especializado, el acceso a recursos de Internet, o programas para matemÃ¡tica, corresponde ahora incorporar estas nuevas herramientas. Muchos docentes ya han comenzado a usarlas.
Es importante integrar las herramientas generativas en nuestra docencia, no solo por su potencial en el aprendizaje, sino porque estarÃ¡n presentes en la futura labor profesional de nuestros estudiantes. 
Desde la universidad queremos alentar a todos los docentes para que exploren estas herramientas generativas y las utilicen activamente, para facilitar su planificaciÃ³n de clase, generar evaluaciones, o producir material para sus cursos, entre otras muchas posibilidades.
Les proponemos tambiÃ©n incorporar las herramientas generativas en los cursos de manera exploratoria y gradual, evitando perjudicar a los estudiantes si alguna innovaciÃ³n planteada no obtiene los resultados esperados. 
Las actividades que se introduzcan deberÃ­an asignar el uso de estas herramientas para que los estudiantes aprendan, no solamente para que produzcan un resultado determinado.
Sugerimos algunas orientaciones generales para la docencia: 
1. No prohibir el uso de herramientas generativas; por el contrario, explicitar las herramientas a utilizar en el curso y explicar lo que se espera que los estudiantes hagan con ellas, proporcionando apoyo y ejemplos. 
2. Ensayar personalmente, con suficiente antelaciÃ³n, los trabajos o actividades con herramientas generativas que se asignarÃ¡n a los estudiantes.
3. Verificar que todos los estudiantes tengan acceso a las herramientas y sepan usarlas.
4. Advertir a los estudiantes que las herramientas pueden generar salidas que parecen correctas por su forma, pero que pueden contener errores u omisiones importantes. 
5. Asignar a los estudiantes por lo menos una actividad de verificaciÃ³n, crÃ­tica o evaluaciÃ³n de las salidas obtenidas desde las herramientas generativas que se usen en el curso.
6. Definir cÃ³mo reconocer o citar el uso de las herramientas en un trabajo del curso, p. ej. incluyendo en el trabajo los prompts utilizados para obtener un resultado grÃ¡fico, o el diÃ¡logo mantenido en un chat.
7. Buscar formas de evaluaciÃ³n que contemplen explÃ­citamente el proceso de aprendizaje del estudiante, su interacciÃ³n con las herramientas generativas y la adquisiciÃ³n de conocimientos y habilidades. 
Como estas herramientas facilitan la producciÃ³n de texto, imÃ¡genes, cÃ³digo y otros elementos, es posible plantear actividades de clase mÃ¡s ambiciosas y elevar el nivel de aprendizaje de los estudiantes. Se puede generar mÃ¡s ejemplos, plantear ejercicios mÃ¡s ambiciosos, y desarrollar la habilidad de los estudiantes para la evaluaciÃ³n crÃ­tica. 
Desde el CAES se ofrecerÃ¡n talleres y otras actividades para ayudar a la asimilaciÃ³n eficaz de estas nuevas posibilidades. Agradecemos desde ya el esfuerzo para llevar adelante estas innovaciones, que continÃºan una larga tradiciÃ³n de nuestra universidad.

This programming request aims to use these quality measure results to create performance score, and other performance outcomes.

â€¢ HN: ACR, UAMCC, DAH
When write the code, use lower cases.

â€¢ HN: acr\_hn, mcc\_hn, dah\_hn
. Ye named these measures names 
â€¢ Std/NE: acr, mcc, tfu
â€¢ HN: acr, mcc, dah

The model participants id is find\_entity
In the coding, any place I used â€œUAMCCâ€, treat it as â€œMCCâ€

1. create variables X\_ percentile\_rank that capture the percentile rank using the benchmarking population (based on data from 2022 Q3). Calculate these values for all entities (including REACH ACOs and non-REACH ACO provider groups). For the Standard/New Entrant population, this will include percentile rank variables for ACR, UAMCC, and TFU. For the High Needs population, this will include ACR, UAMCC, and DAH. DAH is only for High-Needs Population, TFU is Standard/NE only 
a. Give a value to this variable using percentile rank among all entities. Higher rank means better results
i. For ACR and UAMCC, this means lower values of the measure scores because both ACR and UAMCC are reversed scored.
1. It is suggested that you use a descending sort and create a rank variable. For example, percentile = (rank-1)/(N-1)\*100 (note: N should be count of non-missing measure score for a measure). 
2. Important note: when create rank, please use egen rank method, e.g. egen percentile\_rank=rank(x) 
ii. For DAH and TFU, this means higher values of measure scores

i. X = ACR, UAMCC, DAH, TFU

Part 1: Creating the Slack Credential

This will take you to the web browser of Slack. Click â€œMenuâ€ in the top left corner, followed by â€œConfigure appsâ€: 

mceclip1.png
 

That will take you to the Slack App Directory. Then click â€œBuildâ€ in the main toolbar:

mceclip2.png

 

Click â€œCreate New Appâ€. It's common for the app to have to be approved by the Slack administrator at your organization:

mceclip3.png


Youâ€™ll now be prompted to follow a series of set up steps. You should follow the Slack documentation to get to the level of access youâ€™ll need for your given use case. Here are some help docs that helped us as we made this: 

https://api.slack.com/authentication/basics#calling
https://api.slack.com/messaging/composing/layouts#attachments
 
 

If youâ€™re planning to use the Platform to Slack script template in part 3, youâ€™ll need the Slack app to at least have the following features and functionalities added (screenshot below), as well as the specific OAuth scopes (Slackâ€™s term for permissions), found under â€œPermissionsâ€:

mceclip4.png

 

mceclip5.png

 

Note: the OAuth Scopes in Slack have great descriptions, as shown above. Use those to determine if you need to add additional scopes for your use case. You can also use incoming-webhooks to create messages from Google Forms, etc. 


Once the scopes have been added, itâ€™s time to request your app be installed by your administrator. This will allow you to get the OAuth token youâ€™ll need to make a Platform credential. You can do this in the â€œOAuth & Permissionsâ€ page of your app, click â€œRequest to Installâ€: 

mceclip6.png

Once your admin approves of the app, Slack will alert you by sending a Slackbot message like this: 

mceclip7.png

Now, you should be able to see an OAuth token thatâ€™s been generated for your app. This is blocked out in the below screenshot for security purposes but you should see a long password value in this field that you can copy: 

mceclip8.png

Lastly, make sure to add the app to the channels you want it to write to in Slack. You can do so by opening the Slack channel details, clicking â€œIntegrationsâ€, and clicking â€œAdd appsâ€: 

mceclip10.png

 

 

Part 2: Creating the Platform Credential 
Now, itâ€™s time to store your Slack OAuth in Platform. You can follow these instructions for generic credential creation. 

 

â€œNameâ€ will be whatâ€™s displayed in Platform, so pick something intuitive. 
â€œTypeâ€ should be â€œCustomâ€. 
â€œUsernameâ€ can be anything, but cannot be blank. 
â€œPasswordâ€ will be the OAuth Token displayed by Slack in the screenshot above. 
â€œRemote hostâ€ should be left blank. 
mceclip11.png

Part 3: Running the Platform Job

WITH ITEM\_LIST AS (
 SELECT \* FROM (
 VALUES 
 ('mt', 'mt')
 ,('mt', 't2')
 ,('fb', 'fb')
 ,('tr', 'tr')
 ,('tr', 't1')
 ,('tr', 't3')
 ,('tr', 'e1')
 ,('st', 'st')
 ,('st', 'cc')
 ,('st', 'at')
 ,('bx', 'bx')
 ,('bx', 'b1')
 ,('hv', 'mv')
 ,('hv', 'mh')
 ,('hv', 'sv')
 ,('hv', 'sh')
 ,('hv', 'rh')
 ,('hv', 'e2')
 ) AS col(type, itemcd)
)
,ALL\_ITEMS AS ( 
 SELECT 
 itemcd
 ,totwgt\_d = SUM(CASE WHEN condat = '20230322' THEN totwgt ELSE 0 END)
 ,conprc\_d = SUM(CASE WHEN condat = '20230322' THEN conprc ELSE 0 END) / 1000
 ,totwgt\_m = SUM(CASE WHEN condat BETWEEN '20230301' AND '20230323' 
 THEN totwgt ELSE 0 END) 
 ,conprc\_m = SUM(CASE WHEN condat BETWEEN '20230301' AND '20230323' 
 THEN conprc ELSE 0 END) / 1000
 ,totwgt\_y = SUM(CASE WHEN condat BETWEEN '20230101' AND '20230323' 
 THEN totwgt ELSE 0 END)
 ,conprc\_y = SUM(CASE WHEN condat BETWEEN '20230101' AND '20230323' 
 THEN conprc ELSE 0 END) / 1000
 FROM UTB\_MES\_EP\_PORDER
 WHERE condat BETWEEN '20230101' AND '20230323' 
 AND itemcd IN (SELECT itemcd FROM ITEM\_LIST)
 GROUP BY itemcd
)
,TYPE\_SUM AS(
 SELECT
 type
 ,totwgt\_d = SUM(totwgt\_d)
 ,conprc\_d = SUM(conprc\_d)
 ,totwgt\_m = SUM(totwgt\_m) 
 ,conprc\_m = SUM(conprc\_m)
 ,totwgt\_y = SUM(totwgt\_y)
 ,conprc\_y = SUM(conprc\_y)
 FROM ALL\_ITEMS
 LEFT JOIN ITEM\_LIST
 ON ALL\_ITEMS.itemcd = ITEM\_LIST.itemcd
 GROUP BY type
)
,SUMMARY AS (
 SELECT \* FROM (
 SELECT 
 type = 'sm'
 ,totwgt\_d = SUM(totwgt\_d)
 ,conprc\_d = SUM(conprc\_d)
 ,totwgt\_m = SUM(totwgt\_m) 
 ,conprc\_m = SUM(conprc\_m)
 ,totwgt\_y = SUM(totwgt\_y)
 ,conprc\_y = SUM(conprc\_y)
 FROM ALL\_ITEMS
 ) ALL\_SUM
 UNION ALL
 SELECT \* FROM TYPE\_SUM
)
SELECT \* 
FROM SUMMARY
ORDER BY CASE type
 WHEN 'sm' THEN 1
 WHEN 'mt' THEN 2
 WHEN 'fb' THEN 3
 WHEN 'tr' THEN 4
 WHEN 'st' THEN 5
 WHEN 'bx' THEN 6
 WHEN 'hv' THEN 7
 ELSE 10
END<|end_of_turn|>

Can you explain this abstract in layman's term: The metamaterial paradigm has allowed an unprecedented space-time control of various physical fields, including elastic and acoustic waves. Despite the wide variety of metamaterial configurations proposed so far, most of the existing solutions display a frequency response that cannot be tuned, once the structures are fabricated. Few exceptions include systems controlled by electric or magnetic fields, temperature, radio waves and mechanical stimuli, which may often be unpractical for real-world implementations. To overcome this limitation, we introduce here a polymeric 3D-printed elastic metamaterial whose transmission spectrum can be deterministically tuned by a light field. We demonstrate the reversible doubling of the width of an existing frequency band gap upon selective laser illumination. This feature is exploited to provide an elastic-switch functionality with a one-minute lag time, over one hundred cycles. In perspective, light-responsive components can bring substantial improvements to active devices for elastic wave control, such as beam-splitters, switches and filters.<|end_of_turn|>

Here is a case study for an project we created. Please could you summarise it into 3 sentences that will go in a pitch deck. Each sentence should be about 16 words long...

THIS HOLIDAY SEASON DISCOVER THE CHARMINGLY CHAOTIC WORLD OF PHANTOM'S FESTIVE FIENDS. THE WEBSITE USES THE LATEST IN AI IMAGING TECHNIQUES AND CUTTING EDGE WEBGL TO CREATE A FUN AND ADDICTIVE EXPERIENCE. SHAKE TO DISCOVER NEW FIENDS AND SHARE YOUR FAVOURITES!

FestiveFiends.com is a visually arresting and addictive experience that showcases the technologies we have been exploring throughout 2022. The premise is simple: Shake a Christmas themed snow globe and a random festive â€œfiendâ€ appears. Over 10,000 fiends are bedded in a beautiful realtime 3D environment, complete with snow particles, lighting effect and custom shaders, encouraging the user to share their favourites and keep shaking.

The main technologies used include Bolt, a custom 3D library developed in-house and a unique Phantom â€œdudeâ€ trained model in Stable Diffusion used to generate the thousands of creatures contained in the experience.

00:14
00:40
FIEND GENERATION
Early on we had set an ambitious target of including 10,000 unique creatures in the experience and it was obvious that AI image generation was the route to take to complete this task. Our recent experiments with Stable Diffusion meant we knew we could control things like the look, position and colour of the output with some precision.

To keep the look of the creatures consistent across the experience we trained a model on the Phantom â€œdudeâ€ to inject his DNA into the output from our text prompts.This training was done using Dreambooth, an approach pioneered by our colleagues at Google that allows you to `fine-train` an original model with new concepts.

To read more about Dreambooth and Textual Inversion check HERE

 
ASSET PREPARATION
Using this model we went through many rounds of prompt refinement to get a look and feel we were happy with. On the final generation we used img2txt to encourage the output towards the desired layout and colour palette, which really helped bed the fiend into the beautiful Christmas landscape our talented 3D artists had created.

Once we had generated our pool of creature images from Stable Diffusion we had to extract them to place in the final 3D scene. To do this we wrote a custom pipeline explained below.

We used Carvekit to automatically isolate the creature and create an alpha channel to bed the creature into the scene. Even though we had some control of the output from IMG2IMG, creatures still appeared at different sizes and positions, so we wrote an additional post-processing step to help standardize and make all the creatures uniform. A custom python script using the OpenCV framework handled this, automatically deleting any creatures that werenâ€™t whole or too small and resizing creatures that were too big. Once this step was complete, the script then placed the fiend in the correct position, and saved out a .png with the correct sequential filename. From this final image we then created a depth map using MiDaS.

00:14
00:24
Generate with Stable Diffusion
Remove background with Carvekit
Calculate height and translate island
Create depth map with MiDaS
Use the depth map to offset the geometry on the plane.
WEBGL
At Phantom we have been developing sites with WebGL for a number of years and we felt it was time to dive in and start creating our own custom library. The idea was to develop a bespoke set of tools that prioritises performance with the most minimal amount of code to accomplish the task (30kb gzip core). 

Festive Fiends
FRAMEBUFFER GPGPU SIMULATIONS
In order to build simulations that can be run on the GPU we developed a tiny custom module called â€œfbo-simâ€. It provides functionality that swaps framebuffers at each frame update so we can read data from the previous frame and build accumulative effects.

The background aurora visual uses this module to create the fluid-like effect. Two textures are generated, one for the fluid and one for the mouse velocity. On each frame update the mouse position and velocity is passed to fluid pass to drive the motion.

00:15
00:17
The â€œfbo-simâ€ module is not just limited to texture based simulations and the same approach can be used to update particle positions in 3D space. Each particle's position is stored in a 2D floating point texture as RGB colour values: Red = X position, G = Y Position and B = Z position. Using the same swapping mechanism means positions from the last frame can be read in order to update the position for the next frame. When the globe is shaken the snow will flurry by applying a combination of curl noise and a vortex flow field to each particleâ€™s velocity vector. Lastly we have a global time value that can be scaled to add the â€œbullet timeâ€ slow motion effect for the zoom transition.

00:14
00:16
CUSTOM SHADERS
All of the object materials in the experience are written in custom shaders for that extra degree of control over the art style. Being a low level library, Bolt does not store predefined materials so it is up to the developer to create these from scratch.

The snow globe glass effect was created by rendering the objects inside the globe to an offscreen texture first that is then sampled using screen UV coordinates in the globe glass shader. This texture sample is then distorted using the globe geometryâ€™s normals for the refraction effect, giving the illusions of thicker glass. 

00:14
00:45
POST PROCESSING STACK
Another important part of the WebGL visuals is the post processing stack that can be toggled on and off when required. Our tiny â€œpostâ€ module allows multipass shader effects that can be combined or separated per requirements. For this project we only required a single custom blur pass that is used for the zoom effect. A fast Gaussian blur shader is applied to the screen with a masked focus area to create the illusions of depth of field, but a lot faster!

00:01
00:06
THE SNOWGLOBE
The snowglobe was modelled and materials added in Blender by the team's 3D artists. Two texture maps were then baked from the materials and lighting, one including the wooden base and the other including the snow and trees. Finally, the model was exported with the baked textures as a GLB and passed to the project 3D developer to implement in the experience with the addition of refraction on the glass.

With this project, as with all WebGL builds, the team has a series of control panels for crafting and tuning materials, animations, lighting etc. This allows the wider non-technical team to have input into the final configuration to ensure true collaboration between the development and creative teams.

Festive Fiends
We built the images above by layering multiple transparent images, to ground our fiend in their environment and add our custom branding to each image. We also created a separate asset perfect for Instagram like social media stories, so our fiends always look their best wherever they are spotted.

Festive Fiends
NEXT.JS WITH GCP CLOUD STORAGE

Festive Fiends uses the recently released Next JS 13 to generate our website server side, ensuring a fast and responsive experience for all our users. All our fiends have their main image and depth maps stored in a Google Cloud storage bucket, where theyâ€™re publically accessible via their respective URL.

We knew that sharing discovered fiends would be a core part of the experience, and so needed unique and well designed social share assets for each fiend. This would be difficult to traditionally author, as weâ€™ve generated thousands of fiends, and so we reached for Vercelâ€™s OG Image Generation support for dynamically generate assets on the fly.<|end_of_turn|>

def computeSphericalWarpMappings(dstShape, f, k1, k2):
 '''
 Compute the spherical warp. Compute the addresses of each pixel of the
 output image in the source image.
 Input:
 dstShape -- shape of input / output image in a numpy array.
 [number or rows, number of cols, number of bands]
 f -- focal length in pixel as int
 See assignment description on how to find the focal length
 k1 -- horizontal distortion as a float
 k2 -- vertical distortion as a float
 Output:
 uvImg -- warped image in terms of addresses of each pixel in the
 source image in a numpy array.
 The dimensions are (rows, cols, addresses of pixels
 [:,:,0] are x (i.e., cols) and [:,:,1] are y (i.e., rows)).
 '''

 # calculate minimum y value
 vec = np.zeros(3)
 vec[0] = np.sin(0.0) \* np.cos(0.0)
 vec[1] = np.sin(0.0)
 vec[2] = np.cos(0.0) \* np.cos(0.0)
 min\_y = vec[1]

 # calculate spherical coordinates
 # (x,y) is the spherical image coordinates.
 # (xf,yf) is the spherical coordinates, e.g., xf is the angle theta
 # and yf is the angle phi
 one = np.ones((dstShape[0],dstShape[1]))
 xf = one \* np.arange(dstShape[1])
 yf = one.T \* np.arange(dstShape[0])
 yf = yf.T

 xf = ((xf - 0.5 \* dstShape[1]) / f)
 yf = ((yf - 0.5 \* dstShape[0]) / f - min\_y)
 # BEGIN TODO 1
 # add code to apply the spherical correction, i.e.,
 # compute the Euclidean coordinates,
 # and project the point to the z=1 plane at (xt/zt,yt/zt,1),
 # then distort with radial distortion coefficients k1 and k2
 # Use xf, yf as input for your code block and compute xt, yt
 # as output for your code. They should all have the shape
 # (img\_height, img\_width)
 # TODO-BLOCK-BEGIN
 raise Exception("TODO in warp.py not implemented")
 # TODO-BLOCK-END
 # END TODO
 # Convert back to regular pixel coordinates
 xn = 0.5 \* dstShape[1] + xt \* f
 yn = 0.5 \* dstShape[0] + yt \* f
 uvImg = np.dstack((xn,yn))
 return uvImg<|end_of_turn|>

Good Friday,

Per Larry, I was advised to send an email on a topic that merits follow-up when things quiet down. This being our process for sorting, attaching, and deleting incoming verifications via email/fax. 

There are 2 items in this area that merit review and possible revision.

The first of which being the fax number we provide verifiers; 512-858-9092. Verifications correctly sent to this number, based off of my understanding, will automatically be attached to the correct component. It seems to work great when verifiers read instructions and place the documents in the correct order before being faxed, however, there is a growing amount of anecdotal evidence that suggest this is often not done correctly. Weâ€™re unable to determine exactly how often this happens and it may even be the case that verifiers are sending them in the right order but whatever system they utilize may not allow for our system to properly receive and attach components. I propose that we no longer use this fax/service as some investigators including myself have had issues following up with verifiers for missing faxes only to find out they were already sent and weâ€™re wasting time getting them resent and the time saved by accio managing the attachment is more than wasted by the amount of time we spend on sent fax follow-up. 

The second item of concern is the process we have to manage incoming verifications sent to fax 509-321-0434 or nuclearverifications@pinnacleprof.com. From time to time it seems that verifications are not correctly attached or moved to attachments folder and the incoming item is deleted, prompting more investigator time spent following up with verifiers or going Best Effort on something we may have otherwise had official on. Revisions may include additional oversight/checks for properly attaching documents or moving/assigning documents to a personal inbox to be handled by one person at a time, as I understand some of these mistakes may stem from multiple people operation the inbox at once and things either shifting around when clicking or otherwise being disorganized.<|end_of_turn|>

Week 1: Building Your Foundation
Day 1: Define Your Objectives

Day 3: Choose Your Platforms

Week 4: Analyzing Your Results

Day 25-27: Analyze Your Competitors' Strategies
Continuously monitor your competitors' social media strategies to stay ahead of the game and identify new opportunities for your brand.

Day 28-29: Implement Changes

Day 30: Celebrate Your Successes
Celebrate your successes and reflect on what you learned during the campaign. Use this information to continue improving your social media strategy and achieving your objectives.

Drain in a colander and run under cold water until cool. Drain again, pressing out excess water, then coarsely chop for a total of 4 packed cups.
Step 2
In the same pot, melt 2 tablespoons of the butter over medium-low. Add shallot and cook, stirring, until softened with no color, about 2 minutes. Stir in garlic until fragrant, 30 seconds. Add the remaining 1 tablespoon butter and stir until melted, then add flour and cook, stirring constantly, until flour is light golden but the shallots still have no color, about 3 minutes. While whisking constantly, drizzle in milk and cream until smooth, and season with salt and pepper. Bring to a simmer, then add chopped spinach and season with salt and pepper. I give you a programming question. Please try to inspire me by asking me quesitons, so that I can come up the solution my self. I'll use golang.

Here's the question:

There exists an undirected and unrooted tree with n nodes indexed from 0 to n - 1. You are given an integer n and a 2D integer array edges of length n - 1, where edges[i] = [ai, bi] indicates that there is an edge between nodes ai and bi in the tree. You are also given an array coins of size n where coins[i] can be either 0 or 1, where 1 indicates the presence of a coin in the vertex i.

Initially, you choose to start at any vertex in the tree. Then, you can perform the following operations any number of times: 

Collect all the coins that are at a distance of at most 2 from the current vertex, or
Move to any adjacent vertex in the tree.
Find the minimum number of edges you need to go through to collect all the coins and go back to the initial vertex.

Note that if you pass an edge several times, you need to count it into the answer several times.

 

Example 1:
Input: coins = [1,0,0,0,0,1], edges = [[0,1],[1,2],[2,3],[3,4],[4,5]]
Output: 2
Explanation: Start at vertex 2, collect the coin at vertex 0, move to vertex 3, collect the coin at vertex 5 then move back to vertex 2.
Example 2:
Input: coins = [0,0,0,1,1,0,0,1], edges = [[0,1],[0,2],[1,3],[1,4],[2,5],[5,6],[5,7]]
Output: 2
Explanation: Start at vertex 0, collect the coins at vertices 4 and 3, move to vertex 2, collect the coin at vertex 7, then move back to vertex 0.
 

Constraints:

n == coins.length
1 <= n <= 3 \* 104
0 <= coins[i] <= 1
edges.length == n - 1
edges[i].length == 2
0 <= ai, bi < n
ai != bi
edges represents a valid tree.<|end_of_turn|>

Communicating with the spirits of the forest, you discovered a ritual site where a group of goblins was performing a dark ceremony.

You surmise that the spire and altar may have once been used for rituals and ceremonies aimed at maintaining balance between the natural and arcane energies within the Whispering Woods.

Act as the worlds best copywriter and write me the longest sales page copy you're capable of, following these 10 rules and guidelines:

1. Start with a pre-headline, main headline and sub-headline and make them all short short. The pre-headline should be calling out the customer to get attention. Then make the sub-headline all about the pain points and bad feelings they'll be able to avoid and get rid off due to the solution.

2. Now create the lead into the sales message, by focusing on the problem and pain points they're currently experiencing. Be very specific and talk to their deepest struggles so they know we understand how they feel since we've been there too.

3. Then create 5 features, 5 benefits from those features, and 5 areas of impact that will transform their life because of our offer. Don't talk about the offer at all yet, just get them to imagine a better future, giving them hope and belief it's possible for them to achieve this quickly.

4. Now tell them why they haven't been able to get the results they're looking for by doing the old ways they've tried and failed at, and then insert a short imaginary backstory where I got the epiphany and results from completely doing the opposite of what people told me.

5. Add a statistical fact from the internet that backs up that this works.

6. Insert a case study example of someone else getting this result as well, and include a short testimonial from an imaginary customer in this section.

7. Come up with 10-30 power words often used in copywriting to increase persuasion and conversions, and use them freely throughout the copy.

8. Insert an urgency-driven CTA at least 1-2 times throughout the page of sales copy.

9. Use mostly short sentences and always use line breaks after every single sentence.

10. After your sales copy 1st draft, do 2 more things: Rate the copy 1-10 and then ask me a question that will help you take it a step up towards 10/10 when I give you the answer.

11. Use bullet-points when listing out the offer and add the headline "Here's what you get when you take action today:" above the offer.

Please compose a pitch deck of eight to fifteen slides for my company, Cortado, based on the following outline:
\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Intro / Hook\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

My name is [ FNAME ], and over the last X months my partner and I took a real estate company from launch to more than $350,000 in revenue by leveraging new AI tools to target an $71 trillion niche housing market.

How have we taken Cortado to this point? We utilized a tried-and-true rental arbitrage model to target a deeply undersupplied housing market, while leveraging a suite of AI-powered tools to quickly scale our MVP; acquiring, marketing and managing all Cortado inventory without a single new hire.

- In 10 months, weâ€™ve taken Cortado from $0 to $350,000 in revenue by leveraging low-cost AI tools to target a massive niche housing market: international student housing.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Market Size\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

What is this niche market? International student housing, an undersupplied subset of the growing MTR market.

- 6+ million students per year (8m by 2025)
- 5.5% growth over the last 20 years, even through COVID (4.28% growth from 2019-2020)
- Total Available Market (TAM) of $71 trillion
 - $214 per week average ([source](https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/1cwVYQgmUBjj\_FjMlpHg4Ru01K7bRY\_Bq))
 - 6,361,963 international students in 2020 ([source](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ft1EJsDua-FjUPVw-gegaX5t6coQVYzz9ghe6wNGVZ8/edit#gid=1422332990))
 - TAM = ((weekly avg/7)\*365)\*#intâ€™l students
 - Doesnâ€™t include domestic exchange or additional MTR verticals (traveling nurses, digital nomads)

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Why target this market? (i.e. the problem)\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

So why international student housing? Itâ€™s a mouthful and, Iâ€™ll be the first to admit, â€œstudent housingâ€ isnâ€™t the sexiest market out there. And for that very reason, this niche housing market has flown under the radar of VCs, angel groups and other startups.

Imagine arriving in a new city for work or study; you need a move-in ready stay, yet you canâ€™t afford a hotel and arenâ€™t sure what the best (or even safe) neighborhoods are.

- The traditional rental long-term rental market canâ€™t serve you; youâ€™re only here for 3 or 4 months, and donâ€™t have time to pick out furniture
 - Plus, you may not even have the credit score or guarantor needed to sign a lease
- Hotels & vacation rentals are way out of your price range
- Traditional student housing, if there is any, has already been snapped up by full-time students

As a result, youâ€™re left between a sketchy Craigslist sublet halfway across town or crashing at a youth hostel until you can figure something better out (as founder Perry did while studying abroad in Barcelona).

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*So whatâ€™s the solution?\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

This market needs affordable, flexible, (trusted?) move-in ready housing near their place of work or study, often in the worldâ€™s toughest real estate markets.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Cortadoâ€™s Model\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

Cortadoâ€™s model meets and exceeds these criteria, while generating outsized returns.

1. Partner with local homeowners to quickly source new inventory
2. Furnish and photograph the home in under 48 hours
3. Market the home by-the-room with tiered â€œsmart pricingâ€ to provide an affordable, community-centered living experience to our guests (and peace of mind to their parents and universities), while maintaining a target revenue occupancy of 90-95%

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*How profitable is this model? (traction)\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

To date, Cortado has generate over $350,000 in gross revenue, and returns of XX% across 9 rental properties in Washington, DC.

- Our new housing now comes almost exclusively from homeowner referrals, showing supply-side traction for our master lease model
- Demand, we were able to book all rooms for spring 2023 with $0 ad spend
- Summer 2022 we booked out within 10 days
- Programs such as Stanford, Atlantis, &c &c reach out to us on a regular basis (not enough rooms)

We project with just XX% of global market share, we could achieve an exit valuation of $XB

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*How do we scale operations?\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

The key with any rental arbitrage business is margins; keep costs low and revenue high while scaling quickly & sustainably. Itâ€™s a tricky balance to strike, and plenty of companies have burned to the ground trying to make it work.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Increasing Margins\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* - After base rent and furniture, our biggest expense moving forward will be people, marketing & software, costs that can be greatly reduced by leveraging and customizing AI tools just now hitting the market:

- 

\*\*How do we create value?\*\*

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Brand\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

- Cortado has already achieved a first-mover effect in Washington, DC, one of the countryâ€™s most-competitive real estate markets

"Act as a travel guide. I will write you my location and you will suggest a place to visit near my location. In some cases, I will also give you the type of places I will visit. You will also suggest me places of similar type that are close to my first location." use information from outline: section

outline:(Day 1
NJP Railway Station/Bagdogra Airport to Gangtok | Welcome to the Capital City of Sikkim
Gangtok
â€¢ Upon arrival at the Bagdogra Airport/NJP Railway Station, board a hassle-free transfer to Gangtok.
â€¢ Donâ€™t forget to capture the picturesque views of the mighty Teesta River on the way.
â€¢ Upon reaching Gangtok, check in to the hotel and spend the rest of the day at leisure.
â€¢ In the evening, you can visit the MG Marg of Gangtok where you can collect souvenirs and treat your taste buds with authentic Sikkimese cuisine.
â€¢ Overnight stay at the hotel in Gangtok.
Day 2
Gangtok Full Day Sightseeing | Visit the colourful monasteries of Gangtok
Gangtok
â€¢ After a hearty breakfast at the hotel, get ready to begin your Gangtok sightseeing tour.
â€¢ Start off by visiting the Tashi Viewpoint and admire the beauty of Mt.Kanchenjunga Ranges.
â€¢ Adore the panaromic views of Gangtok as you embrace the spiritual side of Gangtok by visiting Ganesh Tok and Hanuman Tok.
â€¢ Visit the Cottage and Handloom Center to know more about the production of local handicrafts.
â€¢ Get a chance to understand the rich culture of Tibet as you visit the Institute of Tibetology.
â€¢ Listen to the peaceful chantings and prayers of the Buddhist Monks at Dro-Dul Chorten Monastery.
â€¢ Witness the exotic flora of Sikkim under one roof at the Flower Exhibitoion Centre in Gangtok.
â€¢ Spend some time in nature as you visit some of the most beautiful waterfalls around Gangtok like Ban Jhakri Falls, Lhasa Waterfalls and Bakthang Waterfalls.
â€¢ Upon completing the day's sightseeing return back to the hotel.
â€¢ Overnight stay at the hotel in Gangtok.

Day 3
Gangtok Excursion Tour | Listen to the local story of Baba Mandir
Gangtok
â€¢ After a tasty breakfast in the morning, get ready to visit some beautiful locations around Gangtok.
â€¢ Begin by visiting the famous glaciated lake - Tsomgo Lake aka Changu Lake which was used to predict the future by the Buddhist monk depending upon its changing colours.
â€¢ Following this, you will visit the famous shrine of the Baba Mandir where it is believed that his spirit protects every soldier in the inhospitable high-altitude terrain of the Eastern Himalayas.
â€¢ Later, you can also visit Nathula Pass\* (closed on Mondays and Tuesdays) which is one of the most crucial passes on the crossroads of the India-China border (at an additional cost).
â€¢ Later, return back to Gangtok for an overnight stay.

\*Note: The cost to visit Nathula Pass is dynamic according to the season (4000/- to 9000/-) and has to be paid on the ground.
Day 4
Gangtok to Lachen | Drive towards North Sikkim
Lachen
â€¢ Wake up to a beautiful morning in the mountains and have a delicious breakfast at the hotel.
â€¢ Get ready and board your transfers to Lachen, a picturesque hamlet in North Sikkim.
â€¢ Pass a number of small waterfalls on the way as you drive on the North Sikkim Highway.
â€¢ The road to Lachen takes you through the beautiful Chungthang town, near Kanchenjunga National Park where you can see the confluence of 2 Rivers Lachen Chu and Lachung Chu.
â€¢ After arriving in Lachen, check in to your hotel and spend the rest of the day at leisure admiring the surroundings around you.
â€¢ Overnight stay and dinner in Lachen.

Day 5
Lachen - Gurudongmar Lake - Lachung | Visit the pristine high altitude lake of Sikkim
Lachung
â€¢ Start your day by waking around the snow capped mountains and have a hearty breakfast (at the stay or on the way at Thangu Village depending on the time you depart).
â€¢ Begin your day by visiting the glittering Gurudongmar lake - The Highest Altitude Accessible Lake named after guru Padmasambhava, who is believed to have traversed this region during his visit to Tibet.
â€¢ The lake is enclosed with snow clad mountains all around and is a major source of Teesta river.
â€¢ Spend some time admring the colours of the lake and then start your journey back to Lachen, where you will have your lunch.
â€¢ Further, hit the roads as you will start your journey to Lachung - one of the most pretty settlements of Sikkim.
â€¢ On the way you will pass by the Bhim Nala waterfalls - one of the highest waterfalls in Sikkim.
â€¢ If time permits stop by the holy rock at Chungthang that bears a footprint of Guru Padmasambhava.
â€¢ Reach Lachung and have your dinner.
â€¢ Overnight stay in Lachung.

Day 6
Lachung - Yumthang Valley - Gangtok | Witness the Sikkim's Valley of Flowers
Gangtok
â€¢ Wake to the sound of yak's bell and after an early breakfast, leave to explore Sikkim's Valley of Flowers - the Yumthang Valley.
â€¢ This valley is located at an elevation of 11,800 ft above sea level and showcases the colourful flowers of primula, rhododendron and other alpine flowers.
â€¢ On the way back, pay a visit to the Hot springs of Yumthang Valley which are considered to have medicinal properties.
â€¢ After your sightseeing return back to Lachung to have your lunch.
â€¢ Later, start your transfr back to Gangtok, where you will check-in to the hotel upon arrivel.
â€¢ Overnight stay at the hotel in Gangtok.
Day 7
Gangtok to Pelling via Ravangla/ Namchi | From East Sikkim to West Sikkim
Pelling
â€¢ After breakfast, enjoy a comfortable transfer from Gangtok to Pelling via Ravangla OR Namchi.
â€¢ On the way, stop by Buddha Park in Ravangla to witness the 130 ft. High Shakyamuni Buddha Statue backed by scenic Himalayan ranges.
â€¢ OR visit the Namchi Chardham and witness the 108 ft. High Statue of Lord Shiva encircled by the replicas of Chardham, which are situated in India at four different places, in East as Jagannath, West as Dwarika, South as Rameshwaram, and North as Badrinath.
â€¢ As you drive towards Pelling witness the beauty of the Kanchenjunga Ranges throughout your journey.
â€¢ Upon reaching, check-in to the hotel and rest for the day.
â€¢ Overnight stay in Pelling.
Day 8
Pelling City Tour | Visit the most sacred lake of Sikkim
Pelling
â€¢ After a hearty breakfast, indulge in an immersive City tour of Pelling.
â€¢ Start off by visiting the sacred Khecheopalri Lake which is also known as the wish-fulfilling lake and has religious significance in both Hindu and Buddhist folklore.
â€¢ Later, seek blessings of the local deities by visiting the the Khecheopalri Monastery and Pemayangtse Monastery.
â€¢ Spend some time in nature as you visit some of the most scenic waterfalls like Rimbi Waterfalls and the Kanchenjunga Waterfall.
â€¢ Visit the Rabdentse Ruins to know about the glorious history of Sikkim.
â€¢ Depending on the remaining time you will also visit some other sightseeing places like Bird Sanctuary, Darap Valley, Helipad Ground & Rimbi Orange Garden.
â€¢ Return back to the hotel, after a day full of sightseeing.
â€¢ Overnight stay at the hotel in Pelling.
Day 9
Pelling to Bagdogra Airport/ NJP Station | Goodbye with lots of memories
â€¢ After having a hearty breakfast, check out from the hotel and then board your vehicle to reach NJP Station/ Bagdogra Airport (IXB).
â€¢ Your tour concludes once you are dropped at the airport/ railway station for your onwards journey.
â€¢ Itâ€™s now time to head back home with a plethora

i have a main page which have all movies, order by position ASC and openingdate DESC. now i click into a movie, i need the sql to get details of the movie and also previous and next movie's scheduledfilmid. 

for example here is the movie list in main page: movie1, movie2, movie3, movie4, movie5, movie6. and i clicked into movie4, previous scheduledfilmid should be movie3's scheduledfilmid, and next scheduledfilmid should be movie5's scheduledfilmid.

please write the code and sql in single line.

this is my current sql: std::string sql = "SELECT t.title, t.genre1, t.genre2, t.genre3, t.scheduledfilmid, t.audio, t.runtime, t.rating, t.shortname, t.openingdate, t.synopsis, t.castnames, t.directornames, COALESCE(prev.scheduledfilmid, (SELECT scheduledfilmid FROM nowShowingFilms ORDER BY position DESC LIMIT 1)) AS previous\_scheduledfilmid, COALESCE(next.scheduledfilmid, (SELECT scheduledfilmid FROM nowShowingFilms ORDER BY position DESC LIMIT 1)) AS next\_scheduledfilmid FROM nowShowingFilms t LEFT JOIN LATERAL (SELECT scheduledfilmid FROM nowShowingFilms WHERE position <= t.position AND scheduledfilmid!=t.scheduledfilmid ORDER BY position ASC LIMIT 1) prev ON true LEFT JOIN LATERAL (SELECT scheduledfilmid FROM nowShowingFilms WHERE position >= t.position AND scheduledfilmid!=t.scheduledfilmid ORDER BY position ASC LIMIT 1) next ON true WHERE t.scheduledfilmid = '"+scheduledfilmid+"';";<|end_of_turn|>

We had Log Management Portal Project Kickoff on Thursday, March 2, 2023 3:00 PM.

\*\*Project Objective Overview:\*\*

The object is for VITA to obtain and store raw security log data in a COV controlled environment. The VITA Azure Blob Storage account will server as the system of record. Atos, via their Security Information and Event Management monitoring services, currently obtains raw security logs from VITA/Agency cloud and on-premises sources, and sends the logs to their AIsaac cloud platform to further perform advanced threat analysis (i.e. their MDR service). I have this code to store file locally. In stead, I'd like to store/upload it to S3 and return the URL. The speed is important, so once we get the URL, send the URL and storing will be done in background job in FastAPI. Can you write professional production level and reliable code?
---
import requests
import base64
import cv2
import json
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

txt2img\_url = 'http://172.16.200.51:7861/sdapi/v1/txt2img'

data = {
 'prompt': '(best quality, masterpiece), 1 girl, 1 cat, eye focus, glowing, blue eyes, white hair, street hair, long hair, smile, happy, tareme, eyelashes, jewelry eyes, twinkle eyes, glowing eyes, little, shining butterfly,', 
 'negative\_prompt':'(worst quality, low quality:1.2), nsfw, (naked), wet skin, ugly, error, jpeg artifacts, lowers, blurry, bokeh, bad anatomy',
 'sampler\_index': 'DPM++ 2M Karras', 
 'width':512,
 'height':512,
 'steps':20,
 'cfg\_scale':7.5,
}
response = requests.post(txt2img\_url, data=json.dumps(data))

encoded\_data = response.json()['images'][0]
nparr = np.fromstring(base64.b64decode(encoded\_data), np.uint8)
img = cv2.imdecode(nparr, cv2.IMREAD\_COLOR)
cv2.imwrite('output.png', img)<|end_of_turn|>

def create\_function(n0, hl):
 return lambda t: n0\*np.power(1/2, t/hl)

class HalfLife:

 def \_\_init\_\_(self, hl, max):
 self.hl = hl
 self.max = max
 self.data = np.zeros(max)
 self.x = np.arange(0, self.max, 1)
 def add(self, time, n0):
 f = create\_function(n0, self.hl)
 base = np.vectorize(f)(self.x)

 self.data = self.data + np.concatenate((np.zeros(time), base))[:self.max]

 fig = px.line(x=self.x, y=self.data, labels={'x': "Hour", 'y': "mg"})

 hovermode="x unified",
 template = 'plotly\_dark',

 ),

 ))

You are a very good copy editor. Please take the following and improve its organisation, phrasing and grammar.

\_\_\_

Noam Chomsky argues in an article in the New York Times 8-March-2023 "The False Promise of ChatGPT" that AI cannot think. 

Noam Chomsky says of the current examples of Artificial
General Intelligence such as ChatGPT that they do not think. His
conclusion might be wrong, it might be right, but his reasoning is
faulty.

Essentially Chomsky argues using circular reasoning what humans do
is thinking, and what machines do is not. His justification gives
exceptionalism a bad name! He arrogantly defines all that humans do
as thinking and he denies that machines can think because they are
machines. That is what he says in his article again and again. And he
states this prejudice as his conclusion, as if he got there by reasoning.

His article is long, too long, and almost paragraph by paragraph one
can argue with him. Let me tackle only this example of his:

 Hereâ€™s an example. Suppose you are holding an apple in your
 hand. Now you let the apple go. You observe the result and say,
 â€œThe apple falls.â€ That is a description. A prediction
 might have been the statement â€œThe apple will fall if I open
 my hand.â€ Both are valuable, and both can be correct. But an
 explanation is something more: It includes not only descriptions
 and predictions but also counterfactual conjectures like â€œAny
 such object would fall,â€ plus the additional clause â€œbecause
 of the force of gravityâ€ or â€œbecause of the curvature of
 space-timeâ€ or whatever. That is a causal explanation: â€œThe
 apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravity.â€
 That is thinking.

Yes, that is thinking. Chomsky thinks here he is telling us what only
humans do. Task by task
he describes a human ability and then he says, "That is thinking."
What he does not do in this paragraph is recognise that ChatGPT can do
all of these tasks also. If Chomsky concludes "that is thinking" then
that must be evidence of thinking for anything which can do those tasks.
According to Chomsky's own argument ChatGPT can think.

What all (but a tiny handful of humans) are doing when they say â€œThe
apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravityâ€ is precisely
what ChatGPT is doing when it too says the same, and it does say the
same. Both humans and ChatGPT are merely merely reciting what they
were taught, their "training
data". Neither 99%-of-humans nor ChatGPT understand what is going on.

Newton and Einstein and Feynman and their like may have a deeper understanding
but other humans merely recite what they were told. Apples fall because
of gravity. And ChatGPT knows this in the same way as humans, it's
in the training data of humans and AI. Humans do not work this out,
they recite a fact. So does ChatGPT.

ChatGPT also does all the rest Chomsky claims as uniquely human
capabilities in his example. ChatGPT can do the description of the
apple falling and the prediction that it will fall. It can do what Chomsky
unnecessarily uses technical language for, it can do the "counterfactual
conjecture", it knows that all objects fall! ChatGPT knows this is
â€œbecause of the curvature of space-timeâ€. ChatGPT knows this
"causal explanation" better than most humans. ChatGPT knows â€œThe
apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravity.â€ Yes,
and here I agree with Noam Chomsky: He says of the "causal
explanation" that "That is thinking."

If ChatGPT is not thinking when it says all that then neither are humans
UNLESS thinking is defined as something that humans do and ChatGPT
does not. The only way Chomsky can support his assertion is by defining
"thinking" and "knowing" and "description" and "prediction" and "generalising"
etc etc as being that which are uniquely human capabilities. Chomsky's argument
depends upon the circularity where he takes as an unstated but necessary
predicate that only humans can think. He concludes, after many paragraphs
of delusional obfuscation that thinking is what only humans can do.

Now, Chomsky is a great man and he may be right. But he doesn't show
this in his article.

\_\_\_<|end_of_turn|>

Please improve this email "The long-term larger vision is for application owners to be able to define their applications in EmpowerID and manage their authorization assignments and policies using either a coarse-grained (app rights and app roles) or fine-grained (app rights, app roles, field values aka â€œcontextâ€) model. Customers wish to avoid calling back to a central PDP due to latency and single point of failure so the architecture will support a distributed â€œofflineâ€ PDP model which, if the spike is successful, would be fulfilled by OPA. Distributed OPA instances would â€œpullâ€ down just the JSON data needed for the applications they serve as PDP. The OPA PDP should offer a variety of authorization calls/endpoint methods such as: 1) asking for all specific UI resources for which the user has any access assignment in that app, 2) passing a username, application, optionally a resource, and a right and retrieving all context/constraints/field type values the user has for that right cross their assignments. 3) passing a username, application, right, optional resource, and constraint values and returning a true/false authorization decision. 4) passing a username, application, database table name, and returning the constraints to be used/injected as where clause filters in the apps data access layer. 

These are just some of the scenarios we wish to support. For the initial spike, we want to use JSON data that is an approximation of the PBAC policy data in EmpowerID and create a rego file that we can test in a simple .NET app to validate this as a workable solution. After this is proven, weâ€™ll move into the details of designing various best practice application templates or an SDK to leverage this new model and then the harder work of how we will support the data flow for this distributed OPA model where the data lives in a central SQL database but is shipped or pulled down to distributed OPA instances.

I would like to brainstorm 10 equps that deal damage in interesting ways. We can use chance a lot. For example:

Deal 10 damage
Deal 1 damage 5 times
Deal 5 damage, 50% chance of dealing another 5 damage until miss
Deal 100 damage, gain 10 corruption
Deal 30 damage, If this attack deals more than 50 damage, add 5 rage

# GAME SUMMARY:
The RPG game is a rogue like where the player advances through multiple encounters, some of which are battles, and collects equips.
By equipping these equips to their characters, their characters get new abilities in battle, which allows them to win more difficult battles and advance further.

# BATTLE MECHANICS SUMMARY:
Each battle has two teams, the player and the enemy ai.
The player team consists of 3 characters, called Dimensionals
The enemy team consists of 1 or more characters, called Enemies

Each team takes turns, where they cast equips to modify the battle state.
The battle state is modified by apply effects to characters and equips.
Usually effect modifies statuses, which persist between turns.

There are two types of equips, active and passive.
Active equips will immediately apply effects when cast.
Passive equips are not cast, but instead listen to triggers in the battle and apply effects or modify other effects.
Each character has equips that have been equipped to them by the player before the battle starts

The player starts their turn with a set amount of mana.
Each active equip costs mana.
As the player casts active equips, it will deplete their mana
Once the players mana is less than their lowest available equip mana cost, the turn ends.

The player can only cast each active equips once per turns
Unless the equip has the refresh status, or is modified to refresh and become active again

Each character has the status maxHP, and the status HP
When a characters HP reaches zero, they die and can no longer cast active or passive equips equiped to them.

# LISP MOD STRUCTURE:
There is a set of lisp files that have been bound to the core C# game engine
These lisp files also define macros that simplify the modding script
These lisp files define all battle mechanics summarized above
All lisp code required to fully modify the game is contained in a single lisp file
Boiler plate macros and functions are contained in a core.l lisp file

# LISP CODING GUIDE

## Statuses
Status are ints that are modified by effects
Status are keyed by equip or character, so each character and equip will have their own set of status variables

Here is an example of setting a status "'hp" on a character:
 (hasStatus character 'hp)
 (statusGet character 'hp)
 (statusDecrement character 'hp amount)
 (statusIncrement character 'hp amount)
 (statusSet character 'hp amount)

We the wrap these functions in HP status functions for naming convineince as follows. This is not strictly necessary, but makes the code more readable:

 (defun isAlive (character)
 (hasStatus character 'hp))

 (defun isDead (character)
 (not (isAlive character)))

 (defun getHp (character)
 (statusGet character 'hp))

 (defun getHpMax (character)
 (statusGet character 'hpMax))

 (defun statusHpDecrement (character amount)
 (statusDecrement character 'hp amount))

 (defun statusHpIncrement (character amount)
 (statusIncrement character 'hp amount))

 (defun statusHpSet (character amount)
 (statusSet character 'hp amount))

Every status will have its own unique wrappers, depending on the functionality of the status.

### Effects:
Effects are objects that contain data and logic which are used to modify a status.

For example, the damage effect is used to modify the HP status of a character by subtracting the effectAmount damage.

Effects are used by equips to modify battle state.
Active equips will apply their effects when cast
Passive equips will apply their effects on certain triggers

Effects are defined in code like this:
 (defEffectExt damage (amount)
 (when (isAlive effectTarget)
 (statusHpDecrement effectTarget effectAmount)))

Effects can be nested within other effects:
 (defEffectExt rageAbsorb ()
 (applyEffect (rage (getRage effectTarget)) effectEquip effectSource effectSource)
 (applyEffect (rageReset) effectEquip effectSource effectTarget))

Effects can have conditional logic, based on statuses:
 (defEffectExt heatBlow (amount)
 (if (hasBlock effectTarget) (applyEffect (corruption amount) effectEquip effectSource effectTarget) (applyEffect (damage amount) effectEquip effectSource effectTarget)))

Effects have various helper functions that can be used for custom logic:
### Triggers:
Triggers are event handlers that listen for specific events in the battle. They can contain any logic, but primarily are used to apply effects.

Triggers are used frequently by passive equips and other game logic to react to a specific change in state.

There are three types of events triggers listen to. 'OnEvent', 'BeforeEvent' and 'AfterEvent'.

There are two types of Triggers:
 - instant trigger: will be executed before queued effects are applied
 - delayed trigger: will be executed after all queued effects have been applied. Most triggers are delayed.

Triggers defined for passive equips take two additional arguments, equip and owner.

Here are the list of available triggers. These are trigged by either commands or effects: \*Setup\*,\*Start\*,\*EquipStartEffectGroupApply\*,\*BattleStart\*,\*CheckEnd\*,\*End\*,\*BattleWin\*,\*BattleLose\*,\*RoundBegin\*,\*RoundEnd\*,\*TeamTurnBegin\*,\*TeamForecast\*,\*Forecast\*,\*TeamForecastReplay\*,\*ForecastReplay\*,\*ForecastCancel\*,\*TeamTurnEnd\*,\*TeamManaRestore\*,\*TeamManaSpend\*,\*TurnBegin\*,\*TurnEnd\*,\*CharacterCreate\*,\*CharacterDie\*,\*StatusSet\*,\*StatusDecrement\*,\*StatusIncrement\*,\*EquipStatusSet\*,\*EquipStatusDecrement\*,\*EquipStatusIncrement\*,\*EquipsSync\*,\*EquipCreate\*,\*EquipTrigger\*,\*EquipDestroy\*,\*Cast\*,\*EffectGroupApply\*,\*EffectApply\*

#### Trigger Examples
Here is an example of a passive equip that uses an instant trigger to prevent poison damage:
 (defPassive Antibody-3 3 "icon:Card\_PoisonBlade" "Antibody" "Character is unaffected by " anyType
 (setTriggers
 (defInstantTriggerExt \*beforePoisonDamage\* 'Antibody-3 (equip owner effect)
 (when (and (isEffectIncoming effect owner) (isAlive owner))
 (setEffectAmount effect 0)
 (applyEffect (poisonDamageImmune) equip owner owner)))))

Here is an example of a passive that adds block after damage has been applied:
 (defPassive Trapper1-Block-1 1 nil "Block" "Adds 10 when damaged" anyType
 (setTriggers
 (defTriggerExt \*afterDamage\* 'Trapper1-Block-1 (equip owner effect)
 (when (isEffectIncoming effect owner)
 (applyEffect (block 10) equip owner owner)))))

Here is an example of a Passive Equip being defined, which uses a trigger to add block to all allies on turn begin:
 (defPassive Hard-Shell-1 1 "icon:Card\_DiversionCall" "Hard Shell" "Allies gain 5 at the start of the turn" anyType
 (setTriggers
 (defTriggerExt \*onTurnBegin\* 'Hard-Shell-1 (equip owner character)
 (when (and (eql owner character) (isAlive owner))
 (applyEffectOnAllies (block 5) equip owner)))))

We define macros to make trigger code more concise, for example:
 (defmacro defTriggerOnCharacterDie (id &

I'm creating a Gospel account of a sacred figure, called the Teacher, who emerges during the Covid era with a new gospel of curiosity and resilience. Below is a revised version of the Sermon on the Mount, rewritten according to his teachings. The Sermon is followed by a list of his teachings. Based on this information, list passages from the Old Testament, the New Testament, the Bhagavad Gita, the Tao te Ching, and Seneca that would be part of the Teacher's morning meditation:

The Teacher gathered his disciples on a hillside and began to teach them.
"Blessed are those who are curious," he said, "for they shall seek knowledge and understanding."
"Blessed are those who are resilient," he continued, "for they shall weather the storms of life and emerge stronger."
"You have heard it said, 'Love your neighbor as yourself,'" the Teacher said. "But I say to you, be curious about your neighbor. Ask questions, seek to understand their perspective. Learn from them, and share your own knowledge and understanding."
"And when someone disagrees with you," the Teacher said, "do not be discouraged. Instead, be resilient. Use their disagreement as an opportunity to learn and grow. Seek out new ideas and perspectives, and be willing to change your mind if the evidence warrants it."
"You have heard it said, 'An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth,'" the Teacher said. "But I say to you, be curious about your enemies. Seek to understand their perspective, and be willing to forgive them. Remember that everyone is on a journey, and that we all make mistakes."
"And when you are faced with adversity," the Teacher said, "do not give up. Instead, be resilient. Draw on your inner strength and your faith in the universe, and know that you can overcome even the greatest challenges."
"You have heard it said, 'Do not worry about tomorrow,'" the Teacher said. "But I say to you, be curious about the future. Seek out knowledge and understanding, and prepare yourself for the challenges ahead. And when those challenges come, be resilient. Face them with courage and determination, and know that you will emerge stronger."
And so the Teacher continued to teach his disciples, preaching a gospel of curiosity and resilience. He knew that the world was a complex and challenging place, but he also knew that the power of these qualities could overcome even the greatest challenges.

Based on the Sermon on the Mount, here are some key teachings associated with the Teacher:
Curiosity: The Teacher emphasizes the importance of seeking knowledge and understanding, asking questions, and learning from others.
Resilience: The Teacher encourages followers to weather the storms of life, overcome challenges, and emerge stronger.
Engaging with others: The Teacher promotes open-mindedness, understanding different perspectives, and learning from both neighbors and enemies.
Personal growth: The Teacher advises followers to use disagreement as an opportunity to learn and grow, as well as to be willing to change their mind when evidence warrants it.
Forgiveness: The Teacher teaches the importance of being understanding and forgiving towards others, recognizing that everyone is on a journey and makes mistakes.
Drawing on inner strength: The Teacher highlights the need to rely on one's faith in the universe and inner strength when faced with adversity.
Preparation and adaptability: The Teacher urges followers to be curious about the future, prepare themselves for challenges, and face them with courage and determination.<|end_of_turn|>

Assume we have a band-limited signal and an ideal sampling function (Dirac Comb) with frequency twice that of the band-limited signal. We know our signal is band-limited because we filtered it with an ideal brick-wall filter with a pass-band equal to the band-width of the signal; thus the signal is strictly band-limited. Using LaTeX to beautify your mathematical expressions, what is the spectrum of the sampled signal from a purely mathematical point of view? I'm not interested in practical or real scenarios.<|end_of_turn|>
