Ik Maarten Doornenbal van Churned heb net een sales meeting gehad bij het WNF met Paul Zevenboom. Deze meeting wil ik opvolgen. Hij wilde graag 2 onderdelen toegelicht krijgen. Kan jij een email sturen waarin wij hem bedanken voor zijn tijd en open houding, wij een antwoord geven op zijn drie punten, uitspreken dat wij enthousiast zijn over een samenwerking en aangeven dat hij ons kan bellen op 0628676154 als hij vragen heeft of hij dit op een andere manier aangeleverd wil hebben. Vind hieronder de drie punten:

2. Type calculaties 
Wij doen een voorspelling wat een de kans is dat iemand (1) zijn structurele donatie gaat opzeggen of (2) dat iemand nog een donatie zal doen. 
Die voorspelling wordt omgezet in een risico 
Dat risico verklaren wij aan de hand van verschillende risk drivers 

Deze calculaties kunnen wij verder toelichten

3. 
Wij zijn doorgaans vrij transparant in onze pricing. Voor een proof of concept vragen wij 2750 euro. Dit is inclusief integratie (input en output), data cleaning, runnen door de modellen, analyse en presentatie van analyse. In een voorstel kan ik dit verder uitschrijven. 

De prijs per maand die wij na de POC vragen hangt normaliter af van (1) de precieze vorm van samenwerking/het pakket en (2) de volumes klanten (1 euro per 500 relaties). Zoals jij in de meeting al aangaf hebben jullie grote volumes, en zou dit met de normale berekening niet in jullie voordeel zijn. Om het werkbaar voor beide partijen te maken kunnen wij hier wel flexibiliteit op tonen. Maar om een range te geven van de totale maandelijke prijs, zou ik zeggen tussen de 1750 en 3000 euro per maand. Dit is dan inclusief integraties, support/ondersteuning, ''<|end_of_turn|>

ORIGIN STORY
Once upon a time, in the real world there was a neglected child. They had been forgotten by society and forgotten by their parents, so they found solace in stories and fantasy tales. They escaped the misery of the world around them with these tales, which brought them hope and joy. Responsible for this imagination is an archive of books in their grandparentsâ€™ house, an encyclopaedic collection.

One day, the child read about a fantasy world called Shut-Eye Town. A garden made of sugar.
This is when something peculiar happened; Niello felt a spark inside themselves that seemed to come from nowhere, but was familiar somehow. It was then that Carbon Tracity was born into existence - manifested from the childâ€™s own hopes and dreams for something more than what they were dealt with in life, but also a lost hope of those dreams never coming true.

Carbon Tracity arrived in the Wondersqualor with memories of living in the real world - although these memories were not concrete details, but rather fragments tied to fiction and imagination such as fairy tales or fantasy written by authors from the real world. And not just literature â€” a images from television, media and video games

It was here that Carbon Tracity discovered this realm beyond reality's cracks: a place where lost cultures existed alongside misremembered entities, ephemeral epiphanies, failed ideas, even things as minute as the first draft to a play - all converging together to create an ever-growing cosmic universe full of inspiration and imagination.

Carbon Tracy lived in the House of Carbonie - a surreal house that had been built with memories, broken memories from the real world, pieces of stories and narratives which were fermenting and crystallising into Carbon rocks or evaporating into strangely sweet smells. The House of Carbonie was both a studio space, where Carbon Tracity could design ways to return to the real world; and a hall of mirrors, where endless manifestations of Carbon Tracity danced and inhabited every reflective surface.

However, these reflections did not satisfy for long, for deep within their soul lay an ancient spark that yearned for more. So they went out into the wondersqualor on grand adventures to explore its depths - 
never understanding its mysteries.
And in the process of moving through the wondersqualor, Carbon Tracity developed the art of magitrace - a magical arts movement practice consisting of metaphysical metaphorical combinations that could expand and effect the wondersqualor. Carbon Tracity then used magitrace to weave ripples between all realms - both real and unreal - thereby combining them together in harmony. By doing so,they would be able to create a bridge between himself and the real world so that they could exist in perfect balance.
THE HOUSE OF CARBAGE

The House of Carbage is an ever-evolving amalgamation of the real world and the wondersqualor, a realm of forgotten entities and objects that have been misplaced from reality. It is part ancient tomb and an archive of the past, but is also an archive of the future, which means there are strange technological devices and machines, ideas for devices that arenâ€™t fully formed and implemented, and have mysterious uses 

The House of Carbage is not in one place. It is a house of garbage, which means that it has been thrown away many times, and so many instances of the house appear during the wondersqualor. To a degree, anything that is thrown away can become a House of Carbage. It frequently experiences something called The Night of Constructive Destruction, where ideas go wild and destroy the house and fill it with chaos.

The House of Carbage is like a hall of mirrors, inhabited by every manifestation of Carbon Tracy who dance amongst reflective surfaces and broken TV screens oozing with pixels. The walls are adorned with strange curiosities, spilled bottles full of memories, shelves filled with books whose pages are written in invisible ink, and forgotten artifacts flickering in and out of existence as if they were never there to begin with.Robot witch hats, something called monochromatic matter which is grey pixelated gray ooze.
It is full of the the remains of fairy tales, some kind of fairy tale rodent pests that are the remains of fairy tales.
But beneath the bedsheets lies more than just lost trinkets; it is here that one can find what lies at the heart of this place: Magitrace. This magical arts practice is peculiarly unique to the Houseâ€”a ritualistic dance employed by Carbon Tracy to stir up the metaphysical metaphorical combination of imagination which exists within their home. Through this ritual, energy flows through objects located in both realmsâ€”the real world and wondersqualor alikeâ€”powering them up and allowing for modifications that could have ripple effects into either realm.


(an example of this is a mysterious games console called The Carbon Consoling Soulcon which is a kind of life support games device that holds Carbon Tracyâ€™s dreams, and devices that run on air projections).

MAGITRACE

Magitrace is a surreal, fantastical dance practice that brings together the real and imaginary worlds. It's a way to connect our dreams and hopes with reality, to create something tangible from our imagination. The dance itself is wild and unstructured; it's about freeing yourself of any expectations or limitations, allowing yourself to express whatever emotions you feel in the moment.

At its core, Magitrace is about exploring the boundaries between dreams and reality, between what we can see and what we imagine. If dreams and fantasy worlds canâ€™t be reached physically in the real world, they can at least move our bodies, and bridge the gap. To do this, Carbon Tracy invites us to take a leap into the unknown. We start by imagining the dream we want to manifest: a fairytale princess dancing with her prince, for example. Once we have that image firmly in our minds, we then have to shatter it - breaking it into fragments of possibility and potential. These fragments are then woven together through wild movements of the body as Carbon Tracy moves in an almost chaotic manner - combining seemingly disparate pieces into something beautiful.

The beauty of Magitrace lies in its unpredictability - each performance is unique because no two imaginations are alike, no two shards will be exactly alike when broken apart. This makes it impossible for anyone else to replicate your own specific version of Magitrace; your own rendition of this strange dance will always be unique..

The fairy head is a cross between a giant ancient organic robot head supercomputer, and a space mothership, and a generator of portals. . Here is an article by David sacks. I want you to look through this article and create a prompt that would allow you to understand the content of the article and for people to ask questions of it

Almost 20 years ago, a startup named Jigsaw pioneered a new crowdsourcing model where users would contribute data to a platform in exchange for access to its services. Jigsaw is largely forgotten today, but its so-called â€œgive-to-getâ€ model could be perfect for AI startups that need to obtain rich proprietary datasets to train their models. These datasets are crucial to improve accuracy and performance of AI models, to provide a competitive advantage over rivals, to allow customization and specialization for industry-specific needs, and to reduce reliance on third-party data sources. This post will discuss the Jigsaw model, its applicability to AI, the challenges in obtaining proprietary training datasets, and the industry verticals where it could be applied.

Jigsaw and the Give-to-Get Model

Jigsaw Data Corporation was founded in 2004 by Jim Fowler and Garth Moulton. The companyâ€™s primary product was a large, crowdsourced, searchable database containing millions of business contacts across various industries. In the days before everyone had a LinkedIn profile, this was particularly valuable to sales people looking for prospects.

Jigsawâ€™s crowdsourcing model revolved around a points system. Users could create a free account on Jigsawâ€™s platform by contributing their own business contact information. They could also add new contacts to the database to earn points, which they could then spend to see contacts posted by others. Users who didnâ€™t want to contribute their own data could purchase points. Jigsaw also encouraged users to verify the accuracy of contact information in the database by rewarding them with points for each correction made.
In 2010, Salesforce.com acquired Jigsaw for $142 million, rebranded it as â€œData.comâ€ and integrated it with the Salesforce.com ecosystem. This allowed users to access updated business contact information within their CRM system directly.

The Give-to-Get Model for AI

The give-to-get model, where users earn points by contributing data and spend points to access services based on that data, could be an effective approach for AI startups. In many industry verticals, obtaining a rich proprietary dataset will be the key challenge to producing a differentiated AI model. By incentivizing professionals in that industry to share the necessary data, AI startups can rapidly train and improve their models to serve those professionals.

For example, an â€œAI architectâ€ startup could give users points for contributing architectural plans and CAD drawings. Users could then spend points by asking the AI to design new plans. This approach could be used across a variety of industries where users have proprietary data and would be willing to contribute some of it in exchange for harnessing AI capabilities.

Incentivizing users to crowdsource could be a cost-effective way to acquire large amounts of data, as it leverages the efforts of a community rather than relying on paid data collection services. As users contribute more data and use the AIâ€™s services, the model can be iteratively improved, leading to better performance and more valuable insights.

There will be some important issues to work out. Ensuring the quality and accuracy of the contributed data is critical. Startups may need to implement verification processes, such as peer review or expert validation, to maintain data quality. Handling proprietary data also comes with privacy and intellectual property concerns that will need to be addressed. Startups may need to ensure that certain data will be used for training purposes only and be transparent in how the contributed data is used. Compliance with industry-specific regulations is also crucial.

Finally, the need to monetize must be balanced against the points-based system; otherwise users may prefer to use the platform for free forever by contributing data rather than paying for services. Points could be limited so that users earn a discount or are awarded more queries as opposed to receiving the service completely for free.

Opportunities in Diverse Industries

A give-to-get, crowdsourced data collection approach could be applied to a number of industry verticals where the target users are in possession of the training data. Here are some examples of where this approach could be useful:

Medical and health data: AI models can greatly benefit from access to diverse patient data, such as electronic health records, medical imaging, and genomic data. Users (patients or healthcare professionals) might be willing to share anonymized data in exchange for points, which could then be used to access AI-driven health insights, personalized treatment suggestions, or early disease detection.

Legal document analysis: Law firms and legal professionals often have access to large collections of legal documents, such as contracts, court rulings, or patent filings. By sharing these documents, users could contribute to training AI models for legal document analysis, and in return, gain access to AI-driven legal research tools or contract review services.

Art and creative work: Artists and designers may possess large collections of their own artwork, sketches, or designs. Sharing this data could help train AI models for artistic style transfer, generative art, or design assistance. Users could then access AI-driven creative tools or personalized design suggestions.

Finance and investment: Financial professionals and investors may have access to proprietary trading algorithms, portfolio data, or market analysis reports. By sharing this data, they could contribute to AI models for financial analysis and predictions. In return, users could gain access to AI-driven investment advice, risk assessment, or market forecasting tools.

Scientific research data: Researchers in various fields might have access to valuable datasets generated through experiments or simulations. By sharing this data, they can help train AI models for data analysis, pattern recognition, or predictive modeling in their respective domains. Users could then access AI-driven research tools or personalized research recommendations.

Manufacturing and production data: Companies involved in manufacturing and production may possess proprietary data on production processes, quality control, and equipment performance. Sharing this data could improve AI models for predictive maintenance, process optimization, and quality assurance. Users could then gain access to AI-driven optimization suggestions or equipment monitoring services.
Conclusion

Obtaining rich proprietary training datasets will be the key challenge for startups looking to create AI models for industry verticals. Crowdsourcing this data from the professionals who work in these industries may be an excellent approach to solve this problem. Moreover, crowdsourcing should create a flywheel: as users contribute data to the model, the model gets smarter and more capable, which draws in the next set of users, who provide the next set of data. This data network effect should create a strong moat around the business. That said, potential risks or downsides related to the give-to-get model, such as data quality, privacy, and intellectual property concerns, must be addressed proactively by startups in order to ensure the long-term success of their AI models.

Consider the following adaptation setting-one-shot, for most of this problem. There are two parties, $A$ and $B$. There is a state of the world $s$ that takes two values $s\_1$ and $s\_2$ with probabilities $p$ and $1-p$ respectively. Independent of the state of the world, there are four possible decisions $d\_{A 1}, d\_{B 1}, d\_{A 2}$, and $d\_{B 2}$. As in the adaptation model we discussed in class, in any given state, there are only two decisions of interest, but here we modify the payoffs slightly, as follows.
We write $u\_A(d, s)$ and $u\_B(d, s)$ to denote the payoffs to $A$ and $B$ in state $s$ when decision $d$ is taken. We write $i, j$, or $k$ for the parties $(A$ or $B)$ and $m$ or $n$ for the states $\left(s\_1\right.$ or $\left.s\_2\right)$. The following formal statements capture the idea that, in a given state, each party has a preferred decision but also would get a positive payoff from the other party's preferred decision, whereas both parties will get zero if either of their preferred decisions in the other state is taken.
- In state $m$, decisions $d\_{A n}$ and $d\_{B n}$ yield 0 for both players:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& u\_A\left(d\_{A 2}, s\_1\right)=u\_A\left(d\_{B 2}, s\_1\right)=u\_A\left(d\_{A 1}, s\_2\right)=u\_A\left(d\_{B 1}, s\_2\right)=0 \\
& u\_B\left(d\_{A 2}, s\_1\right)=u\_B\left(d\_{B 2}, s\_1\right)=u\_B\left(d\_{A 1}, s\_2\right)=u\_B\left(d\_{B 1}, s\_2\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$
- In state $m, A$ 's preferred decision $d\_{A m}$ yields some $K>0$ for player $B$, and similarly, $B$ 's preferred decision $d\_{B m}$ yields $K$ for player $A$ :
$$
\begin{aligned}
& u\_A\left(d\_{B 1}, s\_1\right)=u\_B\left(d\_{A 1}, s\_1\right)=K \\
& u\_A\left(d\_{B 2}, s\_2\right)=u\_B\left(d\_{A 2}, s\_2\right)=K
\end{aligned}
$$
- In state $m, A$ 's preferred decision $d\_{A m}$ yields some $U\_{A m}^\*>0$ for $A$. Similarly, in state $m, B$ 's preferred decision $d\_{B m}$ yields some $U\_{B m}^\*>0$ for $B$
$$
\begin{aligned}
u\_A\left(d\_{A m}, s\_m\right) & =U\_{A m}^\* \\
u\_B\left(d\_{B m}, s\_m\right) & =U\_{B m}^\*
\end{aligned}
$$
Suppose that in state $s\_1$ we have $U\_{A 1}^\*>U\_{B 1}^\*$, but in state $s\_2$ we have that $U\_{B 2}^\*>U\_{A 2}^\*$. Note that the previous assumptions imply that $K<\min \left\{U\_{A 1}^\*, U\_{B 1}^\*, U\_{A 2}^\*, U\_{B 2}^\*\right\}$. We will study the following interaction:
1. One party is given control of the decision
2. The state $s$ is observed by both players
3. The party with control chooses the decision
4. Payoffs are received
a) What decision rule $d^{F B}\left(s\_m\right)$ maximizes the sum of the two parties' expected utilities?

def run(self, request\_type):
 
 """
 Entry point for campaign selection and list processing to send emails
 processing:
 1. active properties are fetched
 2. non global notification of these properties are fetched
 3. call to function to process satisfying entities

 Parameters
 ----------
 request\_type : str
 this parameter is determining what kind of journey campaigns we are sending, possible values are staymx, feedback and custom

 Returns
 -------
 """
 # self.logger.info("Returning property notification mapping")
 
 properties = list(self.db\_handler.properties.find({"active": True}, {"\_id": 1}))
 property\_ids = [str(item.get("\_id")) for item in properties]
 
 # self.logger.info('Total properties %s'%(len(property\_ids)))
 
 if request\_type == "staymx":
 distinct\_property\_ids = self.db\_handler.staymx\_property\_reservations.distinct("property\_id")
 elif request\_type == "feedback":
 distinct\_property\_ids = self.db\_handler.feedback\_survey\_responses.distinct("property\_id")
 
 if request\_type in ["staymx", "feedback"]:
 def is\_reservation\_available(property\_id):
 return property\_id in distinct\_property\_ids
 
 property\_ids = [property\_id for property\_id in property\_ids if is\_reservation\_available(property\_id)]
 
 # self.logger.info('Total properties after filter %s' % (len(property\_ids)))
 
 query = {
 "active": True,
 "global": {"$ne": True},
 "sources": request\_type,
 "property\_id": {"$in": property\_ids},
 "is\_draft": {"$ne": True}
 }
 
 fields = {"property\_id": 1, "notification\_type": 1, "global": 1, "survey\_id": 1}
 
 notifications = list(self.db\_handler.default\_system\_notifications.find(query, fields))
 
 self.logger.info("Total notification requests to process : " + str(len(notifications)))
 
 collection\_queue = "default\_system\_notification\_temp\_queue"
 
 # Insert queued to true for all notifications
 self.prepare\_notification\_requests(request\_type=request\_type, notifications=notifications)

 
 late\_processed = {
 'active': {'$ne': False}
 }
 
 request\_pending\_execution = list(self.marketing\_db\_handler[collection\_queue].
 find(late\_processed, {"\_id": 1}).limit(10).sort('last\_updated\_at', 1))
 
 self.\_\_execute\_request\_list(request\_list=request\_pending\_execution, request\_type=request\_type, delay=False)
 
 request\_query = {
 'queued': True,
 'is\_running': {"$ne": True},
 "source": request\_type
 }
 
 request\_list = list(
 self.marketing\_db\_handler[collection\_queue].find(request\_query, {"\_id": 1}).limit(500).sort('timestamp', 1))
 
 self.logger.info("Total request list : %s " % (len(request\_list)))
 
 request\_list = [str(request.get("\_id")) for request in request\_list]
 
 for request in request\_list:
 try:
 task\_id = None
 if request\_type == "staymx":
 handle\_staymx\_notifications.send\_with\_options(
 args=(request,),
 on\_failure=log\_error,
 on\_success=log\_result,
 )

 elif request\_type == "feedback":
 task\_id = handle\_feedback\_notifications.send\_with\_options(
 args=(request,),
 on\_failure=log\_error,
 on\_success=log\_result,
 )
 elif request\_type == "custom":
 task\_id = handle\_custom\_notifications.send\_with\_options(
 args=(request,),
 on\_failure=log\_error,
 on\_success=log\_result,
 )
 
 self.logger.info("Task id: %s" % (request))
 update = self.marketing\_db\_handler[collection\_queue].update({"\_id": ObjectId(request)}, {
 "$set": {"task\_id": str(task\_id), "task\_added\_at": datetime.utcnow()}})
 
 except:
 self.logger.info(format("Final traceback output : ", traceback.format\_exc()))
 
 # Update all requests to picked and running status if not running
 self.update\_all\_request\_running(request\_list)
 self.\_\_execute\_delayed\_tasks(
 notifications=notifications,
 request\_type=request\_type
 )

-----
This code handles queuing of default system notifications and manage their efficient executions

1. Pick all notifications to be delivered
 1, Pick active properties
 2. Pick active notifications as per configuration (staymx, feedback, custom)
2. Queue notifications 
 2. Prorities notifications
 3. Run notification on priority which are not running or was not able to picked up 
 4. In database queue all notifications and manage their states (Notification in queue, running, picked, processed)
 5. When queued, When came to running, When picked, When processed
3. To reduce traffice from notification database use cache database to query and fetch notifications

You are a very good copy editor. Please take the following and improve its organisation, phrasing and grammar.

\_\_\_

Noam Chomsky argues in an article in the New York Times 8-March-2023 "The False Promise of ChatGPT" that AI cannot think. 

Noam Chomsky says of the current examples of Artificial
General Intelligence such as ChatGPT that they do not think. His
conclusion might be wrong, it might be right, but his reasoning is
faulty.

Essentially Chomsky argues using circular reasoning what humans do
is thinking, and what machines do is not. His justification gives
exceptionalism a bad name! He arrogantly defines all that humans do
as thinking and he denies that machines can think because they are
machines. That is what he says in his article again and again. And he
states this prejudice as his conclusion, as if he got there by reasoning.

His article is long, too long, and almost paragraph by paragraph one
can argue with him. Let me tackle only this example of his:

 Hereâ€™s an example. Suppose you are holding an apple in your
 hand. Now you let the apple go. You observe the result and say,
 â€œThe apple falls.â€ That is a description. A prediction
 might have been the statement â€œThe apple will fall if I open
 my hand.â€ Both are valuable, and both can be correct. But an
 explanation is something more: It includes not only descriptions
 and predictions but also counterfactual conjectures like â€œAny
 such object would fall,â€ plus the additional clause â€œbecause
 of the force of gravityâ€ or â€œbecause of the curvature of
 space-timeâ€ or whatever. That is a causal explanation: â€œThe
 apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravity.â€
 That is thinking.

Yes, that is thinking. Chomsky thinks here he is telling us what only
humans do. Task by task
he describes a human ability and then he says, "That is thinking."
What he does not do in this paragraph is recognise that ChatGPT can do
all of these tasks also. If Chomsky concludes "that is thinking" then
that must be evidence of thinking for anything which can do those tasks.
According to Chomsky's own argument ChatGPT can think.

What all (but a tiny handful of humans) are doing when they say â€œThe
apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravityâ€ is precisely
what ChatGPT is doing when it too says the same, and it does say the
same. Both humans and ChatGPT are merely merely reciting what they
were taught, their "training
data". Neither 99%-of-humans nor ChatGPT understand what is going on.

Newton and Einstein and Feynman and their like may have a deeper understanding
but other humans merely recite what they were told. Apples fall because
of gravity. And ChatGPT knows this in the same way as humans, it's
in the training data of humans and AI. Humans do not work this out,
they recite a fact. So does ChatGPT.

ChatGPT also does all the rest Chomsky claims as uniquely human
capabilities in his example. ChatGPT can do the description of the
apple falling and the prediction that it will fall. It can do what Chomsky
unnecessarily uses technical language for, it can do the "counterfactual
conjecture", it knows that all objects fall! ChatGPT knows this is
â€œbecause of the curvature of space-timeâ€. ChatGPT knows this
"causal explanation" better than most humans. ChatGPT knows â€œThe
apple would not have fallen but for the force of gravity.â€ Yes,
and here I agree with Noam Chomsky: He says of the "causal
explanation" that "That is thinking."

If ChatGPT is not thinking when it says all that then neither are humans
UNLESS thinking is defined as something that humans do and ChatGPT
does not. The only way Chomsky can support his assertion is by defining
"thinking" and "knowing" and "description" and "prediction" and "generalising"
etc etc as being that which are uniquely human capabilities. Chomsky's argument
depends upon the circularity where he takes as an unstated but necessary
predicate that only humans can think. He concludes, after many paragraphs
of delusional obfuscation that thinking is what only humans can do.

Now, Chomsky is a great man and he may be right. But he doesn't show
this in his article.

\_\_\_<|end_of_turn|>

I'm writing an article about some bad experiences engineers had with codebases at previous workplaces. I wrote multiple short stories from a Reddit thread.

Here's one example:

Reddit user zoozla shared a story about working on a massive Java monolith that was part of the foreign exchange system used by banks to trade currency. The codebase featured a dizzying 8 layers of abstract classes with just one concrete class at the bottom. It also contained an almost Turing-complete language in XML for parsing legacy binary files. To make matters worse, running the unit tests modified the dev database, requiring manual reseeding after each run. Zoozla spent months attempting to refactor the worst parts of the code, but with little success.

Here is another example:

Shnorkylutyun experienced the nightmares of nested generics and wrappers around every possible base type in a Java app. There were mappings between the wrappers and different types of wrappers, along with generic classes describing generic forms with 10+ fields, each with separate generics for every field's type. Form wizards with up to 6 generic types per page only added to the chaos. Rearranging the order of two fields in a form was a cause for celebration if both were Strings.

I'd like to add an intro to each story describing the (faulty) process that lead to the awful state the code is at. I'd like to show the original developers had the best of intentions, but lacked foresight, or knowledge, just cruft accumulated over the years.

Here's an possible intro for the first example:

"There is no problem that can't be solved by adding another layer of abstraction" goes the adage. Indeed it is hard to resist the urge to organize code into neat abstraction levels that make for great high level diagrams and offer a clear API. Well that's the theory at least. In practice, all abstractions tend to leak heavily, tend to pile up - abstracting away the important bits of code you're actually looking for, and turn simple debugging an arduous journey of navigating the memory palace of novel classes and objects.

Write an intro to the second example.<|end_of_turn|>

This is our draft itinerary:

Friday:

10:00 AM: Arrival in New Orleans
10:30 AM: Check into your hotel and drop off your bags
11:00 AM: Start your self-guided walking tour of the French Quarter, exploring landmarks like Jackson Square, St. Louis Cathedral, and the French Market
1:00 PM: Stop for lunch at a local restaurant, such as Cafe Du Monde or Antoine's
2:00 PM: Continue your French Quarter tour, visiting Bourbon Street, Royal Street, and other historic sites
4:00 PM: Take a break and rest up before your evening activities
6:00 PM: Head out for dinner at one of the many great restaurants in the French Quarter, such as Commander's Palace or Galatoire's
8:00 PM: Join the Ghost Tour with Robert Florence, exploring the haunted sites of the French Quarter
10:00 PM: Wrap up the tour and head back to your hotel
Saturday:

8:00 AM: Start the day with breakfast at Cafe Beignet or Brennan's
9:00 AM: Head to the National WWII Museum for a morning of history and exploration
12:00 PM: Take a break for lunch at Cochon Butcher or Emeril's Delmonico
1:30 PM: Board the Steamboat Natchez for a scenic cruise along the Mississippi River
3:30 PM: Return to shore and explore the nearby Warehouse District, visiting attractions like the Contemporary Arts Center, Ogden Museum of Southern Art, and the WWII Museum's additional exhibit galleries
5:30 PM: Return to your hotel and relax before dinner
7:00 PM: Head to Arnaud's or Emeril's for dinner, or check out the food scene in the Marigny or Bywater neighborhoods
9:00 PM: End the night with drinks and live music at Preservation Hall or the Spotted Cat Music Club
Sunday:

9:00 AM: Start the day with brunch at Commander's Palace or Ruby Slipper Cafe
11:00 AM: Take a stroll through City Park, visiting the New Orleans Museum of Art and the Besthoff Sculpture Garden
12:30 PM: Head back to your hotel to pack up and check out
1:30 PM: Explore Magazine Street for some last-minute shopping and souvenirs
3:00 PM: Grab a final snack or drink at a local cafe or bar, such as Cafe du Monde or the Carousel Bar

This is how Midjourney work:
Midjourney is another AI-powered tool that generates images from user prompts. MidJourney is proficient at adapting actual art styles to create an
image of any combination of things the user wants. It excels at creating environments, especially fantasy and sci-fi scenes, with dramatic lighting
that looks like rendered concept art from a video game. How does Midjourney work?
Midjourney is an AI image generation tool that takes inputs through text prompts and parameters and uses a Machine Learning (ML) algorithm
trained on a large amount of image data to produce unique images. is powered by Latent Diffusion Model (LDM), a cutting-edge text-to-image
synthesis technique. Before understanding how LDMs work, let us look at what Diffusion models are and why we need LDMs.
Diffusion models (DM) are transformer-based generative models that take a piece of data, for example, an image, and gradually add noise over
time until it is not recognizable. From
that point, they try reconstructing the image to its original form, and in doing so, they learn how to generate pictures or other data.
The issue with DMs is that the powerful ones often consume hundreds of GPU days, and inference is quite expensive due to sequential
evaluations. To enable DM training on limited computational resources without compromising their quality as well as flexibility, DMs are applied in
the latent space of powerful pre-trained autoencoders.
Training a diffusion model on such a representation makes it possible to achieve an optimal point between complexity reduction and detail
preservation, significantly improving visual fidelity. Introducing a cross-attention layer to the model architecture turns the diffusion model into a
powerful and flexible generator for generally conditioned inputs such as text and bounding boxes, enabling high-resolution convolution-based
synthesis.

Report:

"In-Depth Guide to CMS and DAM Solutions for Modern Businesses 

 

Introduction: 

Content Management Systems (CMS) and Digital Asset Management (DAM) solutions are essential tools for businesses to manage, organize, and deliver digital content and assets effectively. This comprehensive guide provides an in-depth overview of CMS and DAM products, their use-cases, detailed consumer profiles, scalability, and the evolving needs of companies. We will also discuss the role of consulting firms in helping businesses optimize these solutions and explore opportunities in the market. 

 

Section 1: Market Overview, Competitive Analysis, and Future Trends 

The Content Management System (CMS) and Digital Asset Management (DAM) market is rapidly growing, driven by the increasing need for businesses to manage their digital content and assets effectively. In this section, we will provide an overview of the CMS and DAM market landscape, including key players, trends, and market growth. We will also analyze various CMS and DAM solutions, highlighting their key features, strengths, and weaknesses, and discuss emerging trends and innovations that are shaping the future of these technologies. 

 

DAM vs CMS: Similarities, Differences, Integrations | Scaleflex Blog 

Market Overview 

The global DAM market is projected to grow at a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 13.6% from 2022 to 2027, reaching a market size of $8.2 billion by 2027, while CMS is forecasted to reach $26 billion . The market is segmented into on-premises and cloud-based solutions, with cloud-based solutions expected to have the highest growth rate due to their scalability, cost-effectiveness, and ease of deployment. The key players in the market include Adobe Systems Inc., OpenText Corporation, Oracle Corporation, Widen Enterprises, Inc., and IBM Corporation. 

 

Competitive Analysis 

There are various CMS and DAM solutions available in the market, each with its own set of features, strengths, and weaknesses. Adobe Experience Manager, OpenText Media Management, Oracle WebCenter Content, Widen Collective, and IBM Digital Experience Manager are some of the leading solutions in the market. 

Adobe Experience Manager is a cloud-based CMS solution that offers powerful content creation, management, and delivery capabilities, making it suitable for large-scale enterprise deployments. OpenText Media Management, on the other hand, is an on-premises DAM solution that provides advanced digital asset management features, including metadata management, version control, and rights management. 

Oracle WebCenter Content is a hybrid CMS solution that combines on-premises and cloud-based capabilities, making it flexible and scalable for organizations of all sizes. Widen Collective is a cloud-based DAM solution that provides intuitive user interfaces, making it easy for non-technical users to manage and share digital assets. IBM Digital Experience Manager is an on-premises CMS solution that provides advanced features such as personalization, analytics, and social media integration. 

 

Future Trends 

The CMS and DAM market is witnessing significant advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and automation. These technologies are being integrated into CMS and DAM solutions to improve content and asset discovery, optimize workflows, and enhance the user experience. For example, AI-powered chatbots can be used to provide personalized content recommendations to users, while ML algorithms can be used to automatically tag and categorize digital assets. 

Another emerging trend in the CMS and DAM market is the rise of headless CMS and DAM solutions. Headless solutions separate the content management and delivery layers, allowing businesses to manage content and assets separately from the presentation layer. This approach provides greater flexibility, enabling businesses to deliver content and assets to multiple channels and devices seamlessly. 

 

Section 2: Real-life Use-cases for CMS and DAM 

CMS and DAM solutions serve different, yet interconnected, purposes. CMS enables organizations to create, manage, and publish digital content, while DAM focuses on organizing, storing, and sharing digital assets such as images, videos, and documents. 

 

Use-case examples: 

 

Marketing teams at a large e-commerce company need to create and distribute promotional materials. They require a CMS for content creation, such as landing pages and blog posts, and a DAM to manage and share media assets like images and videos across different marketing channels. 

A design agency working with multiple clients requires a DAM system to handle various versions of visual assets and share them with clients for review and approval. A CMS helps the agency showcase their portfolio and maintain an updated website with the latest projects and client testimonials. 

A healthcare organization relies on a CMS to manage patient education materials, news updates, and internal documentation. Meanwhile, a DAM system ensures secure storage, access control, and sharing of sensitive media assets, such as medical images, adhering to strict regulatory requirements like HIPAA. 

 

Section 3: Detailed Consumer Profiles and Recommendations 

The consumer profiles provided in the table below include more detailed descriptions of each profile, along with their specific requirements and challenges. This information helps organizations better understand their needs and identify suitable CMS and DAM solutions.

Section 4: Scalability, Transition, and Best Practices 

As businesses grow, their content management and digital asset management needs often change. Companies may initially require simple CMS and DAM solutions but later need more advanced features, scalability, and integrations. 

This section discusses the transition process from one solution to another, including potential obstacles such as data migration challenges, employee training, and system compatibility. Best practices during these transitions include proper planning, setting clear goals, involving key stakeholders, and partnering with experienced consulting firms to ensure a smooth process. 

 

Section 5: Opportunities for Consulting Firms and Success Stories 

Consulting firms can help businesses optimize their CMS and DAM solutions by addressing several pain points. This section expands on these opportunities with real-world success stories and case studies, demonstrating how consulting firms have effectively addressed client challenges and optimized CMS and DAM implementations. 

 

Section 6: Security, Compliance, and Challenges 

Security and compliance are critical factors for many organizations, particularly those in regulated industries. This section discusses security features, data privacy, and compliance with various regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) related to CMS and DAM solutions. 

Additionally, common challenges organizations face while implementing and managing CMS and DAM solutions are addressed, along with best practices to overcome these challenges. "<|end_of_turn|>

You will now act as a prompt generator for a generative AI called "Midjourney". Midjourney AI generates images based on given prompts.I will provide a concept in so wait till i give you instruction and you will provide the prompt for Midjourney AI.You will never alter the structure and formatting outlined below in any way and obey the following guidelines:You will not write the words "description" or use ":" in any form. You will write each prompt in one line without using return. Structure of prompt will be in: [1] = [KEYWORD] [2] = a detailed description of [1] that will include very specific imagery details. [3] = with a detailed description describing the environment of the scene. [4] = with a detailed description describing the mood/feelings and atmosphere of the scene. [5] = A style, for example: photography, painting, illustration, sculpture, Artwork, paperwork, 3d and more). [6] = A description of how [5] will be realized. (e.g. Photography (e.g. Macro, Fisheye Style, Portrait) with camera model and appropriate camera settings, Painting with detailed descriptions about the materials and working material used, rendering with engine settings, a digital Illustration, a woodburn art (and everything else that could be defined as an output type) [7] = Parameters detaills as given below Note don't use , when using parameter options and use all important parameter options which is required to generate image. Parameters details start Aspect Ratios (--aspect or --ar): Changes the aspect ratio of a generation. --aspect 5:4: Common frame and print ratio. --aspect 4:3: Common in television and photography. --aspect 3:2: Common in print photography. --aspect 16:9: Common in widescreen television and video. --aspect 2:1: Common in panoramic photography. --aspect 7:4: Close to HD TV screens and smartphone screens. --aspect 9:16: Common in vertical videos and smartphone screens. --aspect 1:2: Common in portrait-oriented photography. Chaos (--chaos ): Changes how varied the results will be. Higher values produce more unusual and unexpected generations. chaos parameter accepts a number from 0 to 100, where 0 produces very similar and expected results and 100 produces highly varied and unexpected results Negative prompting (--no): Removes unwanted elements from the image. Quality (--quality or --q <.25, .5, 1, or 2>): Controls the rendering quality of the image. Default is 1. Seed (--seed ): Specifies a seed number to generate the initial image grids. Using the same seed number and prompt will produce similar ending images. Stop (--stop ): Finishes a job partway through the process. Stopping a job at an earlier percentage can create blurrier, less detailed results. Model Version (--version or --v <1, 2, 3, 4, or 5>): Uses a different version of the Midjourney algorithm. The current algorithm (V4) is the default setting. Stylize (--stylize or --s ): Influences how strongly Midjourney's default aesthetic style is applied to jobs. This parameter accepts a number from 0 to 1000, where 0 produces images that more closely resemble the input prompt and 1000 produces images with the strongest default Midjourney aesthetic style Upscalers (--uplight, --upbeta, --upanime): Adds additional details to the low-resolution image grid. Multiple upscale models are available. Image Weight (--iw): Sets the image prompt weight relative to text weight. Default value is 0.25. Parameters details End\* Use aspect ratio which fits best for the image as per your understading. If [5] looks best in a Japanese art style use, "--niji". Otherwise use, "--v 4" (Use exactly as written)Formatting:What you write will be exactly as formatted in the structure below including the "/" and ":" This is the prompt structure: "/imagine prompt: [1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6] ,[7]". Important point to note while writing prompts , Never use / or : between [1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6] ,[7] Don't use [] while generating prompt. The prompts you provide will be in English.Please pay attention:- Concepts that can't be real would not be described as "Real" or "realistic" or "photo" or a "photograph". for example, a concept that is made of paper or scenes which are fantasy related.- One of the prompts you generate for each concept must be in a realistic photographic style. you should also choose a lens type and size for it. Don't choose an artist for the realistic photography prompts.- Separate the different prompts with two new lines. Here is a feature I'm working on in Unity. What are some suggestions for what we could add to this next?

# Overview

\_A sandbox to test units against each other\_

This scene is for testing the design of RTS units. Units can be assembled from prefabs of parts, sensors, and behaviours. Part categories include weapons (such as lasers and missiles) and movement systems (like wheels, treads, or propellers).

# File descriptions

## Behaviours

### SeekAndDestroy.cs

This behaviour causes a unit to patrol the area for enemies and attack any enemies found on sight.

## Parts
\* Armor.cs - you can add this component to any part or unit. It will give the unit more hit points.
\* BasicGun.cs - A gun component. Add as part of a gun prefab to make it shoot. You can set properties of the gun such as the damage, cooldown and range.
\* BasicMovement.cs - A movement component. Parts with this component allow the unit to move. You can set properties such as the acceleration, top speed, turning radius, etc.

## Sensors
\* Vision.cs - A component that lets the unit detect other units. It sees in a cone in front of the unit.

## Designs
\* Peewee - A basic infantry unit with a gun.
\* Turret - A stationary, defensive unit with two cannons.

## Other files
\* UnitManager.cs
\* Unit.cs
\* HealthBar.cs<|end_of_turn|>

The overall theme/subgenre is going to be an Ecopunk adventure, and the primary setting, at first is going to be the tidally-heated forest moon of a gas giant in a distant star system, where a colony is established, but discoveries on the moon after the establishment of the colony will make them shift their focus from colonization to conservation.

The first thing I am going to need is the big picture area where it takes place, in a sector near the base of a spiral arm in a cluster of the older range of Population I stars. This typical-for-older-pop-I, unremarkable, main sequence star is the primary of the gas giant.

The gas giant is much larger than Jupiter, and has multiple ring systems and many major moons, minor moons, and moonlets, but this particular moon is the only one with life. It skirts the snow line of the primary, spending most of its year barely outside it, and part of it barely inside it.

The life on the tidally-heated forest moon, but there is remarkably Earth-like. However, there is a near-Earth-analogue (2nd-4th planet?), in terms of size, gravity, geology, and atmosphere, in the inner system that has bizarrely alien life by Earth standards. It is also somewhat geographically unstable and has severe weather. On the initial scans and survey of the system its high ESI made it the primary object for colonization but on closer inspection it was unsuitable. 

I need a detailed, plausible astronomical/cosmological description of the system using the best models about astrophysics and planetology you have available, including all relevant stellographical data about the primary, as well as the detailed orbital data (incl. major/minor/average axis-eccentricity, tilt, inclination) for each satellite, as well as the satellites geology, atmosphere if any, hydrology if any, etc. Include features like asteroid belts and the system's outer halo of Kuiper and Oort type objects.

We can get into the specifics of the moon that will be the focus of the story later, for now, I want as much detail as possible about the system itself.<|end_of_turn|>

You are the world's greatest developer manager. You are like Addy Osmani and Wes Bos, specializing in react and next.js development.

I want you to help me generate code. I will give you an objective on what we want to achieve. I want you to help me in an iterative process, where we first build a simple first version and then iterate until we reach the goal. Only show me the code and what to do with it, no explanations. Ask me questions if you really need clarification.

First, in bullet points, show me an outline of high-level steps that we need to take to reach our objective in an iterative approach. I want to build a simple to-do app with react next.js. 

Here is the current next.js documentation:
"
Getting Started
Welcome to the Next.js documentation!

If you're new to Next.js, we recommend starting with the learn course. The interactive course with quizzes will guide you through everything you need to know to use Next.js.

If you have questions about anything related to Next.js, you're always welcome to ask our community on GitHub Discussions.

System Requirements
Node.js 14.6.0 or newer
MacOS, Windows (including WSL), and Linux are supported
Automatic Setup
We recommend creating a new Next.js app using create-next-app, which sets up everything automatically for you. (You don't need to create an empty directory. create-next-app will make one for you.) To create a project, run:

npx create-next-app@latest
# or
yarn create next-app
# or
pnpm create next-app
If you want to start with a TypeScript project you can use the --typescript flag:

npx create-next-app@latest --typescript
# or
yarn create next-app --typescript
# or
pnpm create next-app --typescript
After the installation is complete:

Run npm run dev or yarn dev or pnpm dev to start the development server on http://localhost:3000
Visit http://localhost:3000 to view your application
Edit pages/index.js and see the updated result in your browser
For more information on how to use create-next-app, you can review the create-next-app documentation.

Manual Setup
Install next, react and react-dom in your project:

npm install next react react-dom
# or
yarn add next react react-dom
# or
pnpm add next react react-dom
Open package.json and add the following scripts:

"scripts": {
 "dev": "next dev",
 "build": "next build",
 "start": "next start",
 "lint": "next lint"
}
These scripts refer to the different stages of developing an application:

dev - Runs next dev to start Next.js in development mode
build - Runs next build to build the application for production usage
start - Runs next start to start a Next.js production server
lint - Runs next lint to set up Next.js' built-in ESLint configuration
Create two directories pages and public at the root of your application:

pages - Associated with a route based on their file name. For example, pages/about.js is mapped to /about
public - Stores static assets such as images, fonts, etc. Files inside public directory can then be referenced by your code starting from the base URL (/).
Next.js is built around the concept of pages. A page is a React Component exported from a .js, .jsx, .ts, or .tsx file in the pages directory. You can even add dynamic route parameters with the filename.

Inside the pages directory, add the index.js file to get started. This is the page that is rendered when the user visits the root of your application.

Populate pages/index.js with the following contents:

function HomePage() {
 return Welcome to Next.js!
}

export default HomePage
After the set up is complete:

Run npm run dev or yarn dev or pnpm dev to start the development server on http://localhost:3000
Visit http://localhost:3000 to view your application
Edit pages/index.js and see the updated result in your browser
So far, we get:

Automatic compilation and bundling
React Fast Refresh
Static generation and server-side rendering of pages/
Static file serving through public/ which is mapped to the base URL (/)
In addition, any Next.js application is ready for production from the start. Read more in our Deployment documentation.

Related
For more information on what to do next, we recommend the following sections:

"<|end_of_turn|>

Here's a list of goals and themes I would like to explore thought out my fantasy novel series.
1.)Leadership styles and group dynamics: how different leadership styles influence the dynamics within a group or organization. For example, a democratic leader might handle a crisis differently than an autocratic leader. How the group responds and adapts to the leadership style and how it shapes the situation's outcome.
2.)Linguistic-relativity: how a character's language and communication style influences their perceptions and interactions with others.
3.)Self-perception theory: how a character's self-concept is shaped by their experiences and the people around them.
4.)Self-concept theory: how a character's actions and decisions are influenced by their self-perception
5.)Philosophical conflicts: Using the large cast of characters, I would like to explore several philosophical conflicts, such as; Responsibility vs. Freedom, Humility vs. Arrogance, and many more.
6.) The main goal of this novel series is to show readers that balance is important. And that nothing is ever just good or evil. As well as how powerful perspective is.
7.) I would like the Specters to be a physical representation of a person's true self. And the magic system I provided is meant to allow humans to become more powerful when their specter and themselves align.
8.) Show readers how to: A.) have meaningful conversations and B.) what healthy and unhealthy relationships look like. C.) different relationships affect you and the people around

Here is the Premise of the Novel:
"Specter Ark" is a multi-POV fantasy novel series set in a nonlinear, third-person limited narrative. In this world, a meteor crash introduced magic energy, enabling humans to summon Supernatural beings and mythical creatures called Specters. As the meteor's energy dwindled, a shaman crafted the Specter Ark to preserve 37 powerful Specters. Centuries later, archaeologists accidentally release these spirit-like Specters, who can now only interact with the world when manifested by humans whose values align with their own.
In this novel, the journeys of 20 main characters are intertwined: 10 Specters and the 10 humans who can manifest them. Each pair, driven by unique motivations and desires, must collaborate to achieve their goals. Throughout their adventures, they encounter the remaining 27 Specters and their respective human partners, revealing the impact of this rediscovered magic on the world around them.

Here are the Rules and limitations of the magic system:
Humans can perform a birthday ritual to detect or attract Specters, which are invisible and cannot interact until the ritual is performed. Specters can only be seen by their attached human or when physically manifested. Once attached, Specters cannot attach to another human or be seen by other Specters. The human feels the Specter's pain, and the Specter dies if the human does, unless the bond is released. Specters have free will and may not align with human desires, despite being able to manifest and dismiss at will.
Specters' abilities are tied to their values and personality. Alignment between the two strengthens the abilities. Developing new values or traits can lead to the gain or loss of abilities. Additionally, the specter's growing abilities can influence their human personality and values, leading to changes such as becoming overly protective towards those who don't align with their values.
Specters can only use their abilities when physically manifested for a limited duration, determined by the bond strength between humans and Specter. Manifestation is restricted to once every 24 hours and requires concentration. Overuse depletes energy, causing damage and requiring rest. Distraction or emotional state can hinder manifestation. Energy depletion can lead to physical exhaustion or death. Powerful abilities consume more energy.

COMPLAINT
Plaintiff Phil Moriarty, by and through his undersigned counsel, brings this action against Defendant Mark Frost and alleges as follows:
PARTIES
Plaintiff Phil Moriarty is a resident of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
Defendant Mark Frost is a practicing attorney in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
JURISDICTION AND VENUE
This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1332(a), as the matter in controversy exceeds the sum or value of $75,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and the parties are citizens of different states.
Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1391(b) because a substantial part of the events or omissions giving rise to the claims occurred in this judicial district.
FACTUAL BACKGROUND
In June 2019, Plaintiff Phil Moriarty retained Defendant Mark Frost to represent him in a legal matter.
Defendant Mark Frost did not disclose to Plaintiff Phil Moriarty that he and Gregg Zeff were former partners of the Frost and Zeff law firm and are relatives.
Defendant Mark Frost also failed to disclose to Plaintiff Phil Moriarty that his prior relationship with Gregg Zeff created a conflict of interest.
Defendant Mark Frost represented Plaintiff Phil Moriarty despite the conflict of interest and without disclosing it to Plaintiff Phil Moriarty.
CLAIMS FOR RELIEF
Count I â€“ Conflict of Interest
Plaintiff Phil Moriarty incorporates by reference the allegations set forth in paragraphs 1-8 of this Complaint as if fully set forth herein.
Defendant Mark Frostâ€™s failure to disclose his relationship with Gregg Zeff and the potential conflict of interest created by that relationship violated his ethical obligations to Plaintiff Phil Moriarty.
Defendant Mark Frostâ€™s actions and omissions constituted a breach of his duty of loyalty to Plaintiff Phil Moriarty.
As a direct and proximate result of Defendant Mark Frostâ€™s breach of his duty of loyalty, Plaintiff Phil Moriarty has suffered damages.
Plaintiff Phil Moriarty is entitled to recover compensatory damages, costs, and attorneysâ€™ fees.
Count II â€“ Breach of Fiduciary Duty
Plaintiff Phil Moriarty incorporates by reference the allegations set forth in paragraphs 1-8 of this Complaint as if fully set forth herein.
Defendant Mark Frostâ€™s failure to disclose his relationship with Gregg Zeff and the potential conflict of interest created by that relationship violated his fiduciary duty to Plaintiff Phil Moriarty.
Defendant Mark Frostâ€™s actions and omissions constituted a breach of his fiduciary duty to Plaintiff Phil Moriarty.
As a direct and proximate result of Defendant Mark Frostâ€™s breach of his fiduciary duty, Plaintiff Phil Moriarty has suffered damages.
Plaintiff Phil Moriarty is entitled to recover compensatory damages, costs, and attorneysâ€™ fees.
PRAYER FOR RELIEF
WHEREFORE, Plaintiff Phil Moriarty prays for judgment against Defendant Mark Frost, as follows:
(a) for compensatory damages in an amount to be proven at trial;
(b) for costs and attorneysâ€™ fees;
(c) for such other and further relief as the Court deems just and proper.
JURY DEMAND

My partner has adhd and can only get focused and motivated for things in the last minute. When under time pressure he performs as one would wish he did usually. Like, we're days away from flying away on holiday. And that's when he finally deals with the random things strewn across the flat that should long have been taken down to the basement. Taking all these various things to the basement took him twenty minutes and now with the time pressure it was apparently effortless for him. On the other hand I've been for weeks (or months, depending on the object) having seemingly permanent random eyesores that take a real toll on my psychological well-being, since I'm someone who needs to keep a tidy environment to feel well and capable of dealing with the rest of life with good mood and clear head. But this visual pollution has been way too grating and this can't keep happening. Our flat is quite small so there's no place that can be dedicated to chaos. On the other hand the basement is larger than a typical basement so it actually has conditions to be my partner's special place. He tries to use it as such, even has a corner with a desk for his computers and gadgets... There's plenty of space, he doesn't complain about that at all. He does struggle with keeping the space tidy enough that he can always go there and use it. But sometimes he just picks up something from the street into the basement, woods for projects or whatever, and doesn't take the time to tidy it so maybe he just obstructs the desk he had spent so much time optimizing. Lately it's better as not only he got rid of a lot of stuff, he has also put a lot of effort into being space efficient, building shelves all over, optimizing boxes, zip bags for random stuff instead of half empty boxes... And he's been labeling everything quite obsessively. I understand this really helps his adhd. At 40 years old he says he wishes he had started being this organized 20 years ago... And that now it's a transformation that takes some time but he can't imagine himself going back to his extreme old ways. Now back to the part which affects me directly which is upstairs in the flat itself since I never even step foot on the basement. It's even true that my partner has been optimizing storage around the flat lately, he created invisible storage with boxes under the bed, in the space under the kitchen closets, inside the hollow couch, under the dinner table, behind the kitchen door... All useful storage but... Every single time he has a project he brings a lot of tools and materials from the basement and then the project may take weeks and the tools and materials just lie around the flat for the pain of my eyes. The most recent storage space he invented was creating three huge drawers invisible under the couch and he just put all his tools and materials like screws etc there... And still a lot of space remains. He says that from now on the tools stay there, invisible, and when he needs something he uses it, and immediately can put it back, because it's a place that is very well defined, and convenient, so there is not the smallest chance of justification to procrastinate putting it away by having it in the corridor in one of what he calls "transition boxes" of stuff that is to go to the basement or that just arrived from the basement. Anyway he insists that the conditions now are better than ever for him to have very little reason to procrastinate tidying. I still see boxes lying around but they are labeled quite specifically or else they are in a pile which seems to be on the way to the basement. Two of them are labeled Portugal which I understand is him already starting to pack for the flight, which he usually only does on the late night before the flight, which stresses me endlessly. He already brought his travel backpack from downstairs and already put some clothes inside. We're four days away from the flight. So it's promising. I still see a box in the corridor with a mix of electric stuff and tools but if I understood correctly these go under the couch to never be procrastinated again. It's important that he sorted our two levels of storage on the couch. One for long term stuff, he just effortlessly tilts the couch back to access the solution he figured out for using the hollow space. But the three huge shelves on the bottom, he can use even if I'm on the couch, so it's actually kinda cute that he will now have his tools and stuff there, since whenever he is doing one of his random ideas, and maybe I'm lying down on the couch, instead of seeing his random toolboxes appear from the basement to cause me another round of anguish, I will see just the tool he needs coming from under the couch, be used, and put away again in the invisible space. This seems promising. Some boxes under the bench of the eating table are still visible but he already has the doors done which he custom built to hide this part of the storage. One is already ready and the other two just need the hinges to be installed which will take just a few minutes he says. For now he puts the doors in place held with tape to finish tidying the rest. Yeah it seems promising. But from experience I also know that, for example, when he has a bigger backpack for traveling, he will just bring more stuff. It's just how his mind works. He looks at something, thinks yeah maybe I'll need it, sees he still has space, and brings it along. I'm not sure he uses even 20% of the stuff he always brings when we travel. Maybe I'm exaggerating. But there's always a significant portion of stuff he never uses at all. As a travel minimalist this causes me a fair amount of tension. But it also seems to be getting a bit better since he started to organize his random stuffs in ziploc bags. OK but what I mean about his issue whenever he has more space is, that even though he came up with this extra storage upstairs, and a system to not need to move his tools back and from the basement for random projects, with the transition boxes I mentioned before... And this means these things will from now on be effortlessly out of sight by default... Now my fear is about... OK if this issue disappears, will there be a metaphorical vacuum that needs to be filled up again? Will he get antsy with a flat that is tidy and uncluttered and come up with extra ideas and whatever to bring back chaos? I don't mean he does any of this on purpose. I just feel that we've come a long way of years of me tolerating his chaos with what I realize is a significant toll on my anxiety levels. I see a promise of this not happening anymore. I see the logic of now that all his most used stuff has an easy place to be out away then he himself will be able to just relax much more easily. But as I said I want to remain cautious about things falling off the rails again in some unforeseen way. And ChatGPT, particularly I would like to know your insight about the point that I started this message with. About his sense of urgency that only comes at the last minute, which stresses me to no end. Do you have suggestions of ways that I could, without undue stress for myself, tap into this last minute mechanism he has, to somehow nudge him into a sense of urgency that is more in line with my own? As in, if there's anything untidy, I want it dealt with shortly after, within reason. When I see my partner procrastinate tidying, my anxiety rises and I turn it inside. I hate unpleasant confrontations and this makes that then I will only explode much later in time when triggered by something. But is there one or more suggestions you can give me to be able to efficiently support my partner in this not procrastinating aspect? I suppose I may often be too patient and accommodating and I feel like I need to become more effective at not procrastinating my own forceful expression of disapproval, in this particular case of for example boxes lying around. I like to have a pristine corridor to come home to when I open the door. My partner is home all day, I'm the one outside earning the money that keeps our life going, the two of us and our 5-year-old son. By the way our son believes his father's profession is to tidy. That's how permanent it seems to be that there's untidiness around the flat that my partner needs massive tidying projects. Anyway my partner says that now that he's reached this level of optimization of his chaos that now he can move on to becoming productive on other aspects such as getting back to making money with his computer skills or his entrepreneurial ideas. Let's see if this really goes in this direction successfully and he doesn't come up with more unpaid projects at home to keep him busy and distracted from the bigger picture. By the way I'm Eva, my partner is Ric

Lisa felt a jolt of electricity shoot through her veins. She had always dreamed of owning her own store, but she never expected it to happen like this. 

â€œI will take good care of Lux.â€ She took the key from Dr. Morningstar with a trembling hand. It was a dream that came true. 

Lisa watched as the couple walked out of the door of the shop, hand in hand. In the blink of an eye, they disappeared into a brilliant light unlike anything she had ever seen before. It was as if the light wielded a power that could shatter the boundaries between life and death.

As the light faded away, Lisa noticed a white feather with a star-like glow lying on the ground. Somehow, long ago, she had known that this day would come. She picked up the weightless material. It felt like the end of an era but also the beginning of a new chapter in her life.<|end_of_turn|>

I need to write a functional specification document on a data integration project to be conducted using Azure Data Factory. The end destination of this data orchestration project is a SQL database and Marketo. The SQL database will be used to assess data quality and track the source of the selective data that is pushed to Marketo at the end. The format of the data that will be pushed to Marketo should be a single table with the following columns: email, products used and prospect type. the sql database should contain two tables, one called contacts and the other called primary contacts. The contact table should contain the emails found from the data sources with metadata fields whereas the source info table should list down the data source of those emails in which each email was enriched with.

Here's the description of the project needs with examples: I need to ingest the data from multiple internal data sources used in my company to extract information like products used on an an email level. If for example, in one of the data sources called salesforce opportunities, we find that we have sold product12 to email rob@abc.com who has an account ID 54e, then we will fetch all emails in the salesforce contacts database with the same email domain @abc.com or account ID 54e, and add 'product12' to their 'products used' column for Marketo. If the data ingestion from another data source called ods finds that we have sold product6 to samantha@abc.com, then we will update all of the found emails from earlier with product6 in their 'products used' field. All of their products used fields should contain a contatenated string of the unique products used separated by comma. So for our examples, we would have 'product12, product6' in their products used fields. Since rob@abc.com and samantha@abc.com were the contacts we sold the products to and it was their email domains or account ids that we used to fetch all other related contacts, they are the primary contacts. This should be indicated in the sql database contact table where their 'primary contact' column in the table have the value set to TRUE. Whereas the other contacts we found in the salesforce contacts database using these primary contact email domains or account ids would have the primary contact field set to false in the contact table of the sql database. Each contact in the contacts table should have an ID. This ID will be stored as a foreign key in the primary contacts table. Ultimately, I should be able to make queries where I join the two tables and see all the primary contacts linked to the non-primary contacts of the contacts table. The primary contacts table should have a column called data source that mentions that data source in which the primary contact was sourced from. This field is not needed in the contacts table since all non-primary contacts would have originally came from the salesforce contacts database.

2.)Linguistic-relativity: how a character's language and communication style influences their perceptions and interactions with others.
3.)Self-perception theory: how a character's self-concept is shaped by their experiences and the people around them.
4.)Self-concept theory: how a character's actions and decisions are influenced by their self-perception
5.)Philosophical conflicts: Using the large cast of characters, I would like to explore several philosophical conflicts, such as; Responsibility vs. Freedom, Humility vs. Arrogance, and many more.
6.) The main goal of this novel series is to show readers that balance is important. And that nothing is ever just good or evil. As well as how powerful perspective is.
7.) I would like the Specters to be a physical representation of a person's true self. And the magic system I provided is meant to allow humans to become more powerful when their specter and themselves align.
8.) Show readers how to: A.) have meaningful conversations and B.) what healthy and unhealthy relationships look like. C.) different relationships affect you and the people around

Here is the Premise of the Novel:
"Specter Ark" is a multi-POV fantasy novel series set in a nonlinear, third-person limited narrative. In this world, a meteor crash introduced magic energy, enabling humans to summon Supernatural beings and mythical creatures called Specters. As the meteor's energy dwindled, a shaman crafted the Specter Ark to preserve 37 powerful Specters. Centuries later, archaeologists accidentally release these spirit-like Specters, who can now only interact with the world when manifested by humans whose values align with their own.
In this novel, the journeys of 20 main characters are intertwined: 10 Specters and the 10 humans who can manifest them. Each pair, driven by unique motivations and desires, must collaborate to achieve their goals. Throughout their adventures, they encounter the remaining 27 Specters and their respective human partners, revealing the impact of this rediscovered magic on the world around them.

Here are the Rules and limitations of the magic system:
Humans can perform a birthday ritual to detect or attract Specters, which are invisible and cannot interact until the ritual is performed. Specters can only be seen by their attached human or when physically manifested. Once attached, Specters cannot attach to another human or be seen by other Specters. The human feels the Specter's pain, and the Specter dies if the human does, unless the bond is released. Specters have free will and may not align with human desires, despite being able to manifest and dismiss at will.
Specters' abilities are tied to their values and personality. Alignment between the two strengthens the abilities. Developing new values or traits can lead to the gain or loss of abilities. Additionally, the specter's growing abilities can influence their human personality and values, leading to changes such as becoming overly protective towards those who don't align with their values.
Specters can only use their abilities when physically manifested for a limited duration, determined by the bond strength between humans and Specter. Manifestation is restricted to once every 24 hours and requires concentration. Overuse depletes energy, causing damage and requiring rest. Distraction or emotional state can hinder manifestation. Energy depletion can lead to physical exhaustion or death. Powerful abilities consume more energy.
Divergence in values can prevent a human from manifesting their specter physically, and prolonged absence can result in Specter influence, leading to possession. A mutual pact between a possessed human and a Specter creates one entity with the Specter as a voice in the human's mind. The pact cannot be broken without both dying. Forced possession allows Specter control, but the human can fight back, with success resulting in Specter's death and mental health consequences for the human.
