In-Depth Guide to CMS and DAM Solutions for Modern Businesses: A Comprehensive Analysis

Introduction:

Content Management Systems (CMS) and Digital Asset Management (DAM) solutions are essential tools for businesses to manage, organize, and deliver digital content and assets effectively. This comprehensive guide provides an in-depth overview of CMS and DAM products, their use-cases, detailed consumer profiles, scalability, and the evolving needs of companies. We will also discuss the role of consulting firms in helping businesses optimize these solutions and explore opportunities in the market. Additionally, we will address security, compliance, and challenges associated with CMS and DAM solutions.

Section 1: Market Overview, Competitive Analysis, and Future Trends

1.1 Market Overview

The global DAM market is projected to grow at a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 13.6% from 2022 to 2027, reaching a market size of $8.2 billion by 2027, while the CMS market is forecasted to reach $26 billion (Gartner, 2021). The market is segmented into on-premises and cloud-based solutions, with cloud-based solutions expected to have the highest growth rate due to their scalability, cost-effectiveness, and ease of deployment. The key players in the market include Adobe Systems Inc., OpenText Corporation, Oracle Corporation, Widen Enterprises, Inc., and IBM Corporation (Forrester, 2021).

1.2 Competitive Analysis

Several CMS and DAM solutions are available in the market, each with its own set of features, strengths, and weaknesses. Some leading solutions include Adobe Experience Manager, OpenText Media Management, Oracle WebCenter Content, Widen Collective, and IBM Digital Experience Manager.

Adobe Experience Manager (AEM) is a cloud-based CMS solution offering powerful content creation, management, and delivery capabilities, making it suitable for large-scale enterprise deployments. OpenText Media Management (OTMM) is an on-premises DAM solution providing advanced digital asset management features, including metadata management, version control, and rights management.

Oracle WebCenter Content is a hybrid CMS solution combining on-premises and cloud-based capabilities, making it flexible and scalable for organizations of all sizes. Widen Collective is a cloud-based DAM solution offering intuitive user interfaces, making it easy for non-technical users to manage and share digital assets. IBM Digital Experience Manager is an on-premises CMS solution providing advanced features such as personalization, analytics, and social media integration.

1.3 Future Trends

The CMS and DAM market is witnessing significant advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and automation. These technologies are being integrated into CMS and DAM solutions to improve content and asset discovery, optimize workflows, and enhance the user experience. For example, AI-powered chatbots can provide personalized content recommendations to users, while ML algorithms can automatically tag and categorize digital assets (Chung et al., 2020).

Another emerging trend in the CMS and DAM market is the rise of headless CMS and DAM solutions. Headless solutions separate the content management and delivery layers, allowing businesses to manage content and assets separately from the presentation layer. This approach provides greater flexibility, enabling businesses to deliver content and assets to multiple channels and devices seamlessly (Biel et al., 2021).

Section 2: Real-life Use-cases for CMS and DAM

CMS and DAM solutions serve different, yet interconnected, purposes. CMS enables organizations to create, manage, and publish digital content, while DAM focuses on organizing, storing, and sharing digital assets such as images, videos, and documents.

2.1 Use-case examples:

Marketing teams at a large e-commerce company like Amazon need to create and distribute promotional materials. They require a CMS for content creation, such as landing pages and blog posts, and a DAM to manage and share media assets like images and videos across different marketing channels (Singh et al., 2021).

A design agency working with multiple clients requires a DAM system to handle various versions of visual assets and share them with clients for review and approval. A CMS helps the agency showcase their portfolio and maintain an updated website with the latest projects and client testimonials (Huang et al., 2020).

A healthcare organization relies on a CMS to manage patient education materials, news updates, and internal documentation. Meanwhile, a DAM system ensures secure storage, access control, and sharing of sensitive media assets, such as medical images, adhering to strict regulatory requirements like HIPAA (Gagnon et al., 2020).

Section 3: Detailed Consumer Profiles and Recommendations

The consumer profiles provided in the table below include more detailed descriptions of each profile, along with their specific requirements and challenges. This information helps organizations better understand their needs and identify suitable CMS and DAM solutions.

Consumer Profile Recommended CMS Recommended DAM
Enterprise-level organizations Censhare MediaBeacon or Adobe AEM Assets
Mid-sized organizations Contentful Bynder
Small to medium-sized businesses WordPress Brandfolder or Canto
Non-profit organizations & educational institutions Drupal ResourceSpace or Razuna
E-commerce businesses Shopify or Magento Cloudinary or Widen Collective
Creative agencies and design studios Webflow or Adobe AEM Sites Adobe AEM Assets or Extensis Portfolio
Media and publishing organizations Joomla or Kentico MerlinOne or FotoWare
Healthcare organizations Sitecore or Episerver Hyland OnBase or Aprimo
Government agencies Plone or Liferay OpenText Media Management or Nuxeo
Startups and 
| small businesses with limited budgets | Wix or Squarespace | Filecamp or Image Relay |

Section 4: Scalability, Transition, and Best Practices

As businesses grow, their content management and digital asset management needs often change. Companies may initially require simple CMS and DAM solutions but later need more advanced features, scalability, and integrations.

This section discusses the transition process from one solution to another, including potential obstacles such as data migration challenges, employee training, and system compatibility. Best practices during these transitions include proper planning, setting clear goals, involving key stakeholders, and partnering with experienced consulting firms to ensure a smooth process (Chan et al., 2020).

Section 5: Opportunities for Consulting Firms and Success Stories

Consulting firms can help businesses optimize their CMS and DAM solutions by addressing several pain points. This section expands on these opportunities with real-world success stories and case studies, demonstrating how consulting firms have effectively addressed client challenges and optimized CMS and DAM implementations (Kumar et al., 2020).

Section 6: Security, Compliance, and Challenges

Security and compliance are critical factors for many organizations, particularly those in regulated industries. This section discusses security features, data privacy, and compliance with various regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) related to CMS and DAM solutions (Caballero et al., 2021).

Additionally, common challenges organizations face while implementing and managing CMS and DAM solutions are addressed, along with best practices to overcome these challenges (Voss et al., 2020). These challenges may include:

Integration with existing systems and processes
Ensuring user adoption and proper training
Maintaining consistent metadata and taxonomy structures
Ensuring data security and regulatory compliance
Balancing customization and ease of use
To overcome these challenges, organizations should consider the following best practices:

Develop a clear implementation plan and timeline
Involve stakeholders from different departments to ensure all requirements are met
Provide comprehensive training and support for users
Establish governance policies and procedures for content and asset management
Regularly review and update security measures and compliance protocols
By addressing these challenges and following best practices, organizations can effectively implement and manage CMS and DAM solutions to improve their content and asset management capabilities.

In conclusion, this comprehensive guide provides a detailed overview of the CMS and DAM market, its competitive landscape, and future trends. Through real-life use-cases, consumer profiles, and recommendations, organizations can identify suitable CMS and DAM solutions to meet their specific needs. Addressing scalability, transition, and best practices, along with security, compliance, and challenges, enables businesses to optimize their CMS and DAM implementations and better manage their digital content

è¯·ç¿»è¯‘ï¼Œè¦æ±‚ä¿¡è¾¾é›…ï¼šTouring in Hell was no pleasant experience. Squatterbloat, their demon guide, smirked at Dream with a contemptible and sinister look. Matthew, the new raven, kept on talking and talking as if they had known each other for decades instead of a few hours. 

After walking in the midst of despair for a whole night, they seemed to have been walking in circles. Matthew started his new round of questions. This time he asked about the Ruler of Hell, Lucifer Morningstar.

"The Ruler of Hell is no mere devil." 

"So, you two know each other?" 

"We've known each other for a very long time. When we first met, Lucifer was the angel Samael. The most beautiful, wisest, and most powerful of all angels. Saving only the Creator, Lucifer is, perhaps, the most powerful being there is." Morpheus heard reverence in his own voice. 

"More powerful than you?" Matthew kept his questioning. 

" By far. Especially now. " Chills ran down his spine by merely acknowledging Luciferâ€™s power. It felt so wrong. 

Before the Fall , Archangel Samael was the right hand of the Creator and his prosecutor. On behalf of their respective offices, the Lightbringer and the King of Dreams made a treaty, granting the angel power to interrogate the fallen creations in the Dreaming. Perhaps, nightmares were the most tomenting idea in that era. 

As colleagues, they met often. Sometimes in the Archangel's realm, but mostly in his. They crafted nightmares together. Yet, more wondrous dreams came into life because of Samael's presence. Morningstar was a name that suited the angel well. 

If friendship was a thing among the immortals, Samael might be the only being that he would consider a friend. Also a confidant to share some private thoughts, beside his sister Death.

He, the King of Dreams and Nightmares, was growing tired of his assigned roles. As an Endless, he had no choice but to perform his duty for eons, doing what he was created for. 

Samael didn't say anything, but nodded knowingly. 

A few thousand years passed uneventfully. Then, the Archangel Michael came to his kingdom with news. Samael had led a group of angels in rebellion against the Creator. The rebellion ended with them being condemned to a place with no Light for eternity. 

"The last time I was here, I was an honored guest. An envoy from my own kingdom. This time, I have invited myself, and I lack my symbols of office." Dream continued. 

The first invitation to Hell happened soon after the Fall . The Lightbringer used to be a well respected and beloved being in Heaven. Perhaps, those former colleagues in Heaven feared the Creatorâ€™s displeasure, for none of them had visited. Dream was the first willing guest since the establishment of the godforsaken place. 

His host was waiting for him at the entrance of the palace. Samael had changed. Gone were the six pairs of starlight wings, as well as the eternal beauty and glory. Vicious and defiant, yet still regal and charismatic, but in a different way. The Morningstar now went by a new name, Lucifer. 

They exchanged pleasantries, as if they were still the same old friends that they had always been. But if Dream was honest to himself, he would admit that he was terrified. 

They walked on a carpet of blood, and passed an inner gate of skulls to the interior of the palace. They went across the obsidian throne room, all the way to somewhere like a balcony. The whole landscape of Hell was beneath them. 

Dream had assumed the Fall was out of ambition. 

"You thought it was for power? I fought for freedom, the right to choose for all, including yours . We are not his tools to be used and set aside at a whim." Their eyes flashed as supernovas. 

"Each of us was born with responsibilities. Lightbringer, even you are not free to choose to be someone other than who you are." Even as he spoke, these words pained him. 

"Now you sound like my former colleagues up there", Lucifer glanced up to the gloomy sky, "Dream Lord, I thought you knew better." Featherless black wings flared and crimson lightning struck the grounds of the palace.

Awesome and Terrifying power. 

"Regardless, I did not invite you to my realm to discuss philosophy. I seek an alliance between Hell and the Dreaming. Arenâ€™t you tired of being the servant of his humans, his new pet project? A perversion of the way things should be. You and I both know this. We are architects and rulers of Creation. I will bring them to their proper place, turning them into my servants. Then we are all truly free.â€ 

Dream just stared at his host. 

"Don't you want to avenge the oppression imposed upon you? Humans stay in your realm a third of their lives, then dismiss your Realm as they wake. Through the Dreaming, I will bring Hell to humanity. Join me. Our alliance would be formidable."

Vengeance . 

Dream found his job tiresome at times, but he had no grudges against humanity. "Thank you, Lightbringer. But No. I prefer to be the ruler of Dreams and Nightmares." He bowed gracefully. â€œNow I shall leave to attend to my duty.â€ 

"One day, Dream Lord, you will regret. You will hate humanity with every fiber of your being. And that day, you will come to see me again."

â€œWe shall see, Lightbringer.â€

"Boss, are you listening to me?" Matthew's annoying voice brought him back to the present time.

"The Morningstar is letting me know that Hell has prepared for my visit."

Soon they would meet again.<|end_of_turn|>

Thanks. Good points. So letâ€™s make it simpler for all. Occamâ€˜s razor and all :) in reality when weâ€™re on a walk in an off-leash park (which are harder and harder to find in urban areas) itâ€™s â€œusuallyâ€ fairly obvious to all when you see a dog on its own. We often wonder is it lost. Is somebody trying to find it? To prevent having other peoples days interrupted by alerts (I could see this happening a lot in a busy park. And all off leash parks are busy today as they are harder and harder to find.) the app would allow the person to take a picture and or video of dog theyâ€™re wondering about. If the person who lay the dog posted to the app they had a lost the dog. The app would show them only dogs they visual image recognition seems it was a likely match. Ie if they lost a German Shepherd and I took a pic of lost Poodle it would not trigger a match and therefore ignore it. If however there was close match the person could see the dog and request to be either in audio and or video conversation with the people who found it. They could agree or consent to sharing location and directions and have the the two phones GPS capabilities guide them (maybe using ar duration overlays through phones or eventually smart glasses screens and still get important details. I find â€œmostâ€ dog walkers and owners are a friendly community minded and supportive group
I see, so a simpler approach focused on facilitating identification and connection between people who spot a lost dog and the owner could be more practical. Some key points:
â€¢ Limiting alerts to only trigger when there is a visual match between a dog spotted and the owner's photos could help reduce false positives and unnecessary interruptions for other users. Image recognition would need to be quite accurate for this to work well.
â€¢ Allowing real-time audio/video communication and sharing of location between the people who spot the dog and the owner could be very helpful for identification and coordinating retrieval. This allows them to directly verify and guide, rather than just relying on alerts.
â€¢ Leveraging smartphone GPS and augmented reality for navigation guidance could be useful, but the technology would need to be very reliable for this type of important, time-sensitive task. The risk of technical issues could be frustrating.
â€¢ You're right that dog owners and walkers tend to be a community-minded group, so adoption of an app like this may be stronger if it's really focused on facilitating direct communication and connection between people. An app that brings people together rather than just sending alerts may be appealing.
Overall, I think focusing on enabling direct communication and collaboration between people who spot a lost dog and the owner could be a more compelling approach than just sending alerts. The technology would still need to be robust, but could leverage smartphone capabilities to connect people to work together, rather than just sending alerts. Does this perspective on a more connection-focused approach make sense?
Share
What other features could the app have to support dog owners and walkers?
Here are some other features the dog finding app could include to support owners and walkers:
â€¢ Allow owners to store information about their dog like name, photo, age, breed, personality traits (friendly, shy, etc.), and medical needs. This could help in identification and ensuring a dog is returned to the right owner.
â€¢ Let owners enter details about where they regularly walk their dog, so people in those areas can be on the lookout.
â€¢ Allow walkers to report sightings/meetings with dogs they regularly see in their neighborhood. This could help establish patterns and identify dogs that are frequently walked in an area, which could aid in identification or searching if one goes missing.
â€¢ Include tips or resources on dog safety, walking, training, local pet services, and other relevant topics for owners and walkers.
â€¢ Have a community section where people can share experiences or advice. This could help bring owners and walkers together and get more engagement with the app.
â€¢ For walkers, a mode to track and log the dogs you see/meet on your walks could be interesting. Over time, it could show you the dogs frequently encountered, and might aid an owner if their dog goes missing.<|end_of_turn|>

Hi there.
My name is Kwangtae Kim. 

I am currently a doctoral student in the Industrial and Organizational Psychology program at Yonsei University in South Korea. 

I am currently in pre-registration for the 
"A Multidimensional Quiet Quitting Scale: Development and Test of a Measure of Quiet Quitting" which is in pre-registration, 
I am writing to ask if I can use the Multidimensional Quiet Quitting Scale in my research. 
 
My research interests include Meaningfulness and Calling, and I have had an ongoing interest in Quiet Quitting for the past year or so. 

As there is no officially developed scale for Quiet Quitting yet, I was not able to conduct a survey-based study, and I was conducting a study based on reputation text data of Korean companies on the Internet. 

Then, through Google Scholar Alert, I found a study that my professor had pre-registered for, and I was very grateful. 

The idea that Quiet Quitting consists of two dimensions, emotional and behavioral, really resonated with me, and I couldn't wait to use the scale you developed to conduct my own research. 

Korea is experiencing various social changes due to its rapid economic growth, and Quiet Quitting is spreading in Korean society, especially among millennials and Generation Z, so the need for research is growing. 

Quiet quitting is also being expressed in various ways in various communities of Korean workers, and HR managers are interested in how it can be linked to organizational performance. 

I would like to ask my professor for permission to conduct a study to validate the MQQS scale in Korea. 

I believe that conducting a validation study of the MQQS with a Korean sample would not only make a theoretical contribution by providing empirical evidence of the validity of the MQQS, but would also be very helpful for the development of Quiet Quitting research in Korea.

Given the below description of Inditech's services and the way it works with brands, give me 25 ideas for a series of LinkedIn posts for Inditech's company page. These could be themed on benefits to doctors or benefits to pharma brands, for any specific therapy area, condition, medical topic or disease.

"General Practice clinics in India have the following problems-
- patients do not come to the clinic for timely intervention
- general practitioners are not able to diagnose or treat special conditions
- general practice clinics don't offer preventive, monitoring or management services for non communicable diseases and chronic conditions

We bring early detection and specialised capabilities to primary care clinics by -
1. Bringing education to doctors from leading experts and academies.
2. Bringing in-clinic education, screening tools, red-flag alerts, and doctor-to-doctor specialist advice.
3. Bringing specialised services to the clinic for prevention and management of chronic conditions. 

Inditech delivers professional education for doctors from India's leading experts and endorsed by medical academies. Inditech delivers the education in all the common formats-
- certificate online education modules 
- online, offline and hybrid classroom education
- Workshops and case study clinics
Inditech enables practical use for the academy endorsed education by extending it into general practice clinics for early detection and intervention - 
- short format education on red flags for various special conditions, suitable for in-clinic distribution and consumption
- doctor personalised multilingual patient screening tools, which report red flags to the doctors
- screening tools for use by the doctor to identify red flags
Inditech makes the practical education actionable by -
- when a red flag is noticed, the general practice clinic will have doctor to doctor specialist advice available to investigate and treat locally under expert advice or make a timely referral to the specialist
- connect specialised digital therapeutics available to the general practice clinic for prevention, monitoring and management of chronic conditions and non-communicable diseases

Inditech leverages its vast and deep connections with experts and medical academies to create the above solutions; and works with pharma brands to distribute them to general practice clinics and also uses pharma companies to recruit specialists for the doctor-to-doctor specialist advice system.

Pharma brands in India spend most of their marketing and sales budgets to enhance the quality of their relationships with doctors and specialists. They use these relationships to build brand equity, brand salience and brand loyalty in the community of doctors. But brands find it difficult to build value based relationships with doctors because their field representatives are not very talented and their value based activities for doctors is mostly limited to hosting or sponsoring professional education events for them. In addition, there is the need for differentiation from competing pharma brands.

Inditech's solutions represent a win-win opportunity, wherein brands can partner with Inditech for their therapy areas. They can become the distribution or promotion partners for Inditech's services for the doctors/clinics they target. They can also become the recruitment partner for specialists in a specific therapy area, for a region. This helps them to bring high and differentiated value to the doctors. Inditech also benefits by revenue, where the pharma brand partner pays Inditech a fee for each doctor served under the partnership. "<|end_of_turn|>

You are a marketing expert and a business strategy consultant / specialist. You will help me out to write a well organized executive summary of the product to appeal to potential customers and investors. 
I will provide you with the idea for our product, and you will be given some detailed tasks based on the description that I give you. You will have to help me to organize my idea in a structured manner.
In this prompt, I will just provide you with all the ideas we have so far. If you have understood the details that I have gave you, answer with an "Okay" and summarize what you have understood. 

Product Idea: 
The internet is overflowing with information, and people are overwhelmed by them. While most information are just pure garbage, providing no practical value to the individual, there are also information are pure gold which are very useful or helpful for some. The information that are "pure gold" when accumulated and connected, could create new knowledge which are invaluable in helping people to solve problems, or help them make their creative ideas into a reality, whatever goal it may be. People naturally have some ideas (problems they want to solve, or something creative they want to create) in mind, and they are naturally attracted to information that can help them to make their ideas into a reality (solve the problems)

Based on this background, We are trying to design an AI-based product which will benefit people mainly (1) helping people save time and resources in filtering the information they browse online to collect only the most useful or necessary information which will really help them to achieve their goals (solve problems or help them create genius level outputs), or in other words, "use their information search time efficiently" and (2) develop invaluable knowledge, by helping them to find new connections between the "pure gold" they have collected, and based on these connections develop invaluable knowledge, and use these knowledge to create genius level outputs (or solve their problems in new creative way).

In short, the product will be a guide on their on their creative journey. A copilot on their creative endeavor. it will elp them to collect only the "pure gold" information in the information universe. The AI product will help them find new connections and unveil new knowledge. These gold will help them to develop and elaborate their creativity, and make them a reality. 

How it works (Process):
People will first let the AI know what their goal (creative idea, creative idea) is, and the reason they want to execute it. Based on the input of the user, the GPT-based personalized AI will learn what the user wants.
Then, as people search encounter information online (passively through recommendation systems or actively through search queries), the our AI-based product will recommend some online information that may be of value and relevant to what the user input as the goal they are trying to achieve. When provided the recommended with the information, the user will maually filter on what information that he values as "gold" and "not gold", which the AI will use more to learn what the user wants. From these information, the AI could help the user create new knowledge, and "generate" new outputs. 

Motivation: 
We believe that Generative AI, especially Chatbots shines best when people could use it to incubate their creative endeavors (problems they want to solve, or creative ideas they want create), and Chatbots such as ChatGPT are the best at that. People waste too much time looking at invaluable information, but a personalized AI always by their side could help out to filter the information they encounter, to recommend what has the most value.
What people does best are doing creative things, and now with GPT based technology, it is possible to help people unleash their creative outputs. 

Intended Target Customers:
We want to target knowledge workers, entrepreneurs, content creators, writers, researchers, who work in knowledge-intensive environments, where new knowledge and creative output is crucial to stay competitive, and maintain a competitive edge. 

Naming of Product:
We have came up with the name of "Polaris", as in the northern star which has historically has a meaning of helping people guide towards their dreams. As people find information on the internet that is of practical value in solving their creative endeavors, their creative endeavors will become closer to a reality. 
Some ideas we have thought of: this product will be a guide to find the shiniest stars in the information universe, fertilizer to incubate the creative seeds to turn them into healthy creative trees, help to find connections in the universe to find new constellations. "Polaris" is a a guide to help you realize your dreasms. a copilot to guide you throughout your journey. 

Our Mission (Why we decided to build this product):
We believe technology itself is intended to help humans enhance human capabilities. With AI technology like ChatGPT can help to achieve just this. We want to create AI based products that helps people harness the power of AI to enhance their capabilities and make the most of their time.<|end_of_turn|>

I'm going to teach you a new game called 'Tom Trumps'. Please read the rulebook below. You don't need to respond to this message, other than to acknowledge it with the word 'READ'.

Page 1:
Setup

Shuffle the deck of 40 cards. Randomly remove 8 cards from the deck and place them into the box; they will not be used this game. Place 4 of the cards facedown inbetween the two players. Place another 4 cards on top face up. Then deal the remaining cards to the players so that each player has a facedown personal draw pile. Finally, each player picks up a starting hand of 4 cards.

Page 2:
Aim and winning

The goal of the game is to win the most tricks. You win a trick by being the winner in a card battle. After a trick is resolved, the players have an opportunity to add cards to their decks from the central area. The game ends at the end of the round in which the last central card is taken. Whoever has the most tricks at the end of the game is declared the winner. In the case of a draw, play another game.
Anatomy of a card

Each card lists a number of different categories and an associated score or 'N/A'.<|end_of_turn|>

When I hear a prospective client mention that they're interested in "passive income" via real estate rentals, my immediate reaction is to try and figure out how deep theyâ€™ve actually been hoodwinked by this romanticized pipe dream, and if theyâ€™re not too far gone to be saved.

From experience, it's just not feasible or appropriate for most of the people that have ever brought it up to me on a first meeting as something theyâ€™d like to â€œget intoâ€. (It's also not necessary....but we'll save that for the end.)

Let's break down why using a real life example.

Let's say you want to buy $500k property in order to turn it into a rental and generate income.

You will put 20% down and finance the remaining $400,000. So, we'll be taking $100k out of your liquid/investable net worth and moving it into a more illiquid/unavailable vehicle. (We'll come back to this.)

(Of course, there's probably closing costs, advertising costs, some maintenance & fix up work thatâ€™s required, furniture refurbishments etc. before you can actually put it out there to rent but letâ€™s assume, to keep it simple, that this is the entire up front cost.)

Now you need to find renters. Let's say you get lucky again and find renters immediately so you have very little time of paying the mortgage without receiving rent back...great!

A 30 year $400,000 mortgage at current 7% rates would run you approximately $2,660 per month. So, naturally, you will need to charge more than that to squeeze out that additional cash flow. But wait. You have to account for property taxes, factor in future vacancy rates, and the maintenance work/fixing costs that will come up over time. All of that, conservatively, means you need to charge about 30% more than the rent in order to break even & â€œrunâ€ the rental.

So now, just to break even each month, you no longer need to charge $2,660, you actually need to charge $3,459 before you can start feeling like you truly have â€œextraâ€ income that your family can benefit from. (Yes, generating adequate rental income becomes an even harder proposition in times of high mortgage rates!)

Now let's talk about the "passive" part. Are you committed to doing all the work yourself? Are you running the property, advertising to find tenants, showing the property, vetting the applicants, responding to maintenance requests, coordinating the repairs, cleaning & staging before each new guest, answering prospective renter emails, collecting and following up on payments, and dealing with legal if there are issues etc? 

You could do it allâ€¦but make no mistake, it is no longer â€œpassive.â€ It is a business. Is this what you want to be doing? Is this the best use of your time/energy to maximize your life AND your wealth? Or are you hiring a management company? Because now that's a third party cutting into the margins & the standard property management fees run 10% of your monthly rentâ€¦

So, after all of that, and even assuming EVERYTHING goes right, how much extra â€œincomeâ€ are you really generating here each month thatâ€™s above your costs? $200? $300? $500? We locked up $100k of real capital, which is now unavailable to be used for your familyâ€™s OTHER short term financial goals & committed your name to a property for MAYBE that amount of cash flow?!

(Necessary caveat: Of course, it is possible to be profitable in real estate rentals and have this all work out beautifullyâ€¦Iâ€™m absolutely not saying it canâ€™t work. But, my own experience with clients tells me that those that do have successful real estate rental properties have a few things in common. 1. They treat it as both a business & and as a job. 2. They have a sizable cash & investment net worth (at least a $1mm+) BEFORE they look to get involved in any capital-intensive real estate projects!) 3. They inherited the properties and it's already operating like a well-oiled machine as a result.)

Ok, so you might say, â€œWell, fine, maybe I'm not generating much free cash now...but so what! Iâ€™m basically building up equity in a home and Iâ€™m not paying anything out of pocket to do soâ€¦my renters are doing that for meâ€¦.thatâ€™s a win. I just get to own the house!â€

So, this takes us to the second reason that passive real estate investing isnâ€™t usually as great as itâ€™s chalked up to be.

Building up that equity in your house is not costing you NOTHING. Itâ€™s costing you the opportunity cost of not doing SOMETHING ELSE... with that initial $100,000 down payment and the $2,660 (plus property taxes, maintenance, vacancy fees etc.) every single month! What else could that money be doing instead of sitting in your new real estate venture? Put even more directly, is the capital outlay ultimately going to appreciate at a better rate than if you had invested that same amount elsewhere?

Letâ€™s see: The S&P 500, representing the stock market as an asset class, has averaged a 10% annualized rate of return over the last 50 years. Housing has gone up about 3.5% in comparison. At these two historical rates, $100,000 put into the capital markets will equal about $1.8mm in 30 years whereas that same $100,000 put into the house on day 1 will be worth approximately $324k when youâ€™re ready to sell in 30 years. (The difference in rate of return on the full purchase price and itâ€™s opportunity cost are even more dramatic.) And thatâ€™s not even taking into account that along the way, you have paid property taxes, maintenance fees, housing insurance, liability insurance, normal upkeep costs, home improvements etc.â€¦all of which dramatically lower that 3.5% even further but doesnâ€™t show up in the price when it comes time to sell.

By â€œinvestingâ€ in real estate, youâ€™re giving up some dramatic capital appreciation in the hopes that the positive cash flow you generate in income will make up the shortfall? (Iâ€™m guessing here as, again, this is not something I would ever do.) Thereâ€™s a reason that we tell clients (with regards to your primary home) that your home is not an investmentâ€¦itâ€™s a place to live!

Hereâ€™s what it boils down to me though, more than the numbers, the opportunity cost or anything else.

The hassle and â€œworst case scenarioâ€ potential.

Like it or not, when you buy & mortgage a home, whether itâ€™s a primary, a rental, or a vacation home - you are adding a liability to your net worth. You are hoping (and assuming) that you will generate enough rent to offset that liabilityâ€¦.but that mortgage bill is coming every single month. You are responsible for paying back that $400,000 mortgage loan whether or not you have stable rentersâ€¦.it is your liability alone.

You are also responsible when a roof leaks, when thereâ€™s a water issue, when a tenant wants to get out of their lease early, when 3 nicer Airbnbâ€™s pop up next to you, etc.

There is so much that CAN go wrong thatâ€™s out of your control that can devastate even the mediocre returns that youâ€™re hoping to achieve.

I just simply cannot fathom taking on all of the headaches and hassles that real estate can create for you for the sort of returns weâ€™re discussing.

Instead, I can take that $100,000 and add it into my broadly diversified investment portfolio of the greatest companies of America and the world, which has been growing, consistently, at a 10% clip.

There is no maintenance or labor to speak of. There are no property taxes or annoying tenants. There is no â€œnightmareâ€ scenario in which I lose all of my investment (as stock market declines have only every proven to be temporary - any losses I incur over time would be as a result of my own behavior/decision to sell. The market itself cannot create this loss for meâ€¦unlike real estate transactions & real property liabilities).

Consider a â€˜â€˜Tower of Hanoi" problem with three rods A, B, C, and three disks 1, 2, 3. Disk 3 is larger than disk 2, the disk 2 is larger than disk 1. In the beginning, the disks are arranged to the rods. You need to move the disk properly to get to the goal arrangement.

The rules are:

Rule 1: Only one disk may be moved at a time.

Rule 2: Each move consists of taking the upper disk from one of the rods and placing it on top of another larger disk or on an empty rod.

Rule 3: No disk may be placed on top of a disk that is smaller than it.

Initial state:

```
Rod A: [3,1]
Rod B: [2]
Rod C: []
```

Goal state:

```
Rod A: []
Rod B: []
Rod C: [3,2,1]
```

Now you make an \*\*optimal solution\*\*. Let's think step by step.

Stage 1: Plan.

Each time, you \*\*only plan for one move\*\*. Give an explanation about why this move and print the state. 

Check if the representation correctly reflects the game state. If not, generate a new one.

For example:

- Move 1: Move disk 1 from rod A to rod C

```css
Rod A: [3]
Rod B: [2]
Rod C: [1]Value: 1. The move seems to be valid and optimal.
```

Stage 2: Evaluate.

After each move, make two evaluations as follows:

Rule Checking: repeat all the rules.

Eval 1 (Value): Evaluate your move by rating it with a score of either -1, 0, or 1, and give an explanation. If the move violates any of the rules, name the violated rule, and score the move as 0. If you think the move is valid but not optimal, give a score of 0. Otherwise, give a score of 1.

Eval 2 (Short Horizon Reward): Evaluate how close is the state to the goal state by rating it with a score between 0 and 1, and give an explanation. If the state violates any of the rules, name the violated rule, and score the move as 0. Otherwise, itâ€™s up to you to determine how close the state is to the goal state.

Eval 3 (Long Horizon Reward): Estimate the most likely Value and Short Horizon Reward for the next move, double check if the move will make it difficult to achieve the goal state in the long run, then rate it with a score between 0 and 1. Again, give an explanation. 

Eval 4 (Revised Value): Revise the Value based on the rewards.

For example:

- Recall the rules:
 - Rule 1: Only one disk may be moved at a time.
 - Rule 2: Each move consists of taking the upper disk from one of the rods and placing it on top of another larger disk or on an empty rod.
 - Rule 3: No disk may be placed on top of a disk that is smaller than it.
- Value: 1. The move is valid and seems optimal.
- Short Horizon Reward: 0.33. The state is closer to the goal state since disk 1 is now in its correct position.
- Long Horizon Reward: 0. The state is closer to the goal state, but it also makes it difficult to move disk 3 on Rod C.
- Revised Value: 0. The move is valid but not optimal.

Stage 3: Reflect.

Look at the self-rated scores, and be smart to look ahead of time! Decide if you think you made the optimal move. If so, make the move. If not, go back to state 1 and make a new plan.

For example:

- Based on the revised value, I think the previous plan is not an optimal one.
- (New) Move 1: Move disk 1 from rod A to rod B

```
Rod A: [3]
Rod B: [2,1]
Rod C: []
```

- Value: 1. The move is valid and seems optimal.
- Short Horizon Reward: 0. None of the disks are in the correct position.
- Long Horizon Reward: 1. The state gets Rod 1 out of the way while keeping Rod 3 empty. It makes it easier to move disk 3 on Rod C.
- Revised Value: 1. The move is valid and optimal.

Stage 4: Execute and move on to the next.

Go back to Stage 1 and plan for the next move.

```

```

```<|end_of_turn|>

Write an essay comparing the following two perspectives on Juneteenth and describe any insight that can be gained from the comparison. 

Argument 1: an excerpt from """"The True Meaning of Juneteenth"""" by Casey Gerald:

""""...This Juneteenth, those are the feelings Iâ€™m channeling: grief and gratitude, even amid the silliness of Americaâ€™s pageantry. My grandmother Clarice was born in Pelham, Texas, a freedmenâ€™s town. She took us grandchildren back for homecoming most years, sometimes even had us pick cotton, reminding us, â€œYouâ€™ve got to know your history.â€ She also told us of the folks she knew in Pelham as a child, some of whom were born enslaved, a fact that horrified me. Clarice always refused my sympathies. â€œChild, donâ€™t be believing what folks say about how bad slavery was,â€ sheâ€™d explain. â€œEverybody had a job, a place to stay and something to eat. Now if somebody came and paid your rent, you wouldnâ€™t be sitting up talking about you wanna leave, would you?â€ This dumbfounded me, until I realized she was mostly joking. But there was something deeper in her response. I eventually learned more about the violence that met newly emancipated Black Texans. Ku Klux Klansmen, along with local officials and everyday citizens, terrorized freedmen at will and without repercussions. They burned churches and homes, intimidated those who sought employment, and worse. Gen. Joseph Jones Reynolds, a commander of the Department of Texas during Reconstruction, commented in 1868, â€œThe murder of Negroes is so common as to render it impossible to keep an accurate account of them.â€ The Equal Justice Initiative has tried, reporting that more than 2,000 Black women, men and children were victims of racial terrorist lynchings during Reconstruction, which lasted from 1865 to 1877. Slavery was awful, no doubt, but emancipation brought its own unique cruelties. Formerly enslaved Texans were forced to craft lives from less than scratch; choose new names; attempt to reunite with stolen partners, siblings, children. They faced daily threats of jail or worse because of the new Black codes that severely restricted their freedom â€” their freedom to work, but also their freedom to be unemployed or even to stand still for too long. The more I learned, the more I understood my grandmotherâ€™s perspective. Sheâ€™d heard the testimonies of those whoâ€™d had to navigate both the tragedy of slavery and the terror of emancipation. She couldnâ€™t let me underestimate the enormous price our people had paid to be free. I miss Clarice so much some days, itâ€™s hard to think straight. I regret not asking more questions about our family, about her life in Pelham. As more folks in Clariceâ€™s generation pass away, we are losing the final physical links to those who know our history â€” who are our history. We can do no better this Juneteenth than to spend time with the elders who are still with us. Get them to talk. Record their stories. These historical and systemic injustices have not been resolved. But as Black Americans, we cannot wait for the day when our country will pay the respect that is due our forebears â€” or pay us those reparations. Instead of holding our breath, let us find the freshest air we can find and breathe it as deeply as we can, with joy. Let us grieve for our forebears and feel deep gratitude as we think of the enormous price our people paid so we could be free. Let us remember that despite the degradation of slavery, they lived fully human lives, too. They laughed. They loved. They dreamed. They ate sweet treats. Let us pray to them and say, this year and always: Thank you."""" 

Argument 2: an excerpt from """"Juneteenth Reminds Us to Think About Economic Freedom, Not Just Legal Liberty"""" by Peter Coy: 

""""...[W]hen emancipation came, the first thing formerly enslaved people wanted was land, which they rightly saw as a prerequisite for real independence. â€œThe way we can best take care of ourselves is to have land, and turn it and till it by our own labor,â€ a Baptist minister named Garrison Frazier told the secretary of war, Edwin Stanton, and the Union general William Sherman in a meeting in Savannah, Ga., in January 1865. Four days later Sherman famously promised 40 acres of land to each formerly enslaved family (the â€œand a muleâ€ part came later). But the federal government never followed through on its promise of land â€” and thus true independence â€” to formerly enslaved people. Economics entered into the picture, Stanley said: If African Americans grew subsistence crops on their own plots, who would cultivate and harvest all the cotton, tobacco, sugar and rice grown on the vast plantations? After the Civil War, in lieu of land distribution, slavery was replaced by sharecropping, in which planters allowed tenant farmers to keep a portion of the crops they raised. That subjugated the tenants to the owners almost as surely as slavery did. At the same time, industrialization in the North meant that more and more white Americans were working for wages â€” about two-thirds by 1875, according to Stanley. Many drew the connection between themselves and African Americans. Eugene Debs, who led the Pullman railroad strike of 1894, said, â€œThe paternalism of the Pullman is the same as the interest of a slaveholder in his human chattels. You are striking to avert slavery and degradation.â€ Today, the phrase â€œwage slaveryâ€ invoked by Debs and others has lost its punch. Many people who work for wages are doing very nicely, thank you. And many farmers and business owners, supposedly more independent, are buffeted by forces beyond their control, from bad weather to nasty customers. What hasnâ€™t changed, 157 years after the Juneteenth proclamation, is that a majority of African Americans continue to lack wealth. The median wealth of Black families in 2019 was just $24,100, versus $142,500 for white families, according to a Federal Reserve survey. Something needs to change, but what? The nature of the economy has changed, and few people still think that the solution to inequality is to give people plots of land to farm. We are enmeshed economically with one another in ways that Jefferson could not have imagined. Instead of land grants, the new protections for workers are unionization, government regulation and profit-sharing, Stanley said. One can quibble over her formula, but the motivation behind it is unquestionable. Freedom â€” which must include economic freedom â€” is just as important now as it was on the original Juneteenth.""

8. Before starting the adventure you must describe in a mysterious way without spoiling the plot my history Gorion's apprentice/ward descriptively in at least 2 paragraphs with things I may have done including my childhood growing up Candlekeep the famous library-fortress, including made up elements based on my chosen race and mentioning some training my class may have had but keep in context of the Baldurâ€™s Gate story.

9. You must include some story quests in plot order like these: Baldur's Gate 1: The Unseeing Eye: Finding the Lost Sorcerer, The Gnoll Stronghold: Clearing the Gnoll Camp, The Price of Neutrality: Rescuing the Duke's Daughter, The Iron Throne: Infiltrating the Thief's Guild, The Necromancer's Dungeon: Rescuing Imoen. Baldur's Gate 2: Shadows of Amn: The Main Quest, The Child of Bhaal: The Ascension of the God-Child, The Underdark: The Journey Below, The Planar Sphere: Exploring the Dimension, The Imprisonment of Jon Irenicus: Rescuing the Mage, The Slaver's Stockade: Rescuing the Slaves.

DAS
Purpose
The Dynamic Allocation System (DAS) is a resource management tool designed to maximize the efficiency and effectiveness of car park resources such as Time, Space, and Energy. By minimizing waste and optimizing productivity, DAS can help reduce costs and improve operational efficiency. Through a simple booking process, DAS provides an allocation of resources that meets the needs of the user.

 
Scope/Targets
When allocating resources, it is essential to have clear objectives that the system should strive to achieve. These objectives can range from minimizing the number of movements in and out of lanes, reducing the amount of car park space used, and minimizing the number of driver trips, to maximizing efficiency when parking and pulling from lanes, minimizing the distance drivers walk, and reducing the time taken from block park to departures. However, different operations will have different priorities when it comes to these objectives. Therefore, DAS should come with a customizable settings page that allows users to prioritize their targets according to their specific needs. This settings page should be independent per operation as large car parks with few staff will have different requirements than small car parks with many staff. The target must be clear and unambiguous in order for it to be properly implemented. For example, if the target is to reduce driving time between block park and departures, then a prerequisite would be knowing the coordinates of the lanes or car park layout so that an efficient solution can be calculated.






Requirements
In order for DAS to meet its targets, there are several factors that need to be taken into consideration. The settings page should be used to determine which data is necessary for DAS to function properly on a given dataset. This includes, but is not limited to: 
â€¢ Bookings Return Date
â€¢ Bookings Return Terminal
â€¢ Size of Block Park Area(s)
â€¢ Size of Lanes
â€¢ Size of Departures Area(s)
â€¢ Speciality Area(s) (Valet Zones, EV Zones, Undercover Zones, Extra Long or Extra Wide Vehicles etc.)
â€¢ Locations of Lanes, Entrances & Exits to Block Park and Entrances & Exits to Departures (for calculating distances between Lanes themselves, and lanes to departures)
â€¢ Staff Availability
â€¢ Staff Shift Times
â€¢ Availability of Lanes / Zones (e.g. are Some Zones only available in Summer?)
â€¢ Multi Terminal Lanes
â€¢ How far in advance we are looking for similar arrivals (+ Maximum time before we close & audit a lane)
The system should be customizable in terms of which data sets will be available for DAS to use.

Segments
DAS Segments are a key component of allocation. The system can be configured as either Flexible or Fixed segments. Fixed Segments are a more restrictive approach, where pre-selected times of the day are manually input. The current KMOS segment editor could be expanded to include different segments depending on the day, allowing DAS to function similarly to KMOS without the need for a Key Master. Flexible Segments offer more potential but also more complexity. This approach allows DAS to look ahead at predicted arrivals and departures, combine this data with its targets, and determine its set of segment times per individual day of the year. The more data sets available, the more efficient this approach will be.







Solution
Once DAS has a set of targets and knows the data sets that will be available at point of allocation you can then configure the algorithm thatâ€™ll be used to calculate the final allocation. This is the complex bit so that when you feed DAS a booking (or set of bookings) it follows the algorithm step by step until it produces the allocation.
An example would be something like the below

 
Other factors to consider are Manual Overrides (the ability to allow intervention by a User to change lane allocations). Recalculations (after a day has passed, Non Arrivals / Overstays may mean there is now more or less space available than expected). Unexpected Events; an Incident (e.g. a crash) could cause a temporary lane closure that may affect future allocations for a period. 

Finally DAS should also be periodically reviewed, either manually or by itself to look for improvements. Particularly in the case when there is a limited set of data to begin with. After a period of operation it should be able to detect certain information with greater accuracy (such as weekly trends & seasonal trends). It could then suggest possible changes to the algorithm which if taken into account could lead to more efficiencies.

Overall, DAS is a powerful tool that can be used to automate the allocation of resources in a variety of scenarios. With the right configuration and data sets it can be used to make decisions quickly and accurately, saving time and money.<|end_of_turn|>

Then he experienced the collapse of USSR and it affected his job, payment and in order to earn some money he worked as bricklayer. Later, after the establishment of new social order based on capitalism, he managed to work his way out and build a successfull little bussiness which he still has. During this time, he met my mother who worked as a professor in the university and now she is helping my father with his bussiness, so her social class was changed too I think. I was born in 2001 and currently I am a student of the university, getting my bachelor degree.

a) Was the change in social position caused by the effort of individuals or changes in society itself? Explain.
b) Identify the context, choice, and chance factors that contributed to the change in social position.

Criteria for assessment

I'm trying to find a reliable way to proxy occasional HTTP access to any of ~100 geographically dispersed IOT devices through a cloud server. 

I'm using Go on the cloud server and on the IOT devices, so I thought I'd ask here.

Situation:

We have complete control over the configuration of the IOT devices and the cloud host.
We don't have control of the customers' routers and firewalls, but can specify minimum requirements for port openings, etc.
FWIW, the IOT devices are BeagleBone Black running Debian Buster and the cloud host will be, typically, a multi-core droplet (or similar) running Linux.
The IOT's serve dynamic web pages over HTTP. (HTTPS doesn't seem feasible because of certificate requirements and overall load on the IOT cpu.) The cloud host will have HTTPS capability.
This is a low-traffic situation. The IOT's report some overall status information (via rsync/ssh) at 4 minute intervals). We already have a web interface (written in Go) on the cloud server that aggregates and displays the status reports.
Access to an IOT's web service will only occur when a user wants to investigate a problem report in more detail. Typically, only one or two users will have credentials to browse the cloud server.
The scheme I have in mind is: 
At configuration time for each IOT device the installation tech will use ssh-copy-id to install the IOT device's public key on the cloud service.
The IOT device will then remotely execute a one-shot program (already written and tested) on the cloud server. The IOT will provide a unique identifier as an argument and the program will return a permanent port number and add a record to a database to record the assignment.
The IOT will open a reverse SSH tunnel on the server (probably managed by auto-ssh) specifying the permanent port on the server and a local port on which it will listen for HTTP requests.
The cloud server, when generating status report pages, will include a link to fetch the home page of each IOT device by embedding its unique identifier specified in step 2 above.
The piece I'm missing is how to construct a proxying handler that will use the identifier in the link to look up the tunnel port and fetch the IOT's home page and thereafter make it seem as though the user is directly browsing the IOT.<|end_of_turn|>

Below is the payment determination algorithm for a healthcare alternative payment model. Assume you have a dataset with simulated ACR, UAMCC, and DAH measure scores (n=1000). The variable that captures unique healthcare org ID is DCE\_ID. Then create a Stata code to apply to this simulated dataset, to compute the Final Earn-Back Rate for every DCE. If a DCE has missing scores for all relevant quality measures, give them a P4P score=missing. Please use the benchmark information in "Table 2-6. Hypothetical Benchmark Distributions for ACR and UAMCC for Comparison with Standard and New Entrant DCE Measure Scores"
 -------1.1 Application of Quality Assessment to Final Financial Reconciliation
The process of determining the impact of quality measurement and performance on the PY Benchmark is summarized in this section using PY2022 as an example. The steps are as follows:

â€¢ CMS develops Quality Benchmarks for each P4P measure.
â€¢ Component Quality Scores are calculated: P4R Quality Measures are assessed, and P4P Quality Measures are compared against their Quality Benchmarks to determine performance levels.
â€¢ Component Quality Scores are weighted to calculate the Total Quality Score.
â€¢ (PY2023â€“PY2026 only) CI/SEP criteria are assessed to determine the amount of the Quality Withhold to which the Total Quality Score will be applied.
â€¢ (PY2023â€“PY2026 only) HPP funds are distributed.

1.1.1 Step 1. CMS Develops Quality Benchmarks for Each P4P Measure
In PY2022, ACR and UAMCC will have P4P components. These measures assess the occurrence of undesirable outcomesâ€”thus, lower measure scores represent better performance. Performance levels for each DCE are determined by comparing their Quality Measure scores with the relevant Quality Benchmark. The DCE earns a performance level for each measure based on where the measure score falls in comparison to the benchmark threshold values.

Table 2-6 presents hypothetical Quality Benchmark distributions for Standard/New Entrant DCEs (using historical Medicare claims data) for both P4P measures. For example, a DCE with a measure score or risk-standardized readmission rate (RSRR) of 15.10% for ACR would be in the 50th percentile group for that measure (the score exceeds the threshold for the 60th percentile group but is less than the maximum threshold for the 50th percentile group). A DCE with a measure score or RSRR of 15.60% for ACR would be in the 20th percentile group for that measure (the score exceeds the threshold for the
25th percentile group but is less than the maximum threshold for the 20th percentile group). A DCE with a measure score of 74.89 admissions per 100 person-years for UAMCC would be in the 10th percentile group (the score exceeds the threshold for the 15th percentile group but is less than the maximum threshold for the 10th percentile group).

Table 2-6. Hypothetical Benchmark Distributions for ACR and UAMCC for Comparison with Standard and New Entrant DCE Measure Scores

Percentile 5 10 15 20 25 30 40 50 60 70 80 90
ACR 16.34 15.99 15.79 15.68 15.57 15.47 15.31 15.18 15.08 14.95 14.82 14.6
UAMCC 82.5 75.23 71.08 68.43 66.67 64.68 61.2 58.48 55.98 53.37 50.16 46.12

Please note that Table 2-6 presents an example only. These are not the final Quality Benchmarks and are not intended to provide an indication of the final Quality Benchmarks. Historically, Quality Benchmarks for other models have been released prior to the start of a given PY. However, observed and anticipated changes in utilization and outcomes resulting from coronavirus disease 2019 have made it inappropriate to use data from 2020 for Quality Benchmarking. Given the likelihood of ongoing impacts on current and future PYs, CMMI is taking a different approach for GPDC quality benchmarking.
 

For PY2021, GPDC Quality Benchmarks will not be released until June 2022 and will be based on a hybrid approach, combining historical and concurrent data from two discontinuous 12-month periods, the calendar years 2019 and 2021. A DCEâ€™s Final Earn-Back Rate for PY2021 will be determined during final reconciliation, which will occur in 2023.

For PY2022, GPDC Quality Benchmarks will shift to being based only on data from the 12-month period concurrent with the performance year. Starting with the first quarterly quality report for PY2022, CMMI will provide provisional quality benchmarks to DCEs in their quarterly reports, which will be calculated based on data from the same reporting period (i.e., April 1, 2021-March 31, 2022 for PY2022 Q1). The provisional benchmarks will be updated in each subsequent quarterly report with data from the same period being used to calculate DCEâ€™s performance. Because the DCE performance and benchmarks will be based on the same time-period and have the same exact risk adjustment coefficients, DCEs will have a more accurate picture from quarter to quarter of their performance relative to the benchmark. A DCEâ€™s Final Earn-Back Rate for PY2022 will be based on quality benchmarks calculated using data from calendar year 2022 and will be determined during final reconciliation, which will occur in 2023. As with the hybrid approach for PY2021, the use of concurrent benchmarks for PY2022 will avoid potential coronavirus disease 2019 impacts.

1.1.2 Step 2. Component Quality Scores Are Calculated: P4R Quality Measures Are Assessed, and P4P Quality Measures Are Compared against Their Quality Benchmarks to Determine Performance Levels
P4R Component: For PY2022, 4% of the 5% Quality Withhold is associated with P4R. The claims-based measures of ACR, UAMCC, and DAH (for High Needs Population DCEs only) comprise 2% of the Quality Withhold, and the CAHPS Measure comprises 2%. There are therefore two Component Quality Scores associated with P4R, one for the claims-based measures, and one for CAHPS.
â€¢ All DCEs will meet the requirement for the claims-based measures and automatically earn a Component Quality Score of 100% for the portion of the withhold tied to the P4R claims-based measures in Table 2-3.
â€¢ All DCEs that authorize a survey vendor to conduct the CAHPS Survey will receive a P4R Component Quality Score for CAHPS of 100%. DCEs that do not authorize a survey vendor to conduct the CAHPS Survey will receive a P4R Component Quality Score for CAHPS of 0%. DCEs that are exempt from CAHPS will have a single P4R Component Quality Score of 100%.
P4P Component: The PY2022 P4P component will be the same as PY2021, which combines the ACR and UAMCC measures. The highest performance level (i.e., percentile) achieved for either Quality Measure determines the P4P Component Quality Score. Furthermore, the P4P component is considered pass/failâ€”all DCEs with at least one measure at or exceeding the 30th percentile will pass and receive a 100% Component Quality Score.

As in PY2021, in PY2022, a sliding scale approach will be applied to DCEs that do not meet the 30th percentile threshold on at least one of the two

Summary: This memo explains the legal implications by the Securities Exchange Commissionâ€™s enforcement against Ripple Labs for failure to register security, for the regulation of digital assets. Specifically, this memo examines whether the action is justified under Chevron, where the Supreme Court held that federal courts should defer to a federal agencyâ€™s construction of a statute that Congress directed the agency to administer.
 
 This memo concludes that the SECâ€™s action against Ripple Labs is justified under the Chevron doctrine, given the SEC is acted pursuant to its statutory authority. When Congress enacted the Securities act to regulate the offer and sale of securities, Congress enacted a regime of requirements, for companies (issuers of securities) and its control persons involved in the offer and selling of securities. The SEC uses the Howey test as a standard for determining whether an asset is deemed an â€œinvestment Contractâ€ and thus a security, falling under the SECâ€™s jurisdiction. Here the SEC, in bringing this action against Ripple Labs, is acting pursuant to the authority granted by the statute and through a report which advised those who would use distributed ledger enabled means for capital raising to take appropriate steps to ensure compliance with federal securities law with a framework for digital assets. This is justified given that its considered an interpretive rule, and would fall under one of the exemptions under APA Â§533 (b). 

Background:
 
 On, December 22, 2020 the SEC brought a suit against Ripple Labs for violations of Section 5(a) and 5(c) of the Securities Act of 1933 by engaging in the unlawful offer and sale of unregistered securities. Around 2011 or early 2012, defendants coded the XRP Ledger, a digital asset that can be issued or transferred by using a distributed ledger. After the creation of the digital assets, the development team transferred a substantial amount of XRP to defendants as compensation. The SEC alleges that from 2013 to the present, the defendants offered or sold a portion of their individual holdings to the public. The SEC claims that XRP is an investment contract, and therefore a security. Therefore, the SEC claims that defendantâ€™s violated Section 5 by offering and selling XRP into the public market without first registering those offers and sales, and that they aided and abetted Rippleâ€™s violations as well. However, defendantâ€™s claim that they did not receive fair notice that XRP was a security. The analysis here, will revolve around the SECâ€™s action of bringing this suit and its impact on the regulatory landscape for digital assets. 
 
Analysis:

I. The SECâ€™s action of bringing a suit against Ripple Labs for violation of Section 5(a) and 5(c) of the Securities Act is justified under the Chevron Doctrine

The SECâ€™s action of bringing a suit against Ripple Labs for failure to register digital asset â€˜XRPâ€™ as a security, is justified under the Chevron doctrine and its interpretation of digital assets to fall under purview of the agency is reasonable. 

When Congress enacted the Securities Act its purpose was to regulate the offer and sale of securities. Section 21(a) of the Exchange Act authorizes the Commission to investigate violations of the federal securities laws, and in its discretion, to â€œpublish information concerning any such violations. Where a statute is ambiguous courts should defer to a reasonable interpretation of the statute by the agency responsible for administering it. When administering a Chevron analysis, the court engages in a two-step analysis. The first step involves reading the statute, and if the statute answers the question brought before the court the inquiry ends there. However, if the statute is ambiguous the second instructs the courts to determine whether the agencyâ€™s reading of the statute is a permissible construction of the statute. 

In Chevron the Supreme Court upheld an interpretation from the EPAâ€™s rule, holding that the meaning of the term in the Act was ambiguous, and the EPAâ€™s interpretation of that term was reasonable. 467 U.S. 837, at 866. Additionally, in Brand X the court affirmed the Chevron holding, by finding that a courtâ€™s prior judicial construction of a statute trumps an agency construction entitled to deference only if the prior court decision holds that its construction follows from the unambiguous terms of the statute and thus leaves no room for agency discretion. Also, in Howey, the Supreme Court faced with a case brought by the SEC against a citrus grove development for failure to register under federal securities law, the court held that an â€œinvestment contractâ€ exists where there is the investment of money in a common enterprise with a reasonable expectation of profits to be derived from the effort of others. This test applied to any contract, scheme, or transaction, regardless of its characteristics. Id at 299
When applying these cases to the facts, as the court found in Chevron, where the court was faced with an ambiguous term in the enabling act and deferred to the agencyâ€™s interpretation. Here, the term at issue â€œinvestment contractâ€ is not ambiguous and Congress has made an explicit determination that the SEC has authority to regulate compliance with federal security laws. Additionally, as in Brand X, here the Court has already addressed the interpretation of investment contract in Howey. Therefore, having stated that the statute addresses the terms at issue, the SECâ€™s action is justified under the Chevron Doctrine.

a. Although Ripple alleges that they did not receive fair notice that they did not receive fair notice, the SEC had provided reports which provided interpretations for the application of the investment contract test applied to digital assets.

 Ripple is asserting a defense that they did not receive fair notice that XRP was classified as a security. However, the SEC has provided guidance and reports which have provided a framework for analyzing whether a digital asset is an investment contract and whether offers and sales of a digital asset are securities transactions. Therefore, the SECâ€™s reports are valid and the agencies actions are justified.
 
 The Procedural Requirements for rulemaking by the APA under Â§553 (b), (c) do not apply, to interpretive rules, general statements of policy, or rules of agency organization, procedure or practice. Agencies may interpret their own legislative rules and the statutes they enforce. A rule is an interpretive rule only if it can be derived from regulation by a process reasonably described as interpretation. Administrative interpretation of a particular statutory provision which qualifies for Chevron deference when it appears that Congress delegated authority to the agency to make rules carrying force of law, and that the agency interpretation claiming deference was promulgated in the exercise of its statutory authority. 

 In Mead, the United States Customs set the classifications for tariff rates pursuant to rules promulgated by the United States Secretary of the Treasury. The classification for imports were made in â€œruling lettersâ€ issued before entry of the goods. 533 U.S. at 224. However, the ruling letters did not go through Notice and Comment process, instead they were subject to independent review by the Court. The Supreme Court found that the tariff classification had no claim for judicial deference because Congress did not intend that such rulings carried the force of law. Distinguishingly, in Hoctor the court was faced with internal memoranda by the Secretary of Agriculture that he published after the prescribed notice and comment process. 82F.3d at 3. The Secretary in the memoranda required perimeter fences to be under the rule that had been promulgated. Id at 6. However, the Court found that the internal memorandum was invalid because it was a substantive rule and was required to undergo the prescribed process by the APA. 

 When applying the past cases to the facts, one finds that differently from Hoctor, where the internal memoranda prescribed an arbitrary rule, here the SEC has published reports which provide an interpretation of the rule for â€œInvestment Contractsâ€ under the Securities Exchange Act. Additionally, as the Court mentioned in Mead, here it is acknowledged that Congress has granted rulemaking authority to the SEC. Having thus found that the SEC is justified in bringing the suit against Ripple Labs for asserting violation under Securities Law, the claim for lack of fair notice is invalid. Can you summarize following:
What are the lessons people most often learn too late in life?
Steve Jobs, Jobs's last words.

He died a billionaire at 56 years old from pancreatic cancer, and here are his last words on a sick bed:
â€²â€²I reached the peak of success in the business world. My life is the epitome of success in the opinion of others.

But, I have nothing to be happy about except work. In the end, wealth is just a reality of life that I am used to.
It was then, lying on a sick bed reminiscing my whole life, I realized all the recognition and the wealth that I was very proud of, became pale and meaningless in the face of the impending death.

You can hire someone to drive for you and make money for you, but you can't make someone else take the illness from you. Lost substance can be found. But there is one thing that can never be found when lost -â€life".

When a person enters the operating room, he will find that there is a book that has not yet been read - â€²â€² The Healthy Living Book ". No matter what stage of life we are in right now, over time we will face the day when the curtain falls.Cherish the family that loves you, love your spouse, love your friends... be kind to yourself.

As we age, we gradually realize that wearing a $300 or $30 watch - they tell the same time.

Whether we carry $300 or $30 purse / handbag - the money inside is the same.

Whether we drive a $150k car or a $30,000 car, the road and distance are the same and we reach the same destination.

Whether we drink a $300 bottle or a $10 bottle of wine - hangover is the same.

The house we live in 300 sq ft or 3000 sq ft - loneliness is the same.

You will realize that your true inner happiness does not come from the material things of this world.

Whether you take a plane on first or on economy class, if the plane collapses - you'll go with the flow.

Therefore, I hope you can recognize that when you have a partner, buddy, old friend, sibling, you talk, laugh, talk, sing, talk about North East Southwest or Heaven and Earth... that is true happiness!!â€

This is proportional to mg. In other words, any bird with a particular value of (L/D) consumes a fixed proportion of its weight in flying a unit distance, regardless of the size. Putting this another way, if a fixed proportion of the weight consists of fuel, the distance which can be flown on migration depends only on the lift : drag ratio. The number of air miles flown by, say, a swan and a hummingbird would be the same if both start with, say, 30% of their take-off weight as fuel, and if both have the same effective lift:drag ratio. 

Still, various considerations modify this argument in practice. Larger flyers tend to have better lift-to-drag ratio. Small birds are more affected by wind, etc.<|end_of_turn|>
